LaTeX word count

Format/colour codes of verbose output:

Text which is counted  ....  counted as text words
Header and title text  ....  counted as header words
Caption text and footnotes  ....  counted as caption words
Ignored text or code  ....  excluded or ignored
\documentclass  ....  document start, beginning of preamble
\macro  ....  macro not counted, but parameters may be
\macro  ....  macro in excluded region
[Macro options]  ....  not counted
\begin{group}  \end{group}  ....  begin/end group
\begin{group}  \end{group}  ....  begin/end group in excluded region
$  $  ....  counted as one equation
$  $  ....  equation in excluded region
% Comments  ....  not counted
%TC:TeXcount instructions  ....  not counted
File to include  ....  not counted but file may be counted later
[cumsum]  ....  cumulative sum count
ERROR  ....  TeXcount error message

File: Chapters/00_FrontMatter/00b_Abstract.tex

\begin{abstract} [0]
\thispagestyle{plain} % needed to print page number on abstract page [0]
%This is my last 3.5 years. Actually, make that 4. [0]
[0]
The CMS detector at the LHC has collected proton-proton data since 2010, enabling analysts to study the [17]
properties of the top quark, the heaviest known fundamental particle, in great detail. Starting with a [33]
description of the CMS detector and an overview of the Standard Model of particle physics, this thesis goes on [52]
to present a measurement of normalised differential cross sections of \ttbar production in the electron+jets [67]
and muon+jets channels with respect to global event variables.  5.0\fbinv of proton-proton collision data [82]
collected with the CMS experiment at \roots=7\TeV, and with 19.7\fbinv of data collected at \roots=8\TeV is [98]
used. The measurement is performed in bins of the following global event variables: missing transverse energy [114]
(\met), the scalar sum of jet transverse momenta (\HT), the scalar sum of the transverse momenta of all [130]
objects in the event (\st), the transverse momentum (\wpt) and the transverse mass (\mt) of the leptonically [144]
decaying \W boson from the \ttbar decay. [149]
[149]
The datasets used in the electron channel were obtained using an electron+jets trigger in 2011 and a single [168]
electron trigger in 2012. Muon datasets were obtained using a single muon trigger during both data taking [185]
periods. Following the application of selection criteria on the datasets and Monte Carlo simulation to obtain [201]
a \ttbar signal sample, and background samples from single top, \W/\ZpJets and QCD multi-jet processes, a fit [216]
of the simluated samples to data is carried out in each bin and in each channel to obtain a \ttbar event [236]
yield. The number of signal events is then unfolded to remove detector and selection effects. Combining the [253]
result from the two channels, the calculation of the normalised differential cross sections is performed. [268]
Comparison with common Monte Carlo generators, including with different modelling parameters, confirms [280]
previous CMS findings of a softer measured transverse momentum distribution than in simulations, but otherwise [295]
there is general consistency between generator predictions and data. [304]
[304]
\end{abstract}

File: Chapters/00_FrontMatter/00d_Declaration.tex

\chapter{Declaration} [1]
[1]
I declare that the work in this dissertation was carried out in accordance with the requirements of the University's [20]
Regulations and Code of Practice for Research Degree Programmes and that it has not been submitted for any other academic [40]
award. Except where indicated by specific reference in the text, the work is the candidate's own work. Work done in [60]
collaboration with, or with the assistance of, others, is indicated as such. Any views expressed in the dissertation are [79]
those of the author. [83]
[83]
\vspace{4cm} [83]
\noindent [83]
Signed:\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots \hfill [84]
Date:\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots\ldots [85]

File: Chapters/01_Introduction/01_Introduction.tex

\chapter{Introduction} [1]
\label{c:introduction} [1]
Particle physics research over the last century or so has provided us with our current basic understanding of [19]
the fundamental particles that have made up the universe since its origin, and their interactions with each [36]
other. This is summarised by the Standard Model (SM) of particle physics, which has been developed [52]
incrementally in recent decades and has stood up well to scientific scrutiny. The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) [69]
at the Organisation Europ\'{e}enne pour la Recherche Nucl\'{e}aire (CERN) near the Swiss city of Geneva [84]
(Figure~\ref{fig:LHC_map}) was constructed with the aim of investigating the SM. Areas of current interest [98]
including electroweak symmetry breaking, the Higgs mechanism and physics beyond the SM (BSM) such as [113]
supersymmetry (explained in further detail in Section~\ref{c:the_standard_model}), require the acceleration of [124]
particles to high energies (of the order of several TeV). The start of data-taking from proton-proton [140]
collisions at the LHC in 2009 ushered in a new era in terms of energies at particle colliders, taking over as [161]
the highest energy particle collider from the TeVatron at Fermilab. In 2010 and 2011 the LHC collected data at [180]
a centre of mass energy of 7\TeV (5.1\fbinv), followed by 8\TeV (21.8\fbinv) in 2012 and currently in 2015 [198]
after the first long shutdown at 13\TeV. [205]
[205]
The Compact Muon Solenoid (CMS) general-purpose detector is one of the four main detectors located around the [222]
LHC (the others being ATLAS, LHCb and ALICE), approximately 100\m below ground level. [235]
[235]
\begin{figure}[!hbtp] [235]
  \centering [235]
   \includegraphics[width=0.6\textwidth]{Chapters/01_Introduction/Images/lhc-pho-1997-169.jpg}\\ [235]
   \caption{Map of LHC location.} [239]
   \label{fig:LHC_map} [239]
\end{figure} [239]
[239]
This thesis presents an analysis based on the full proton-proton collision data from the CMS experiment in [256]
2011 and 2012. The analysis investigates the top-antitop (\ttbar) differential cross section with respect to [270]
global level event variables, specifically in semileptonic \ttbar decays in the electron+jets and muon+jets [285]
channels. This investigation is motivated primarily by the importance of understanding \ttbar events, since [298]
they are a significant background in many new physics analyses. The understanding of QCD and event generators [315]
that studies such as this provide is also helpful for other physics analyses. Furthermore, rare Standard Model [332]
processes such as $\ttbar + W\rightarrow l\nu$ or $\ttbar + Z\rightarrow \nu\bar{\nu}$ would appear in \met [341]
distribution tail, and $\ttbar + X$ where $X$ is massive would appear in the \HT and \st distributions. There [356]
are also possible new physics scenarios such as stop pair production, $\tilde{t}\bar{\tilde{t}} \rightarrow [368]
t\tilde{\chi_0} \bar{t}\bar{\tilde{\chi_0}}$ which could show hints of dark matter. [375]
[375]
The work presented here was carried out in collaboration with Emyr Clement, L{}ukasz Kreczko, Sergey Senkin [392]
and Philip Symonds under the supervision of Professors Joel Goldstein and Greg Heath. The main contribution of [409]
the author to these studies lay in development of the C++ and Python software frameworks and scripts used in [428]
the analyses. Related to this, maintaining up-to-date particle object definitions, corrections, efficiencies [440]
and prescription recommendations from working groups within CMS was a large component of the author's work. In [457]
terms of the technical workflow employed, the author was heavily involved in producing n-tuples from the [473]
analysis-ready AOD data format, running the software to perform the prescribed analysis methods, and running [488]
final scripts on the output ROOT data to perform the final calculation and to produce results plots and [506]
tables. Particular areas of focus regarding physics included synchronisation of the event selection, [519]
comparison of distribution shapes between 7\TeV and 8\TeV data, and implementing aspects of the analyses such [535]
as selection criteria, \btagging and jet energy resolution. [542]
[542]
Chapters~\ref{c:CMS_Detector} and \ref{c:CMS_computing_and_offline} describe the LHC and the CMS detector, [551]
including information about the object reconstruction process based on detector readout, to represent [564]
particles produced in collisions. Chapter~\ref{c:the_standard_model} provides an overview of the Standard [575]
Model theory and some of its shortcomings, followed by a review of physics of the top quark at the LHC in [596]
Chapter~\ref{c:top_physics_at_the_lhc}. A small study investigating the \btagging algorithms used in CMS is [607]
described in Chapter~\ref{c:b_tagging_study}, and the main \ttbar differential cross section analysis is then [619]
covered in Chapters~\ref{c:Differential_Cross_Section:data_simulation_and_selection}, [622]
\ref{c:Differential_Cross_Section:fitting_unfolding_and_measurement} [622]
and~\ref{c:Differential_Cross_Section:systematics_and_results}. To conclude, Chapter~\ref{c:summary} contains [627]
a summary and outlook to the future. Additional data, tables and plots from the presented analyses are given [645]
in Appendices~\ref{ac:b_tagging_plots} and \ref{ac:ttbar_diff_cross_section_analysis}. Finally, an addendum [651]
describing the brief continuation of work from the author's MSc in testing a readout chip for the CMS strip [670]
tracker is outlined in Appendix~\ref{ac:cbc}. [675]
[675]
From the outset, natural units are used throughout this thesis, unless otherwise specifed, so that [690]
\begin{equation} [691]
\hbar = c = 1, [691]
\end{equation} [691]
meaning that mass, momentum and energy all have the same units of electronVolts (eV).

  • Included file: Chapters/01_Introduction/01_Introduction.tex

  • Words in text: 694

  • Number of headers: 1
  • Number of floats: 1
  • Number of math inlines: 5
  • Number of math displayed: 1

File: Chapters/02_Detector/02a_TheCMSDetectorAtTheLHC.tex

\chapter{The CMS Detector at the LHC} [6]
\label{c:CMS_Detector} [6]
[6]
\section{Introduction to the LHC} [4]
\label{s:Introduction} [4]
The CMS general-purpose detector is one of four detectors located around the LHC, approximately 100\m below [20]
ground level. The CERN accelerator complex and the locations of the various experiments around the LHC are [37]
shown in Figure~\ref{fig:LHC_schematic}. [40]
[40]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [40]
  \centering [40]
   \includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{Chapters/02_Detector/Images/0812015.jpg}\\ [40]
   \caption[Schematic of LHC and experiments.]{Schematic of CERN accelerator complex including the LHC and [49]
    experiments. [50]
    CMS is located at Point 5 on the LHC ring.} [60]
   \label{fig:LHC_schematic} [60]
\end{figure} [60]
[60]
The 27\km circumference LHC can collide two proton beams, each composed of 2808 bunches, at a design energy of [79]
7\TeV per beam (meaning a 14\TeV centre of mass energy, \roots, in collisions) with a luminosity $\mathcal{L}$ [95]
of $10^{34}\cm^{-2}\s^{-1}$ at a collision rate of 25\ns (40~\MHz). Each event that is recorded in the CMS [112]
detector is one crossing of the bunches of protons of which the beams are comprised. During the first part of [132]
Run 1 in 2011 the machine ran at a centre of mass energy of 7\TeV at a bunch spacing of 50\ns (leading to 8 [156]
proton-proton interactions per bunch crossing) and CMS recorded a peak instantaneous luminosity of [169]
$3.7\times10^{33}\cm^{-2}\s^{-1}$. In 2012 the centre of mass energy was increased to 8\TeV (21 proton-proton [183]
interactions per bunch crossing) and CMS recorded a peak instantaneous luminosity of [195]
$7.7\times10^{33}\cm^{-2}\s^{-1}$. Since Run 2 began in May 2015 after Long Shutdown 1, the LHC has been [211]
operating at a collision energy of 13\TeV and CMS recorded a peak instantaneous luminosity of [226]
$4.7\times10^{33}\cm^{-2}\s^{-1}$ at a collision rate of 25\ns initially, before switching to 50\ns. [238]
The design collision energy and luminosity are scheduled to be attained later in Run 2 and after Long Shutdown [257]
2 (in 2019) respectively. 6.1\fbinv and 23.3\fbinv of data was delivered to CMS during the 2011 and 2012 data [276]
taking periods respectively; Figure~\ref{fig:integrated_luminosity} shows the increase in integrated [285]
luminosities delivered to CMS over time during 2010$--$2012. [295]
[295]
The acceleration process begins with a tank of hydrogen (see Figure~\ref{fig:LHC_schematic}). After stripping [308]
electrons off the hydrogen atoms using an electric field, the remaining protons are inserted into the Linear [325]
Accelerator 2 (LINAC2) which accelerates them up to 50\MeV. From here, the proton beam is injected into the [343]
Proton Synchrotron Booster (PSB) which increases the energy to 1.4\GeV, followed by the Proton Synchrotron [358]
(PS) which accelerates the beam to 25\GeV and the Super Proton Synchrotron (SPS) where the beam energy reaches [376]
450\GeV. Finally, the protons are injected into the LHC where two beampipes carry the beams in a clockwise and [395]
an anti-clockwise direction while accelerating them up to the required collision energy. Filling the LHC rings [411]
takes approximately 4 minutes, followed by approximately 20 minutes until the beams reach energies of 4\TeV [427]
(during 2012 data taking). The beams are accelerated by radio frequency cavities, and superconducting dipole [442]
magnets bend the beams to maintain their trajectory around the LHC beampipe. Once the collision energy has [459]
been attained, the beams are ``squeezed'' to focus them into a cross sectional area of approximately 16\um [476]
using superconducting quadrupole magnets. Collimators act to scrape away protons, thereby maintaining beam [489]
losses to the superconducting magnets below the level that would cause quenching. The counter-circulating [503]
beams are brought to collide at the four main LHC experiments CMS, ATLAS, LHCb and ALICE. ATLAS, like CMS, is [523]
a general purpose detector, ALICE is specifically designed to investigate heavy ion collisions (as opposed to [539]
protons), while LHCb investigates b-meson physics. [545]
[545]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [545]
  \centering [545]
   \includegraphics[width=0.75\textwidth]{Chapters/02_Detector/Images/int_lumi_cumulative_pp_2.png}\\ [545]
   \caption[Cumulative luminosity delivered to CMS during 2010, 2011 and 2012.]{Cumulative luminosity [547]
    delivered to CMS over time during 2010, 2011 and 2012 proton-proton data taking periods.} [561]
   \label{fig:integrated_luminosity} [561]
\end{figure} [561]
[561]
\section{Overview of CMS} [3]
\label{s:Overview} [3]
Compact Muon Solenoid is both the name of the detector at the LHC, and of the collaboration of people [22]
worldwide who work to build, operate, maintain and upgrade it, and to analyse the data it records. [39]
[39]
CMS is a general-purpose detector, designed to be efficient at detecting new physics with a wide range of [57]
signals. The detector measures 14.6\m in diameter and 21.6\m in length, and weighs 12500~tonnes [72]
\cite{CMS_experiment}. The different sub-detectors of CMS are arranged in concentric layers around the point [85]
of the beampipe at which the two beams of proton bunches collide, known as the interaction point (see [103]
Figure~\ref{fig:CMS_diagram}). As the products of any collisions that occur in the bunch crossing travel [117]
outwards from the interaction point, they pass through the sub-detectors depositing energy, resulting in [131]
signals being produced. A subset of the information from some sub-detectors (the calorimeters and muon [146]
chambers, described in Section~\ref{s:Subdetectors}) is then processed by a trigger while information from [159]
other sub-detectors is buffered on the detector. [166]
[166]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [166]
  \centering [166]
   \includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{Chapters/02_Detector/Images/cms_120918_02.pdf}\hfill [166]
   \caption[Diagrammatic sectional view of the CMS detector.]{Diagrammatic sectional view of the CMS [172]
    detector [173]
    \cite{Sakuma_sketchup}.} [173]
   \label{fig:CMS_diagram} [173]
\end{figure} [173]
[173]
The design of CMS is based firstly around a superconducting solenoid magnet. Around and inside the magnet are [191]
the sub-detectors: the pixel and strip tracker, the electromagnetic calorimeter, the hadronic calorimeter, the [205]
return yoke for the magnet and the muon detectors. The coordinate system of the detector is designated with [223]
the origin as the intersection point of the two beams in the beampipe, the x-axis positive towards the centre [242]
of the LHC ring, the y-axis positive vertically upwards and the z-axis pointing along the beampipe in an [260]
anticlockwise direction. The azimuthal angle, $\phi$, is defined as the angle in the x-y plane, transverse to [277]
the beampipe starting from the x-axis. The polar angle, $\theta$, is defined as the angle in the z-y plane [296]
starting from the z-axis (the beampipe). The angle $\theta$ is related to the pseudorapidity, $\eta$, by the [313]
formula $\eta=-\ln(\tan(\theta/2))$, so that $\eta$ ranges from 0 at $\theta=90~\degreeCelsius$ to $\infty$ at [326]
$\theta=0~\degreeCelsius$~\cite{CMS_TDR1}. The two ends of the detector, at high $\abseta$ values, are called [339]
the endcap regions while the central area at lower $\abseta$ values is called the barrel region. The detector [357]
volume is often denoted in terms of $\Delta R$, with the separation between two particles 1 and 2 being [375]
defined as [377]
\begin{equation} [378]
\Delta R = \sqrt{(\eta_{1} - \eta_{2})^{2} + (\phi_{1} - \phi_{2})^{2}}. [378]
\end{equation} [378]
[378]
\section{Sub-Detectors} [1]
\label{s:Subdetectors} [1]
[1]
\subsection{Tracker} [1]
\label{ss:Tracker} [1]
[1]
Any charged particles produced as a result of the proton-proton collisions in these bunch crossings need to be [19]
recorded for later use in reconstruction of particle information such as trajectories and charges. This is [35]
achieved using the tracker section of CMS which consists of silicon sensors in two forms: pixels and strips. [53]
As the charged particles travel through these silicon sensors, electron-hole pairs are produced that induce a [69]
current in the sensors and are processed by readout chips. This readout is carried out by the Analogue [87]
Pipeline Voltage 25 (APV25) chip. A new chip called the CMS Binary Chip (CBC) is intended to replace the APV25 [107]
in the HL-LHC after Long Shutdown 3, currently scheduled for 2023-2024. The CBC is described in more detail in [126]
Appendix~\ref{ac:cbc}. [127]
[127]
The purpose of the tracker within the CMS detector is to track the trajectory of charged particles as they [146]
travel out from the interaction point. An important requirement of the tracker is that it must allow the above [165]
whilst not affecting the energy of the particle being tracked. The silicon in the tracker sensors also does [183]
not stop particles, thereby allowing them to pass through this innermost layer of the detector and interact [200]
with outer layers. The tracker readout chips must also be able to distinguish from which bunch crossing a [218]
particle was produced (bunch-crossing identification) in order for the trigger to remove particles from [232]
previous bunch crossings (termed out-of-time pileup) and fully reconstruct events. [242]
[242]
The tracker is split into two parts, with an inner silicon pixel detector and an outer silicon strip detector. [261]
A diagrammatic view of the tracker, including both pixels and strips, is shown in [275]
Figure~\ref{fig:CMS_strip_tracker}. The inner pixel detector consists of three layers in the barrel region at [289]
distances of 4.4\cm, 7.3\cm and 10.2\cm from the beam line with two endcap discs at each end. Each pixel [308]
measures 100\um by 150\um. The entire pixel detector covers an area of only approximately $1\m^{2}$ but [324]
contains 66~million pixels in total. [330]
[330]
The strip tracker is comprised of ten layers in the barrel region at distances ranging from 20\cm to 1.1\m [349]
from the beampipe. The four inner layers (at distances of 26\cm, 34\cm, 42\cm and 50\cm from the beampipe) [367]
are collectively named the Tracker Inner Barrel (TIB), while the outer six layers (at distances of 61\cm, [384]
70\cm, 78\cm, 87\cm, 97\cm and 108\cm from the beampipe) are known as the Tracker Outer Barrel (TOB). [401]
The endcaps consist of twelve discs, three of which correspond to the Tracker Inner Discs (TID) at z-distances [419]
from 75\cm to 100\cm, and nine to the Tracker End Caps (TEC) at z-distances between 120\cm and 280\cm [437]
\cite{Palmonari:1260970}. The largest silicon detector ever constructed, the strip tracker contains about ten [449]
million channels and covers an area of approximately $200\m^{2}$ \cite{CMS_experiment,CMS_TDR1}. The operating [460]
temperature of the tracker during 2011 and 2012 has been $0~\degreeCelsius$ for the pixels and [475]
$+4~\degreeCelsius$ for the strips but will be lowered for both after Long Shutdown 1~\cite{Butz:1497745}. [489]
[489]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [489]
  \centering [489]
   \includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{Chapters/02_Detector/Images/tracker.pdf}\hfill [489]
   \caption[Cross sectional diagram of the CMS strip tracker.]{Cross sectional diagram of the CMS strip [496]
    tracker; each line represents a detector module [503]
    \cite{CMS_TDR1}} [503]
   \label{fig:CMS_strip_tracker} [503]
\end{figure} [503]
[503]
As a charged particle passes through the various layers of silicon in these detectors, electrical signals are [520]
created which are then read by readout electronics. Offline algorithms then use the data relating to which [537]
strips and sensors received `hits' to reconstruct the tracks of charged particles and this information is [553]
later used for particle reconstruction and identification \cite{CMS_experiment,CMS_Tracking_Early_Results}. [560]
[560]
% Neutral particles could also leave signals in the tracker in a small proportion of cases if the particle [560]
% interacts with a silicon atom and/or converts to charged particles such as a photon conversion to two [560]
% electrons. In the majority of cases, the presence of neutral particles must be detected from their energy [560]
% deposits in the calorimeters. [560]
The curving of particle tracks within a magnetic field allows the calculation of the particle momentum and [577]
charge, $mv=RqB$, where $mv$ is the momentum of the particle, $R$ is the radius of curvature, q is the [596]
electric charge, and B is the magnetic field strength. [605]
[605]
%With the higher data rate expected after the LHC upgrades over the coming decade, [605]
%pile-up will become an important issue, with approximately 20 interactions per bunch crossing even at the [605]
%current design luminosity. This number is expected to increase to 100-200 following Long Shutdown 3. [605]
[605]
%At higher luminosities, the occupancy (the fraction of channels with a 'hit') increases, [605]
%which makes pattern recognition more difficult for track reconstruction algorithms and readout systems. The [605]
%higher tracker resolution desirable for such circumstances also requires more sensors and readout chips. As a [605]
%result, any new chip would need to be more efficient in its use of power whilst processing the data and/or [605]
%require the associated cooling systems to be more efficient. Indeed, studies have shown that the present [605]
%tracker could itself produce acceptable tracking performance in such conditions based on simulations of [605]
%heavy-ion collisions, which produce similar numbers of tracks per event to that expected after the luminosity [605]
%upgrades at the LHC [10]. [605]
[605]
%The LHC upgrades are split into 2 phases. The pixel detector will be upgraded during Phase 1, and will be an [605]
%on-going process during both Long Shutdown 1, Long Shutdown 2 and shorter intermediate shutdowns. The strip [605]
%detector will be upgraded during Phase 2, more specifically during Long Shutdown 3 [11][12]. [605]
[605]
The required tracker characteristics of high granularity and resolution, fast response to process the high [620]
data rate without losing potentially valuable information, radiation hardness and keeping detector material to [634]
a minimum to minimise interactions of the particles with detector matter, resulted in silicon being chosen to [651]
construct the tracker. [654]
[654]
One of the advantages of using silicon over gaseous detectors is that silicon produces more charge carriers [671]
per unit of length travelled by a particle. This therefore means the silicon thickness can be reduced, [688]
typically around 300\um per layer. The silicon sensors that make up the strip tracker in the CMS detector vary [707]
in thickness depending on their location. Sensors of 320\um thickness are utilised in the TIB and TID, 500\um [725]
in the TOB, and a mixture of both thicknesses is used in the TEC. Thicker sensors are used in the outer [746]
sections of the strip tracker in order to maintain a high signal to noise ratio, since the increased strip [765]
lengths in this region lead to increased electronics noise due to higher capacitance~\cite{CMS_experiment}. [778]
[778]
Silicon also allows fast signal transfer, of the order of about 10\ns, as the charge carriers travel quickly [796]
through silicon. Furthermore, the spacing between strips in a silicon sensor, known as the strip pitch, can be [814]
manufactured to be extremely small, down to around 50\um. The strip pitches and their lengths vary such that [832]
there are fifteen distinct types of sensor geometries in the strip [843]
tracker~\cite{Commissioning_and_Performance_Strip_Tracker}. [844]
[844]
A further tracker requirement is low occupancy (the fraction of channels with a hit in an event was desired to [864]
be 1~\% or lower at the nominal LHC luminosity) so that pattern recognition can be carried out efficiently and [883]
so the amount of simultaneous data to be read out is manageable. In order to maintain such a low occupancy, [903]
the strip tracker has a high granularity, with strip lengths less than 20\cm and strip pitches less than [921]
205\um~\cite{Palmonari:1260970}. While high granularity is beneficial for high precision tracking, it also [933]
results in a high number of channels, which in turn requires a large amount of electronics for readout and [952]
leads to a high heat load. [958]
[958]
On a global scale, the tracker data is read out using a combination of interoperating systems. [974]
The data from the APV25 tracker readout chips is taken via optical fibres to 440 [989]
off-detector Front End Drivers (FEDs) (tracker FEDs make up 63~\% of the total number of FEDs in CMS). [1007]
The FEDs then forward the data to the online Data Acquisition System (DAQ). In addition, off-detector Front [1024]
End Controllers (FECs) control the front-end electronics by means of approximately 350 control rings, [1038]
including triggers, clock and monitoring~\cite{CMS_experiment, Corrin}. [1043]
[1043]
%As a result of the higher collision rates to be expected after [1043]
%these upgrades, the CMS tracker will require an improvement in its infrastructure because of radiation damage [1043]
%it will have suffered by that point and to ensure that it is robust enough to handle the higher levels of [1043]
%radiation after the upgrades. The pile-up is also expected to be in the range of 100 to 200 interactions per [1043]
%bunch crossing which also necessitates an improvement in the CMS tracker performance in order to ensure [1043]
%valuable data are not lost during collisions \cite{CMS_Silicon_Tracker_upgrade_for_HL-LHC}. [1043]
[1043]
% Within the lattice of pure silicon, there are well-defined bands of energy levels called the conduction band [1043]
% and the valence band. The band gap is the difference in energy between these two bands and varies depending on [1043]
% the material. At absolute zero, -273$^{\circ}$C, almost all the electrons can be said to be fixed in place in [1043]
% this lattice in the valence band, meaning that if an electric field is applied across the silicon, no current [1043]
% would be able to flow. When energy is input to the system and an electron gains energy, it may be able to [1043]
% cross the band gap to the conduction band, in which case a hole would be present in its previous place in the [1043]
% valence band. At this point, both the electron and the hole are mobile and can move freely in current flow, [1043]
% for example, under the influence of an electric potential. Materials with a large band gap are insulators, and [1043]
% those with a small band gap (or even sometimes with energy bands that overlap with each other) are conductors. [1043]
% Silicon, being a semiconductor, has a 'medium' sized band gap of approximately 1.12eV. Nevertheless, the [1043]
% number of mobile electrons, above absolute zero, is still large enough to make it difficult to distinguish the [1043]
% real signal from the inherent noise in the silicon, known as leakage current (explained in Section 2.3.2). [1043]
% In order to decrease this number of free electrons and holes in silicon to obtain a much cleaner signal from a [1043]
% traversing particle (i.e. improve the signal to noise ratio), a process called doping is employed to increase [1043]
% the number of charge carriers. This involves the substituting of silicon atoms in the lattice with atoms of [1043]
% other elements like arsenic, phosphorous, boron or aluminium. In the case of the former two, both have five [1043]
% valence electrons. Four of these electrons bond to the four valence electrons present in a silicon atom, [1043]
% leaving one electron that can be easily removed from the lattice to the conduction band. This 'donation' of [1043]
% electrons to the conduction band increases the number of charge carriers. This type of silicon is called [1043]
% n-type silicon because the additional charge carriers are negative. Similarly, if boron or aluminium atoms are [1043]
% introduced to the silicon lattice, their three valence electrons bond to the electrons in a silicon atom but [1043]
% one silicon electron has nothing to bond to, creating a mobile positive hole. The addition of holes (which [1043]
% 'accept' electrons) leads to this type of silicon being called p-type because the additional charge carriers [1043]
% are positive. [1043]
% Although both p- and n-type silicon increase the number of free charge carriers, a PN-junction can be created [1043]
% by attaching a piece of n-type silicon to a piece of p-type silicon. Considering a PN-junction in isolation, [1043]
% mobile electrons from the n-type silicon would diffuse into the p-type silicon and unite with the holes from [1043]
% the p-type material, leaving behind the positively charged donor atoms. Similarly, the mobile holes from the [1043]
% p-type silicon would diffuse to the n-type silicon and leave behind negatively charged acceptor atoms. As [1043]
% these electrons and holes move to the two sides of the junction, the resulting electric field opposes the [1043]
% initial diffusion of electrons and holes, eventually reaching a state of equilibrium. Once equilibrium is [1043]
% reached, this area around the PN-junction will contain no mobile charge carriers and is called the depletion [1043]
% region. [1043]
% However, if a reverse bias voltage is applied to the silicon (a negative terminal connected to the p-type [1043]
% silicon and a positive terminal to the n-type silicon), then the electrons from the n-type silicon, rather [1043]
% than diffusing towards the junction, will be attracted towards the positive terminal. Similarly, the holes [1043]
% from the p-type silicon will be attracted towards the negative terminal, as shown in Figure 7. [1043]
% [1043]
%  [1043]
% A higher reverse bias voltage leads to a larger depletion width as more electrons and holes are carried away [1043]
% from the junction. At high enough voltages, the width of the depletion region can be made equal to the width [1043]
% of the silicon; this voltage is known as the depletion voltage. At this stage, there are no free charge [1043]
% carriers anywhere in the silicon and it is in this state that silicon detectors are operated, thus ensuring [1043]
% that any charge carriers are only produced as a charged particle travels through the silicon. In this state, [1043]
% silicon detectors are effectively reverse biased diodes, only allowing a current to flow in one direction. [1043]
[1043]
%Figure 8 - Basic diagram of silicon strip detector with p+ strips (green) on n-bulk (blue) [24]. [1043]
[1043]
% The silicon sensors in the CMS strip tracker are p+ strips (which denotes a high concentration of p-type [1043]
% impurities) on n-bulk sensors, similar to the diagram in Figure 8. As the silicon is ionised by a traversing [1043]
% particle, mobile charge carriers are created which then travel, due to the depletion voltage, to the p+ strips [1043]
% (holes) or to the backplane (electrons). As the signal will be created on a particular strip (or strips), it [1043]
% will then be possible to deduce the position of the particle. [1043]
[1043]
% 2.3.2 Radiation Hardness The current tracker front-end electronics were initially designed to last about 10 [1043]
% years in operation under the radiation conditions of the detector [5]. The higher radiation they will be [1043]
% subjected to as a result of the higher luminosity and higher collision energies at the HL-LHC will clearly [1043]
% impose the requirement that all components, including sensors and electronics, should be manufactured to a [1043]
% higher standard of radiation hardness. Radiation damage can occur when particles of high enough energy are [1043]
% created in the collisions at the centre of CMS that when they pass through the silicon tracker, they collide [1043]
% with atoms in the lattice. This damage is done most often by neutrons, in particular low energy neutrons from [1043]
% calorimeters and other detector elements, which interact with nuclei in the silicon and move atoms out of [1043]
% place. These atoms are knocked out of place into levels where there is usually no atom, known as interstitial [1043]
% levels. An energy of around 15eV is necessary for this to happen; generally at energies of 2keV or less only [1043]
% isolated displacements occur, whereas for energies between 2 and 12keV, one or more defect clusters will be [1043]
% created. The removal of donor atoms in this way leads to a change in the doping concentrations and eventually [1043]
% to an increase in the leakage current (current which may flow when there is no ionising particle traversing [1043]
% the silicon). A leakage current will in turn require a higher depletion voltage to remove additional electrons [1043]
% or holes captured by the electronically active defects. [1043]
% The leakage current is temperature dependent and can be mitigated by using low temperatures. The planned [1043]
% running temperature of the CMS silicon tracker in the HL-LHC is planned to be lowered from +4$^{\circ}$C to [1043]
% the region of -20$^{\circ}$C to -40$^{\circ}$C due to the benefits in terms of radiation damage. To evaluate [1043]
% the behaviour of the proposed CBC in these conditions, an environmental chamber was used to carry out tests at [1043]
% varying temperatures in this project. If a leakage current is present, this will lead to noise in the system, [1043]
% since current will always flow and any signal would sit on top of this noise. If subject to high levels of [1043]
% radiation damage, the leakage current increases to levels at which excessive amounts of power are dissipated, [1043]
% and the noise in the readout will be too high to read a clean signal. [1043]
% [1043]
% 2.3.3 Noise The aforementioned leakage current is a result of the quantised nature of the charge carriers. [1043]
% This noise is present even when there is no signal present, and increases as radiation damage increases the [1043]
% leakage current. [1043]
% Other potential sources of noise include electronic noise caused by thermal fluctuations of the charge [1043]
% carriers. This would manifest as noise in the amplifier at the front end of the CBC and would increase [1043]
% proportionally with the capacitance of the connected input system [25]. Another contributor to noise in the [1043]
% system could be from non-linearity of the analogue to digital converter (ADC) in the CBC that converts the [1043]
% incoming analogue pulse to a digital signal [25]. [1043]
% The dominant source of noise in our test system is likely to have resulted from electronic noise in the [1043]
% connected laboratory setup. In practice, the external noise under operational conditions when the CBC is [1043]
% connected to the CMS detector should ideally be maintained lower than the noise in the amplifier. [1043]
[1043]
[1043]
\subsection{Electromagnetic Calorimeter} [2]
\label{ss:Ecal} [2]
The electromagnetic calorimeter (ECAL), is a hermetic, homogeneous sub-detector constructed of scintillating [14]
crystals of lead tungstate ($\mathrm{PbWO_{4}}$), and is the next layer outside the tracker. Any [28]
electromagnetic particles such as electrons or photons are absorbed by the ECAL crystals which then [43]
scintillate emitting a blue-green coloured light. These signals are then collected and converted to electrical [58]
signals by connected photodetectors, and processed by readout electronics. [67]
[67]
The signals in the crystals are collected by avalanche photodiodes in the barrel region and vacuum [83]
phototriodes in the endcaps. The numbers of photoelectrons produced is dependent on temperature, with [97]
increasing temperature resulting in a decrease in the number of electrons at a rate of [112]
$-3.8\pm0.4\%/\degreeCelsius$. A cooling system is thus employed which maintains a stable operating [124]
temperature of the ECAL system to within $\pm0.05\degreeCelsius$, with a nominal operating temperature of [138]
$18\degreeCelsius$~\cite{CMS_experiment}. The energy resolution of the ECAL has been shown to follow [150]
$\sigma_{E}/E = 2.8\%/\sqrt{E}\oplus 12\%/E \oplus 0.3\%$ where the three constant terms come from stochastic [159]
fluctations such as photostatistics, electronics noise and temperature stability and calibration uncertainties [171]
\cite{ECAL_calibration_and_resolution_at_7TeV}. [171]
[171]
The barrel region of the ECAL consists of 61,200 crystals and extends up to a pseudorapidity $\eta\pm1.479$. [189]
Each individual barrel crystal is $25.8X_{0}$ thick, where $X_{0}$ is the radiation length (the mean distance [205]
over which a high energy electron loses all but 1/$e$ of its energy through bremsstrahlung [221]
radiation~\cite{Agashe:2014kda}), and has cross sectional dimensions of $22\times22\mm^{2}$, which equates to [232]
$0.0174\times0.0174$ in $\eta-\phi$ plane. These crystals are divided into 36 groups, called supermodules, [245]
with each supermodule consisting of 4 smaller modules. The endcaps are comprised of 7,324 crystals, cover the [263]
range $1.479\leq\eta\leq3.0$ and are split into two halves known as ``Dees'', each divided into operating [278]
segments of $40\degreeCelsius$ each. The endcap crystals have slightly larger dimensions, having a thickness [292]
of $24.7X_{0}$ and cross sectional dimensions of [299]
$28.62\times28.62\mm^{2}$~\cite{CMS_experiment,ECAL_frontend_monitoring}. Figure~\ref{fig:CMS_ECAL} shows the [303]
layout of the ECAL. [307]
[307]
The crystals of high density ($8.28~\g/\cm^{3}$), short radiation length ($X_{0}=0.89\cm$), and small [319]
Moli\`{e}re radius (a measure of the transverse dimensions of electromagnetic showers in a [332]
material~\cite{Agashe:2014kda}) of 2.2\cm lead to a compact calorimeter with fast response time (80~\% of the [347]
light is emitted within 25\ns) and high granularity, capable of withstanding the radiation levels within CMS. [363]
[363]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [363]
  \centering [363]
   \includegraphics[width=0.7\textwidth]{Chapters/02_Detector/Images/ECAL.pdf}\hfill [363]
   \caption[Diagram of the ECAL showing barrel supermodules, endcaps and preshower detectors.]{Diagram of [365]
    the ECAL showing barrel supermodules, endcaps and preshower [373]
    detectors~\cite{ECAL_calibration_and_resolution_at_7TeV}.} [374]
   \label{fig:CMS_ECAL} [374]
\end{figure} [374]
[374]
An ECAL preshower, comprised of two lead plates each followed by a layer of orthogonal silicon strip sensors [392]
(thickness 350\mm, strip pitch 2\mm) is located between the tracker and ECAL endcaps to provide a higher [409]
spatial resolution than the ECAL. This helps to identify, for instance, closely spaced photon pairs [424]
originating from pion decays which may otherwise be identified as a single high-energy photon based on ECAL [441]
energy deposits. As photons pass through the lead, a shower of electromagnetic particles ($e^{+}e^{-}$ pairs) [456]
is produced that are detected by the silicon layers to give a measure of the energy of the photon, while the [477]
orthogonal strips allow a position measurement. The measured energy can then be combined with the energy [493]
measured by the ECAL. [497]
[497]
\subsection{Hadronic Calorimeter} [2]
\label{ss:Hcal} [2]
The next sub-detector outside the ECAL is the hadronic calorimeter (HCAL) which works in a similar way to [20]
the ECAL, in this case by absorbing hadron jets. The HCAL is located at a distance of 1.77~m to 2.95~m from [43]
the beamline, with an additional outer hadronic calorimeter also installed outside the magnet due to [58]
radial restrictions imposed by the magnet coil. The HCAL barrel (HB), outer (HO) and endcaps (HE) cover [75]
the $\abseta$ range up to 3.0, with the forward HCAL (HF) placed at $\abseta$ up to 5.2 increasing the [94]
coverage. Figure~\ref{fig:CMS_HCAL} shows a quarter of the HCAL endcap. [103]
[103]
The HCAL is a sampling calorimeter, meaning it is composed of alternating absorber layers (made of brass) and [121]
scintillator layers (made of plastic). A hadronic particle produces a shower of secondary particles when it [137]
strikes an absorber layer. This process is repeated as these secondary particles themselves pass through [152]
successive absorber layers. The scintillator layers in between absorb the energy of these particles, emitting [167]
light as they do which is fed to readout electronics via optical fibres to measure the particle energies. [185]
[185]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [185]
  \centering [185]
   \includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{Chapters/02_Detector/Images/HCAL.pdf}\hfill [185]
   \caption[A longitudinal schematic of the CMS HCAL.]{A longitudinal schematic of the CMS HCAL showing the [194]
    location of the hadron barrel (HB), endcap (HE), outer (HO) and forward (HF) calorimeters [208]
    \cite{CMS_experiment}.} [208]
   \label{fig:CMS_HCAL} [208]
\end{figure} [208]
[208]
\subsection{Superconducting Magnet} [2]
\label{ss:Magnet} [2]
The magnet of the CMS detector is the largest and highest field strength superconducting solenoid constructed [18]
for a physics experiment in terms of bending power for physics and total stored energy~\cite{CMS_experiment}. [33]
It can produce a magnetic field up to 4~\tesla~ (a field strength of 3.8~\tesla~ is used in normal operation) [52]
with a stored energy of 2.7~\giga\joule~\cite{CMS_TDR1}. The cold bore, cooled to 4.5~\kelvin~ using liquid [66]
helium, has dimensions of 12.5\m length and 6\m diameter, and weighs [77]
220~tonnes~\cite{Cryogenic_System_for_Superconducting_Solenoid}. [79]
Due to design constraints and structural requirements, the magnet itself provides some of the structural [94]
strength both to support itself and to withstand its own magnetic bursting force on the coil [110]
\cite{CMS_experiment}. [110]
[110]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [110]
  \centering [110]
   \includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{Chapters/02_Detector/Images/Cold_mass.png}\hfill [110]
   \caption[Bore of the CMS solenoid magnet in vertical position in the CMS assembly hall, SX5.]{Bore of the [113]
    CMS solenoid magnet in vertical position in the CMS assembly hall, SX5, prior to installation \cite{CMS_experiment}} [128]
   \label{fig:CMS_magnet_cold_bore} [128]
\end{figure} [128]
[128]
The cold bore, pictured in Figure~\ref{fig:CMS_magnet_cold_bore} in the CMS assembly hall, is enclosed in a [143]
steel return yoke weighing 10,000~tonnes with the aim of containing and returning the magnetic field. The yoke [162]
is interspersed with the muon chambers and is made up of 5 barrel segments and 6 endcap discs. The magnet was [183]
designed in a manner such as to facilitate assembly at ground level prior to lowering into the CMS [201]
experimental cavern, UX5. Despite the challenges involved in constructing such a powerful magnet, the high [216]
bending-power created by the high magnetic field was desirable in order to provide good momentum [231]
resolution of the tracking components. [236]
[236]
\subsection{Muon Chambers} [2]
\label{ss:Muon_Chambers} [2]
Muons pass through all the previous inner sub-detectors, losing very little energy as they traverse them [18]
(around 1\MeV/\mm on average), leading to the muon chambers being located outermost in the detector. There [34]
are, in fact, three types of muon detectors in use in CMS. The endcaps contain Cathode Strip Chambers (CSCs), [53]
the central barrel regions contain Drift Tubes (DTs), and both regions are equipped with Resistive Plate [69]
Chambers (RPCs). These systems, in combination with the silicon tracker, are used to determine the momentum of [86]
muons by taking advantage of their curved tracks due to the magnetic field. The different technologies are [103]
used due to the different numbers of particles expected in different areas of the detector and because of [121]
technological considerations regarding the physical areas to be covered~\cite{CMS_TDR1}. [130]
Figure~\ref{fig:CMS_muon_system} shows a diagrammatic representation of one quarter of the CMS muon detectors. [143]
The CSCs are used in the endcaps to cover \abseta values between 1.2 and 2.4 that experience high muon rates [162]
and where the magnetic field of the solenoid is high~\cite{CMS_TDR1}. They take the form of four disc layers [180]
each made of 2 (inner layer) or 3 (outer three layers) concentric rings. They consist of volumes of gas in [200]
which positive wires are placed at right angles to negative copper strips. To relate these to the name given [219]
to these detectors, the positive wires are the anodes and the negative strips are the cathodes. As a charged [238]
particle passes through the gas it ionises gas atoms and the electrons that are knocked out travel towards the [257]
anode wires. At the same time the resulting positively charged ions in the gas travel towards the cathode [275]
strips. Since the wires and strips are at right angles to each other, the CSCs provide two position [293]
co-ordinates for the passing muon. The CSC detection mechanism is a fast process so their signals are used for [312]
muon triggering~\cite{CMS_experiment}. [314]
[314]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [314]
  \centering [314]
   \includegraphics[width=0.65\textwidth]{Chapters/02_Detector/Images/MuonSys-mod3.png}\hfill [314]
   \caption[Schematic representation of a quarter of the CMS muon system.]{Schematic representation of a [318]
    quarter of the CMS muon system \cite{Muon_tracking}} [324]
   \label{fig:CMS_muon_system} [324]
\end{figure} [324]
[324]
The barrel region DTs cover \abseta values of less than 1.2, that encounter low rates of low transverse [341]
momentum muons~\cite{CMS_TDR1}. The drift tube chambers are arranged in four cylindrical layers, or stations, [355]
among the layers of the magnet's iron return yoke and RPC layers. The stations are slightly staggered to [373]
ensure that even a muon of high transverse momentum will be detected by at least three of the four layers. The [394]
drift tubes contain a mixture of argon (85~\%) and carbon dioxide (15~\%), and a positively charged stretched [411]
wire. As a particle with a charge traverses the volume of gas, atoms in the gas are ionised and the resulting [432]
free electrons travel along electric field lines towards the positive wire. By using the position of the [449]
electron along the wire and the time taken for the wire to detect the electron, two coordinates of the muon [469]
position can be deduced. [473]
In comparison to the DTs and CSCs, the RPCs that complement them provide a better resolution in terms of time [493]
(1\ns) but a worse resolution in terms of position, and so provide additional trigger information. As their [510]
name suggests, they are constructed of plates, one negatively charged (cathode) and one positively charged [525]
(anode) and made of a plastic with high resistance. In a similar process to the other muon detectors, a gas [545]
that makes up the volume in between the plates is ionised by a passing charged muon. The resulting electrons [564]
create an avalanche of electrons by, in turn, ionising other gas atoms; this avalanche of electrons moves [581]
towards the anode and metal readout strips outside the plastic anode detect the signal for readout. The hit [599]
strips pattern allows a calculation of the muon momentum which is then fed to trigger algorithms. [615]
[615]
\subsection{Trigger and Data Acquisition} [4]
\label{ss:Trigger} [4]
At the design bunch crossing frequency of 40~\MHz~ and at the design luminosity of $10^{34}\cm^{-2}\s^{-1}$, [19]
the expected number of proton-proton collisions per second is approximately $10^{9}$, translating to 21 [33]
proton-proton collisions per bunch crossing on average. Each bunch crossing produces approximately 1~MB of [48]
data, leading to 40,000\GB/\s~ of data. This extremely large amount of data, which is impractical to record, [66]
means that a trigger system is required to filter the events in order to record only data that are of interest [87]
for physics analyses. [90]
[90]
There are two levels to the CMS trigger, named Level 1 Trigger (L1) and High Level Trigger (HLT). These work [110]
with the electronics and readout systems in place in the detector to filter the events to a practically [128]
manageable amount for processing. In combination, these triggers reduce the data rate by at least a factor of [146]
$10^{6}$~\cite{CMS_experiment}. [147]
[147]
The L1 Trigger is a pipelined deadtimeless system comprised of calorimeter triggers, muon triggers and a [163]
global trigger that works on a combination of data from the former two. The decisions made by the L1 Trigger [183]
are carried out by custom-designed hardware processors, consisting mostly of programmable electronics such [196]
as Field Programmable Gate Arrays (FPGAs)~\cite{1742-6596-219-3-032009}. The data from a bunch crossing are held in [211]
pipeline buffers in the electronics on the detector (at the front) end whilst the information for the triggers [229]
is processed in the CMS service cavern (USC) and the decisions transmitted back to the front end. The maximum [248]
time allowed for this process for each event is 3.2\us, which is the time taken for the signals to be [268]
transmitted via optical fibres from the detector to the processors, processing time, and transmitted back [283]
again. This time is known as the latency~\cite{CMS_TDR1}. The L1 Trigger outputs events to the HLT at a rate [302]
of 100~\kHz~\cite{CMS_experiment}. [304]
[304]
As mentioned, the trigger uses calorimeter and muon chamber data to reach a decision on an event [321]
within the required timeframe. Tracker data are not currently used since track reconstruction exceeds the [336]
amount of time allowed for the L1 trigger decision. Good trigger performance is related to the quality of the [355]
calorimeters and muon systems. Factors such as good momentum resolution of high momentum muons, good charge [371]
determination of muons, good ECAL energy resolution and good missing transverse energy resolution are required [386]
for the trigger to select interesting events. The trigger was designed as described in order to allow the CMS [405]
experiment to meet the goals of the LHC physics programme~\cite{CMS_experiment}. [415]
[415]
Unlike the Level 1 Trigger, the High Level Trigger (HLT) is software-based and runs offline in HLT processor [433]
farms of about a thousand commerical processors~\cite{CMS_TDR1}. If the Level 1 produces an accept decision, [448]
the data which was stored in buffers in the front end electronics is read into readout buffers from where the [468]
DAQ system accesses it. The L1 output rate of 100~\kHz~ corresponds to a data rate of approximately 100\GB/\s. [486]
The HLT software processes these events in a computer farm that carries out fast processing of offline [503]
algorithms such as selections and object reconstructions to reduce the rate down to approximately 100~\Hz. [518]
These accepted data are then stored on tape. The HLT algorithms are designed based on the principle of [536]
minimising the number of objects that need to be reconstructed in order to come to a decision, and events are [556]
discarded as early as possible, leading to the HLT consisting of many virtual levels that progressively use [573]
more information from, first, the muon chambers and calorimeters, followed by pixel tracker data, and finally [589]
full tracker information~\cite{CMS_TDR1}. [592]
[592]
Figure~\ref{fig:single_muon_trigger_rates} shows the variation in trigger rates with increasing muon [602]
transverse momentum at luminosities of $2\times10^{33}\cm^{-2}\s^{-1}$ and $10^{34}\cm^{-2}\s^{-1}$. The rates [612]
for different trigger levels are shown. The L1 trigger rate begins to flatten out as the \pt threshold [629]
increases because the lack of tracker information at L1 means that low momentum muons mis-measured as having [646]
high momentum are not removed. Thus, increasing the threshold would have no discernible effect on reducing the [663]
trigger rates while reducing physics performance by rejecting desirable events. In comparison, the L3 trigger [678]
rate, which includes tracker information, continues to decrease at high muon momenta, and is able to maintain [695]
the rate at the desired level. [701]
% Tracker data could thus be used for improved muon momentum resolution, in addition to electron matching, for [701]
% the application of more efficient isolation criteria, and for primary vertex identification at the L1 [701]
% stage~\cite{Klein:1628930}. [701]
% Incorporating the tracker information in the L1 trigger at the HL-LHC would therefore be an effective method [701]
% of maintaining the L1 trigger rate at 100kHz at higher luminosities. [701]
[701]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [701]
  \centering [701]
   \includegraphics[width=0.65\textwidth]{Chapters/02_Detector/Images/Muon_trigger_rates.png}\hfill [701]
   \caption[Single muon HLT rates at low and high luminosities.]{Single [702]
    muon high level trigger rates at (a) $\mathcal{L}=2\times10^{33}\cm^{-2}\s^{-1}$ and (b) [712]
    $\mathcal{L}=10^{34}\cm^{-2}\s^{-1}$~\cite{Cittolin:578006}.} [713]
   \label{fig:single_muon_trigger_rates} [713]
\end{figure} [713]
[713]
A more detailed description of the data acquisition (DAQ) system can be found in \cite{CMS_experiment} [727]
and \cite{CMS_TDR1}. [728]
[728]
\section{Upgrades} [1]
\label{s:Upgrades} [1]
The CMS experiment, along with the LHC and the other detectors are in a long term programme of upgrades and [21]
maintenance. By 2023 the luminosity provided by the LHC is expected to be $2\times10^{34}\cm^{-2}\s^{-1}$ [35]
\cite{Technical_Proposal_Upgrade_of_CMS_Detector_through_2020}. The various runs and shutdowns until 2023 are [43]
collectively referred to as Phase 1. In phase 2, or after 2023, long shutdown 3 is also planned to bring [63]
further improvements and upgrades to the performance of the LHC, after which the luminosity of the LHC is [81]
expected to reach $5\times10^{34}\cm^{-2}\s^{-1}$. The machine in this state will be known as the high [96]
luminosity LHC, HL-LHC (also sometimes referred to as Super LHC, SLHC). [107]
[107]
Naturally, the above dates and schedules are the latest best estimates and are liable to change over time, [125]
particularly those further in the future, as work progresses.

File: Chapters/02_Detector/02b_ComputingandOffline.tex

\chapter{CMS Computing and Offline} [4]
\label{c:CMS_computing_and_offline} [4]
[4]
\section{CMS Computing} [2]
\label{s:CMS_computing} [2]
[2]
The CMS offline computing infrastructure takes on the workload of transferring accepted data from the triggers [18]
to both permanent and temporary storage, of processing this data for subsequent analysis, in addition to the [35]
production of simulated CMS data. The resources needed to process the high volumes of data involved require a [53]
distributed computing system. The Worldwide LHC Computing Grid (WLCG) infrastructure, an international [65]
collaboration of LHC experiments and computing centres, is employed to carry out these tasks. [79]
[79]
CMS computing resources are primarily divided into three tiers. Tier 0 (T0) consists of only one site, at CERN [98]
itself. The T0 centre has as its main aim to take accepted data from the detector and transfer it to permanent [119]
storage on tape. Tier 0 computing is also responsible for reconstructing the initial RAW data into smaller [136]
formats, by passing events through modules to produce physics objects (like electrons and jets) using [151]
algorithms to reconstruct tracks in the silicon tracker, clusters of deposits in the calorimeters, primary and [167]
secondary vertices, determine particle identification and to correct for detector characteristics such as [180]
non-functioning components (see Section~\ref{s:Event_Data_Model} onwards for more details on data formats). [191]
From the T0 centre, copies of the data in RECO and RAW format are transferred to T1 centres around the world. [212]
Owing to its crucial role in ensuring the reliable transfer of RAW and RECO data, T0 resources are not [231]
available for analysis by CMS users. There are seven Tier 1 centres located in various countries within the [249]
CMS collaboration. The UK T1 centre is located at the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory in Harwell, near Oxford. [266]
T1 centres provide reliable computing resources for data storage and processing. RAW data is spread between [282]
them, providing a second copy of the RAW data stored at CERN. The second reconstruction step, termed RERECO, [300]
is also carried out at T1 centres, in addition to the production of simulated data. These can then be provided [320]
to any of the Tier 2 centres at CMS institutes (typically universities) where they may be temporarily stored. [338]
T2 centres are also generally used to run users' final analyses and produce simulations [352]
\cite{CMS_experiment,CMS_TDR1}. [352]
[352]
\section{Event Data Model} [3]
\label{s:Event_Data_Model} [3]
Reconstructed data from CMS uses a data model based around an event, called the Event Data Model (EDM), where [22]
one event is one crossing of proton bunches at the centre of CMS that passes the triggers. This model [41]
is created and manipulated within a CMS software framework (CMSSW)~\cite{cmssw} written in C++, with the event [57]
and related objects in the object-oriented data analysis framework ROOT~\cite{ROOT}. [67]
[67]
The iterations of data from the initial recorded information to subsequent, more compact formats, are produced [83]
by passing events through a sequence of modules. The arrangement of these data takes the form of several [101]
layers, with the first of these being RAW. This level contains the full information from the event in CMS and [121]
occupies approximately 1.5-2~MB/event. More information than is necessary for user analyses is included at [137]
this level, and so the majority of CMS users will not use this data format. Reconstructed level data (RECO) is [157]
slightly smaller in size (approximately 0.5~MB/event) and is essentially a compressed subset of the RAW data [175]
after modules performing reconstruction have been run. [182]
[182]
The third level, Analysis Object Data (AOD), is the smallest of the data formats, requiring approximately [198]
100~kB/event, which is small enough to allow the entire AOD data to be stored at computing centres worldwide. [218]
AOD format is a subset of the RECO data, and is produced by further reducing RECO, leaving only high level [238]
physics objects (e.g. electrons, jets) which is adequate for most physics analyses. [250]
[250]
In the differential cross section analysis presented in this thesis, this AOD data is processed using the [267]
Bristol Top Group's NTupleProduction code~\cite{NTT_LukeKreczko_SergeySenkin_JesonJacob_EmyrClement_2015} to [273]
produce private ntuples which are yet again smaller in size, at approximately 3~kB/event. These ntuples are [291]
then converted to simple ROOT histogram files after applying the required selection criteria and corrections [306]
in the BristolAnalysisTools~\cite{BAT_LukeKreczko_JesonJacob_SergeySenkin_EmyrClement_2015}. Scripts written [311]
in Python in DailyPythonScripts~\cite{DPS_LukeKreczko_SergeySenkin_JesonJacob_EmyrClement_2015} are then used [318]
to produce final results plots and tables. [325]
[325]
[325]
\section{Object Reconstruction and Identification} [4]
\label{s:object_reconstruction_and_identification} [4]
[4]
The process of producing a physics object such as an electron, photon or jet, from the data recorded by CMS is [25]
known as reconstruction and is carried out by modules qknown as EDProducers within CMSSW. The three-step [41]
process of reconstructing high level objects consists of local reconstruction within a sub detector, global [56]
reconstruction using data from the whole CMS detector, and a final stage combining reconstructed objects from [72]
the first two stages. The reconstruction technique used in the majority of CMS analyses is called Particle [89]
Flow (PF) \cite{particle_flow}. PF uses information from all of the sub-detectors of CMS to identify and reconstruct [105]
particles produced from a proton-proton collision. [111]
[111]
\subsection{Track Reconstruction} [2]
\label{ss:track_reconstruction} [2]
Algorithms performing local track reconstruction execute a scan to identify tracker modules that receive a [17]
higher than threshold signal. Clusters are then constructed by adding adjacent strips or pixels to the [33]
originally identified seed strip or pixel. In order to reconstruct complete tracks to obtain the position and [50]
momentum of the charged particle, algorithms based on specific requirements such as high or low transverse [66]
momentum tracks are used. These algorithms in CMS are collectively known as the Combinatorial Track Finder [82]
(CTF). [83]
[83]
Multiple passes of the CTF reconstruction software are carried out to reconstruct tracks, in a process called [100]
iterative tracking. The earliest iterations identify tracks that are easy to find such as high \pt tracks [116]
originating near the interaction point. As these tracks are reconstructed, the corresponding hits are removed [131]
from consideration in subsequent iterations, making it simpler for later iterations to identify tracks that [146]
are more difficult to find such as those of displaced particles or with low \pt. [160]
[160]
Six iterations are carried out in total, and each iteration can be split into four steps. Seeds are created [179]
using 2 or 3 hits to produce intial track candidates. The seed gives an estimate of the trajectories of the [199]
potential track candidates. A Kalman Filter \cite{kalman_filter, Speer:927395} based track finding algorithm [209]
then looks for further hits along an extrapolated path of the seed trajectory. A track fitter is then run [228]
using information from the previous steps to produce final values for trajectory parameters. The fourth and [244]
final step then rejects tracks which fail specified quality checks \cite{track_reconstruction}. [254]
[254]
\subsection{Pileup Subtraction} [2]
\label{ss:pileup_subtraction} [2]
When reconstructing an event in CMS, all vertices (points from which multiple tracks originate) in the event [19]
must be reconstructed. By ordering the vertices by the sum of the transverse momenta of their tracks, it is [38]
possible to identify the the vertex of interest for physics analyses, known as the primary vertex (PV), as the [57]
vertex with the largest transverse momentum. The particle flow algorithm reconstructs objects, starting with [71]
those coming from the primary vertex, followed by other vertices (known as pileup). The reconstructed objects [87]
from the PV can be affected by the number of other vertices present in the event. For example, the jet [107]
momentum and lepton isolation could both increase with high pileup. This can, in turn, lead to signal events [125]
not passing selection requirements because a truly isolated lepton from the PV may appear not to be isolated. [143]
In addition, a larger number of events from background processes may pass selection requirements due to low [160]
energy jets appearing to have a higher energy. Hence, pileup subtraction, the removal of charged particles [176]
coming from vertices other than the PV is implemented to reduce these effects. [189]
[189]
Neutral particles, however, pose a more difficult problem since they leave no tracker information for the [205]
reconstruction algorithms to easily identify their origin. One method of removing such particles from an [220]
event, known as the $\Delta\beta$ correction, uses the fact that the estimated average energy in an event from [238]
neutral particles is half that from charged particles. Thus, it can be estimated that 0.5 times the charged [256]
particle energy comes from neutral particles. The second method, known as $\rho$ correction, subtracts an [271]
average transverse momentum coming from pileup per unit area. While the two methods produce similar results, [287]
the $\rho$ correction is used to correct the electron isolation and the $\Delta\beta$ correction is used to [304]
correct the muon isolation in the differential cross sections analysis presented in this thesis, as [319]
recommended by the CMS TOP physics analysis group. [327]
[327]
\subsection{Electron Reconstruction} [2]
\label{ss:electron_reconstruction} [2]
ECAL local reconstruction algorithms calculate the time of arrival, position and the energy of deposits. After [18]
grouping together deposits in neighbouring crystals to form clusters, deposits are then matched to deposits in [34]
the HCAL, forming a Calo Tower. Electrons are, typically, completely stopped in the ECAL and deposit their [51]
energy in a narrow cluster of crystals. [58]
[58]
However, electrons can interact with the material between the interaction point and the ECAL, emitting a [74]
photon via bremsstrahlung radation. Similarly, photons can convert to an elecron-positron pair ($e^{+}e^{-}$). [87]
Both of these processes result in ECAL deposits with a larger spread in $\phi$ because of the strong magnetic [106]
field in the inner section of CMS containing the tracker. In the case of photons, several clusters are grouped [125]
together to form superclusters, which are then corrected for their energies to obtain the energies of the [142]
original photon \cite{photon_reconstruction}. [144]
[144]
Electron reconstruction in the ECAL is carried out by two methods. The first matches superclusters with a [161]
trajectory compatible with two or three pixel detector hits and the interaction point. The second matches the [178]
supercluster to tracker tracks to identify electrons (and in the case of electrons emitting bremsstrahlung [193]
radiation, tracks with a low number of hits) \cite{electron_reconstruction}. Combining the seeds from the two [207]
methods, a Gaussian-Sum Filter, a generalisation of the Kalman Filter algorithm, is used to reconstruct [222]
electron paths \cite{electrons_GSF}. [224]
[224]
Since other objects can leave similar signatures in the detector to electrons, such as jets or electrons from [242]
photon conversions, candidates are required to satisfy additional requirements of identification and [254]
isolation. Several electron identification methods exist and are used in CMS analyses. The top cross sections [270]
analysis in this thesis uses the multivariate identification (MVA ID). As the name suggests, this approach [286]
uses a multivariate analysis, with track, track quality, and supercluster variables as input, to produce a [302]
discriminator value, with higher values indicating a higher likelihood for a candidate to be a real electron. [319]
The MVA ID algorithm is optimised for identifying electrons from W and Z boson decays, and separately for [337]
triggering and non-triggering electrons~\cite{electron_reconstruction}. [341]
[341]
The isolation of an electron is defined as the activity within a cone surrounding the electron. Isolation is [359]
used as an additional criterion to select electrons, in particular to distinguish electrons promptly produced [374]
in a proton-proton collision. Such isolated electrons would have less activity in its vicinity than electrons [390]
from within a jet, which could originate from leptonically decaying b hadrons, and jets faking electrons. Two [407]
methods exist in CMS of calculating the isolation of a particle: detector based isolation and particle based [424]
isolation. The detector based method is defined in each sub detector as the sum of the momenta or energies in [444]
a cone of $\Delta R = 0.3$ around the electron. The particle based method uses the total transverse energy of [461]
PF reconstructed particles within a cone of $\Delta R = 0.3$ and can remove activity coming from collisions [476]
other than the hard proton-proton interaction of interest. By normalising this isolation to the momentum or [492]
energy of the electron, a relative isolation is obtained, relating the cone activity to the electron. [508]
Termed PFRelIso, it is this relative isolation that is used in the cross section analysis to select [525]
electrons. [526]
% can improve signal efficiency [526]
[526]
In order to avoid the selection of electrons originating from a photon conversion, a veto can be placed on a [546]
second electron in the event. However, since the two electrons in a photon conversion may not necessarily have [564]
equal transverse momentum, \ie one may have a very low \pt, such a veto may be insufficient, and so further [582]
techniques to identify conversion events are used. Firstly, since an electron from a conversion would be [598]
produced at some distance from the interaction point and in the detector material, eliminating candidates with [614]
missings hits in the pixel tracker helps to distinguish such electrons from promptly produced electrons. In [630]
events in which the conversion occurs in the beam pipe or if the electron is matched to unassociated pixel [649]
hits, this method can also be insufficient, so an additional track matching step is used. Tracks are matched [667]
in pairs and following geometrical cuts, can be removed if they appear to originate from a conversion [684]
\cite{electron_reconstruction}. [684]
[684]
\subsection{Muon Reconstruction} [2]
\label{ss:muon_reconstruction} [2]
Local reconstruction in the muon chambers provides hit position and time of arrival of a muon. This [19]
information from the DTs and CSCs is then amalgamated to create muon track hits and segments, which are then [38]
used by the muon global reconstruction algorithms to reconstruct ``standalone'' muons. An inner detector [52]
segment is used as a seed for a Kalman Filter~\cite{kalman_filter, Speer:927395} and possible trajectories are [66]
generated. By removing hits which are unlikely to have come from the track in question, the likely trajectory [84]
is constructed layer-by-layer. A final fit is carried out, including an extrapolation to the interaction point [100]
for greater momentum resolution. [104]
[104]
Muons are also independently reconstructed in the tracker. These tracker tracks can therefore be combined with [120]
the aforementioned muon chamber information, where the magnetic field is only 2~\tesla, to improve the \pt [135]
resolution of muons, as seen in Figure~\ref{fig:muon_momentum_resolution}. [142]
[142]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [142]
  \centering [142]
   \includegraphics[width=0.65\textwidth]{Chapters/02_Detector/Images/muon_momentum_resolution.png}\hfill [142]
   \caption[Muon transverse momentum resolution using muon system and the tracking system.]{Muon transverse [144]
    momentum resolution as a function of muon transverse momentum using the muon system only, using inner tracking only, [162]
    and using both~\cite{Chatrchyan:2012xdj}.} [165]
   \label{fig:muon_momentum_resolution} [165]
\end{figure} [165]
[165]
Two methods are employed to combine the information from the two sub-detectors. \textit{Global muon [179]
reconstruction} matches a tracker track to a standalone muon track and carries out a fit of the resulting [197]
\textit{global muon} track. The second method, \textit{tracker muon reconstruction}, extrapolates tracker [208]
tracks outwards to the muon chambers and accepts a muon candidate if a DT or CSC matching track is found and [229]
the muon \pt is greater than 0.5\GeV~\cite{muon_reconstruction}. [235]
[235]
For triggering, the \pt of a muon is first estimated using the information available at Level 1 from all three [254]
types of muon detectors. At HLT level, the muon candidates from Level 1 are further refined using track [272]
finding and fitting, but still using only information from muon chambers, leading to Level 2 muons. As [289]
mentioned in Section~\ref{ss:Trigger}, due to the time constraints required of the L1 trigger, full tracker [304]
data are not currently used. However, tracks of Level 2 muons are extrapolated into the tracker systems and a [323]
localised track finding algorithm is run to identify only nearby tracker hits. A track matching that of a [341]
Level 2 muon leads to a Level 3 muon. %See Emyr's thesis P45 top for details. [350]
[350]
\subsection{Jet Reconstruction} [2]
\label{ss:jet_reconstruction} [2]
As quarks produced in proton-proton interactions (except the top quark) hadronise~\cite{Griffiths:1987tj}, [13]
jets of particles are formed in the direction of travel of the quark. The time of arrival, position and the [33]
energy deposited by hadronic objects are locally reconstructed in the HCAL. If the deposit matches an ECAL [50]
deposit, a Calo Tower is formed for later use in jet reconstruction algorithms. [63]
[63]
The PF algorithm performs the reconstruction of particles in the jet, and the \antikt algorithm is used to [80]
perform the clustering of these particles into jets. The \antikt algorithm, explained in detail [93]
in~\cite{Cacciari:2008gp}, is one of several jet algorithms that exist in CMS to combine reconstructed [107]
particles into jets. It defines a distance $d_{ij}$ between reconstructed particles as [119]
\begin{equation} [120]
%\begin{center} [120]
d_{ij} = [120]
min\left(\frac{1}{p_{T,i}^{2}},\frac{1}{p_{T,j}^{2}}\right)\frac{(\eta_{i}-\eta_{j})+(\phi_{i}-\phi_{j})^{2}}{R^{2}}. [120]
%\end{center} [120]
\end{equation} [120]
$p_{T,i}$ and $p_{T,j}$ are the transverse momenta of the two particles $i$ and $j$, $\eta_{i}$ and $\eta_{j}$ [137]
are the rapidities, $\phi_{i}$ and $\phi_{j}$ are the azimuth angles and $R$ is the radius of the jet cone. [156]
The \antikt algorithm iteratively clusters together particles with the smallest $d_{i,j}$ between them until [169]
all jets are reconstructed and there are no particles remaining. Events will usually consist of a small number of [188]
high-\pt (hard) particles and a large number of low-\pt (soft) particles. The distance between hard particles [204]
is typically small, and the distance between softer particles is larger. Soft particles tend to [219]
cluster around hard particles first, before clustering with other soft particles. [230]
[230]
While the PF anti-$k_{t}$ jets show high jet matching efficiency on Monte Carlo simulation samples, [246]
corrections are applied based on the jet $\pt$ and $\eta$ to correct for mismeasurements in the [262]
detector and thereby improve the agreement between generated and reconstructed particle flow jets. The [276]
factored approach to CMS jet energy corrections is comprised of three parts: [288]
\begin{enumerate} [288]
  \item {L1 Pile Up: corrects for additional energy from charged particles from pile-up in the event [303]
  \ref{ss:pileup_subtraction}.} [303]
  \item {L2 Relative Jet Correction: corrects the reconstructed energy to match the generated jet with respect [318]
  to $\eta$.} %to flatten the jet response in the ecal eta [320]
  \item {L3 Absolute Jet Correction: corrects the reconstructed energy to match the generated jet with respect [335]
  to $\pt$.} %to flatten the jet response in the ecal pt [337]
  \item {L2L3Residuals: reduces any residual differences between the reconstructed and generated [347]
  jet due to simulation not being perfectly tuned to data. This correction is applied to data only.} [364]
  %https://twiki.cern.ch/twiki/bin/viewauth/CMS/IntroToJEC [364]
\end{enumerate} [364]
In order to identify jets in the differential cross sections analysis, further identification criteria are [379]
used to reduce electronic noise, to reduce the number of electrons mis-identified as jets and, in so doing, to [398]
ensure the selection of high quality jets. The requirements, which are known as the loose PF Jet ID, are: [417]
[417]
\begin{itemize} [417]
  \item at least one constituent particle [422]
  \item the neutral hadron energy fraction (NHF) must be $<0.99$ [431]
  \item for jets with \abseta$<2.4$, the charged hadron energy fraction (CHF) must be $>0$ [444]
  \item the neutral electronmagnetic energy fraction (NEF) must be $<0.99$ [453]
  \item for jets with \abseta$<2.4$, the charged electronmagnetic energy faction (CEF) must be $<0.99$ [466]
  \item for jets with \abseta$<2.4$, the number of charged hadronic constituents (NCH) must be $>0$ [480]
\end{itemize} [480]
[480]
\subsubsection{B Jets} [482]
\label{sss:b_jets} [482]
The process of identifying jets coming from \bquarks is known as \btagging and is very important in top quark [499]
physics due to the decay of the top to a \W boson and a \bquark. Effective \btagging can therefore help to [517]
appreciably reduce background processes in an analysis. A description of \btagging, the several algorithms [530]
available in CMS, relevant event variables, and a performance comparison, is given in [543]
Chapter~\ref{c:b_tagging_study}. [544]

  • Included file: Chapters/02_Detector/02b_ComputingandOffline.tex

  • 321+2+0 (1/0/4/0) Subsection: Pileup Subtraction
