File: Chapters/03_Theory/03a_TheStandardModel.tex

\chapter{The Standard Model of Particle Physics} [6]
\label{c:the_standard_model} [6]
[6]
\section{Introduction} [1]
\label{s:standard_model_intro} [1]
[1]
The Standard Model (SM) is the name given to the theory developed during the course of the \nth{20} century [20]
that describes the elementary particles that make up all known, observable matter and the three fundamental [36]
forces by which they interact (electromagnetic, weak and strong). The SM does not, however, describe the [52]
gravitational force as it is not known how to model it mathematically at a quantum scale. The SM puts forward [72]
twelve fermions, with a spin quantum number of 1/2, as the matter particles. These are split into two groups [92]
of six quarks and six leptons, all of which are split into three generations. The six quarks are classified [111]
according to their charge and flavour: up, down, charm, strange, top and beauty quarks. The leptons are in [129]
turn classified similarly: electron, muon or tau leptons, together with their corresponding neutrinos. [142]
Neutrinos, although originally thought to be massless, are now believed to carry mass due to the observation [159]
of the oscillation of neutrinos between different flavours. Table~\ref{tab:standard_model} shows these [170]
particles of the Standard Model in their respective generations. All of these particles have a respective [186]
antiparticle which has identical quantum numbers except opposite electric charge. [196]
[196]
\input{Chapters/03_Theory/tables/standard_model} [196]
[196]
All known, observable matter in the universe is composed of the aforementioned twelve fermions or their [212]
antiparticles. All stable matter is composed of protons, neutrons and electrons. All other particles are [227]
unstable and decay; they are produced only in particle colliders such as the LHC, or in cosmic radiation. [245]
Quarks also carry the charge of the strong force, termed `colour', of red, green or blue. The only quark which [265]
does not form bound colourless states (hadronise) is the top quark which has a very short lifetime [282]
of~$\approx5\times10^{-25}\s$~\cite{Agashe:2014kda} due to its large mass, and therefore decays before it can [295]
hadronise. [296]
[296]
These fermions interact via the integer spin (spin 1) gauge bosons of the three fundamental forces. Electron, [313]
muon and tau leptons interact via the electromagnetic and weak forces; their neutrinos, since they carry no [330]
electric charge, interact only via the weak force; and the quarks interact via the electromagnetic, weak and [347]
strong forces. Each of the forces are mediated by gauge bosons that are the `force carriers'. The mediator of [366]
the strong force is known as the gluon, that of the electromagnetic force is the photon and those of the weak [387]
force are the $\W^{+}$, $\W^{-}$ and $\Z$ bosons. Table~\ref{tab:standard_model} shows the gauge bosons and [401]
their properties. [403]
[403]
% The range of action of the boson determines the interaction range of the force it carries. Heavier bosons, [403]
% like the $\W^{+}$, $\W^{-}$ and $\Z$ bosons, have a short range of action, while massless bosons such as [403]
% photons and gluons have a theoretically infinite range. In reality, this is not the case because the gluons [403]
% themselves carry the strong colour charge and so interact with each other, reducing their interaction range. [403]
The strength of the fundamental forces is quantified by their coupling strength, denoted $\alpha$. Taking the [419]
strength of the strong force as the baseline, the relative strength of the electromagnetic force is $10^{-2}$, [436]
that of the weak force is $10^{-5}$ and the strength of the gravitational force is [451]
$10^{-39}$~\cite{Rolnick_Fundamental_Particles}. The electromagnetic coupling strength, also known as the [460]
fine-structure constant, is defined as $\alpha_{em}=\frac{e^{2}}{4\pi}$, which at low energies is [471]
$\approx\frac{1}{137}$. Although the strong force is the strongest force, it has a limited range of only [487]
\textasciitilde$~10^{-15}\m$, and the weak force has an estimated range of \textasciitilde$10^{-18}\m$, while [499]
the electromagnetic and gravitational forces have infinite range. [507]
[507]
The Higgs boson, the discovery of which was announced in July 2012 by the CMS and ATLAS experiments at the [527]
LHC, is the latest component of the Standard Model to be discovered~\cite{Chatrchyan:2012xdj, Aad:2012tfa}. [539]
The mechanism of electroweak symmetry breaking through which other particles acquire mass is due to the Higgs [556]
field, and is described in Section~\ref{ss:spontaneous_symmetry_breaking}. [562]
[562]
\subsection{Gauge Principle} [2]
\label{ss:gauge_principle} [2]
The underlying mathematical model of the Standard Model is a Quantum Field Theory (QFT) combining special [18]
relativity and quantum mechanics. All interactions in the SM must conserve the kinematic quantities energy and [34]
momentum, in addition to electric charge. The electromagnetic and strong forces also conserve the dynamic [49]
quantities colour, baryon number, lepton number and quark flavour. The weak force, if mediated by a charged [66]
propagator ($\W^{\pm}$), can allow the violation of quark flavour, meaning a quark can decay into another [82]
flavour quark. [84]
[84]
The laws of conservation occur as a result of underlying symmetries in the theories. For instance, energy [101]
conservation stems from time symmetry and angular momentum conservation is a result of rotational symmetry. [116]
In addition to these classical symmetries, a quantum field theory can also possess gauge symmetries. The [132]
principle of gauge invariance refers to field theories in which the Lagrangian, which summarises the dynamics [148]
of the system, is invariant under local transformations (transformations that are a function of a field, and [165]
therefore different at all space-time points within the field). %The collection of all such transformations, [174]
% called gauge transformations, are called the Lie group. [174]
If the collection of all such gauge transformations, is commutative, \ie any order of application of the [190]
symmetry transformations produces the same result, the theory is termed Abelian. Conversely, if the group is [206]
non-commutative, the theory is non-Abelian. Each group of transformations has an associated generator, and [220]
each generator has a corresponding vector field, or gauge field, whose purpose is ensuring invariance under [236]
local transformations. The quanta of these fields are the gauge bosons of the Standard Model. Note that the [254]
converse of local transformations are global transformations, in which the transformation takes place [267]
instantaneously at all space-time points. [272]
% However, the speed of any tranformation is limited to c, the speed of light, and so a more realistic local [272]
% transformation is interesting to consider. [272]
[272]
Group transformations can be represented as groups of $n \times n$ matrices which possess properties such as [287]
unitarity ($U$) and orthogonality ($O$). A group of matrices with determinant 1 is called `special' ($S$), [303]
leading to further groups $SU(N)$ and $SO(N)$. The Standard Model is comprised of electroweak theory [318]
(combining electromagnetism and weak theory), with a gauge symmetry of $SU(2) \times U(1)$, and the theory of [333]
strong interactions, described by the gauge group $SU(3)$. [341]
% The Standard Model is therefore a gauge theory based on the gauge group $SU(3) \times SU(2) \times U(1)$. [341]
[341]
\subsection{Quantum Electrodynamics} [2]
\label{ss:quantum_electrodynamics} [2]
[2]
Quantum electrodynamics (QED) is a component theory of the Standard Model that governs the interactions of [18]
electrically charged particles. The simplest electromagnetic process is shown in [28]
Figure~\ref{fig:qed_processes}a, and all real processes are made of some number of these processes combined [43]
together, such as electron-positron annihilation shown in Figure~\ref{fig:qed_processes}b. [52]
[52]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [52]
  \centering [52]
   \includegraphics[width=0.3\textwidth]{Chapters/03_Theory/Images/e_e_gamma}\hfill [52]
   \includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{Chapters/03_Theory/Images/e_e_gamma_e_e} [52]
    \caption[Elementary electromagnetic processes.]{(a) the elementary electromagnetic process of an electron [60]
    emitting a photon and (b) electron-positron annihilation.} [67]
   \label{fig:qed_processes} [67]
\end{figure} [67]
[67]
Any such real process is represented by the sum of all possible orders of Feynmann diagrams for the [85]
interaction. In practice, since each vertex contributes a factor of $\alpha$ at low energies, higher-order [100]
Feynmann diagrams with more than a few vertices contribute negligibly to the process and are often ignored. [117]
[117]
The coupling strength of a force can be further explained in terms of vacuum polarisation. Regarding the [134]
electromagnetic force, this refers to the phenomenon of electron-positron pairs and photons being [147]
spontaneously created and absorbed by an electron. These virtual particles, which would be represented in [162]
Feynmann diagrams as closed loops, shield the original electron leading to the electron charge being measured [178]
at a lower value than its true charge. This measured value is called the effective, or 'screened', charge. As [197]
a result, the coupling strength of the electromagnetic force is said to be a `running' coupling [213]
constant, due to the fact that it decreases as a function of distance. [226]
[226]
The mathematical formulation of QED stems from the Dirac equation, which describes the Lagrangian for a [242]
spin-half (Fermionic) field $\psi$~\cite{Dirac610}: [246]
[246]
\begin{equation} [247]
\calL = i (\hbar c) \bar{\psi} \gamma^{\mu} \partial_{\mu} \psi - (mc^{2}) \bar{\psi} \psi \end{equation} [247]
[247]
Here, $\hbar$ is the reduced Planck's constant, $\mu$ are the Lorentz indices and $\gamma^{\mu}$ are the gamma [264]
(or Dirac) matrices. Under a global transformation of the field by a phase $i \alpha$, [278]
%\begin{equation} [278]
%\psi(x) \rightarrow \psi'(x) = e^{i\alpha}\psi(x), \bar{\psi} \rightarrow \bar{\psi}'(x) = [278]
%e^{-i\alpha}\bar{\psi}(x) [278]
%\end{equation} [278]
% [278]
this Lagrangian is invariant (\ie under a global transformation of the $U(1)$ group, since this is [293]
equivalent to multiplication of the field $\psi$ by a $1 \times 1$ unitary matrix). However, under a local [309]
gauge transformation by a phase of $i\alpha(x)$, the symmetry %is no longer true since the partial derivative [318]
no longer holds [321]
%\begin{equation} [321]
%\partial_{\mu}(e^{i\alpha(x)}\psi) = i(\partial_{\mu}\alpha(x))e^{i\alpha(x)}\psi + [321]
%e^{i\alpha(x)}\partial_{\mu}\psi , [321]
%\end{equation} [321]
% [321]
meaning the Lagrangian is not invariant: [327]
\begin{equation} [328]
\calL \rightarrow \calL - \bar{\psi}(x)\gamma^{\mu}\psi(x)[\partial_{\mu}\alpha(x)]. [328]
\end{equation} [328]
[328]
Local symmetry can be maintained in this case if a new gauge field, $A_\mu$, is introduced to the Lagrangian [347]
by means of a covariant derivative $D_\mu$. %: [354]
%\begin{equation} [354]
%D_{\mu} = \partial_{\mu} + ieA_{\mu}. [354]
%\end{equation} [354]
% [354]
%Under the local transformation, $A_{\mu}$ tranforms as [354]
% [354]
%\begin{equation} [354]
%A_{\mu} \rightarrow A_{\mu}' = A_{\mu} - \frac{1}{e}\partial_{\mu}\alpha(x). [354]
%\end{equation} [354]
% [354]
If the partial derivatives in the Dirac equation are now replaced with the covariant derivatives, the [370]
invariant Lagrangian is obtained: [374]
\begin{equation} [375]
\calL = i (\hbar c) \bar{\psi} \gamma^{\mu} \partial_{\mu} \psi - e \bar{\psi} \gamma^{\mu} \psi A_{\mu} - [375]
(mc^{2}) \bar{\psi} \psi - \frac{1}{4}F^{\mu\nu}F_{\mu\nu}. [375]
\end{equation} [375]
[375]
In this way, the principle of local gauge invariance under the $U(1)$ group is used to introduce additional [393]
fields to a Lagrangian in order to make it invariant under local transformations. This final Lagrangian is [410]
that of quantum electrodynamics. The physical interpretation of the gauge field $A_{\mu}$ is the photon, which [426]
couples to charged particles (electrons and positrons) with a coupling strength proportional to the charge. [441]
The term $\frac{1}{4}F^{\mu\nu}F_{\mu\nu}$ is an additional term to account for the kinetic energy of the free [457]
particle of the new gauge field, \ie the photon; and there is no term denoting the photon mass. [474]
[474]
% \begin{equation} [474]
% F_{\mu\nu} = \partial_{\mu}A_{\nu} - \partial_{\nu}A_{\mu}. [474]
% \end{equation} [474]
[474]
\subsection{Electroweak Theory} [2]
\label{ss:electroweak_theory} [2]
[2]
The unification of the electromagnetic and weak forces in the 1960s provided a more complete theory of [19]
fundamental particles. This unification takes the form of an $SU(2) \times U(1)$ gauge group combining the [33]
electromagnetic and weak forces, and can be constructed in a similar way to the QED formalism in [50]
Section~\ref{ss:quantum_chromodynamics}. [51]
[51]
First, it is necessary to define isospin, $I$, an abstract fundamental property of fundamental particles that [67]
is conserved in all interactions. Similarly, weak hypercharge, $Y$, is also a quantum property, defined as [83]
$Y_{W} = 2(Q-I_{3})$, where $Q$ represents the charge of the particle and $I_{3}$ is the third component of [99]
isospin. $I_{3}$ takes a value of $1/2$ for left-handed fermions. [109]
[109]
It has been shown empirically that the weak interaction exhibits violation of parity ($P$) and interacts only [126]
with left-handed particles via the charged gauge bosons ($\W^{\pm}$). Hence, the fields representing fermions [140]
are split into left handed and right handed components by defining a left handed doublet containing the left [158]
handed electron and left handed neutrino, and a right handed singlet containing the right handed electron.%: [174]
% \begin{equation} [174]
% \chi_{L} = \left( \begin{array}{c} \nu_{e} \\ e \end{array}\right)_{L}, e_{R} [174]
% \end{equation} [174]
% Here, the left handed doublet has $I=\frac{1}{2}$, and the right handed lepton has $I = 0$. Similar doublets [174]
% can be constructed for the other generations of leptons ($\mu$ and $\tau$) and quarks in their pairs of three [174]
% generations ($\cPqu\cPqd$, $\cPqc\cPqs$ and $\cPqt\cPqb$). Right handed neutrinos, which would have $I=0$ and [174]
% $Y=0$, do not exist in the Standard Model. %as they would not interact with any of the force mediators. [174]
[174]
Four additional massless fields and their associated currents are introduced in order to impose [188]
gauge-invariance: $\W_{\mu}^{1}$, $\W_{\mu}^{2}$, $\W_{\mu}^{3}$ and $B_{\mu}$. The $\W_{\mu}$ fields are [198]
introduced for gauge invariance of the $SU(2)$ group, and interact with the third isospin component $I_{3}$. [214]
The $B_{\mu}$ field similarly transforms by the unitary group $U(1)$, and interacts with the weak hypercharge [230]
$Y$. These additional fields lead to the construction of three weak isospin currents and a weak hypercharge [247]
current. [248]
[248]
Requiring local gauge invariance under an $SU(2) \times U(1)$ group, the covariant derivative is [260]
\begin{equation} [261]
D_{\mu} = \partial_{\mu} + \frac{i}{2} g_{\W} \vec{\tau} \cdot \vec{\W}_{\mu} + ig' \frac{Y}{2}B_{\mu}. [261]
\end{equation} [261]
[261]
The vectors $\W_{\mu}^{1}$, $\W_{\mu}^{2}$, $\W_{\mu}^{3}$ have coupling strengths of $g_{\W}$ to the three [274]
isospin currents and $B_{\mu}$ couples to the hypercharge current with a strength of $g'$. These four bosons [291]
relate to the quanta of the new fields. A linear superposition of the $\W_{\mu}^{1}$ and $\W_{\mu}^{2}$ states [308]
gives the $\W^{\pm}$ bosons, while the neutral states $\W_{\mu}^{3}$ and $B_{\mu}$ undergo a mixing related by [324]
the weak mixing angle, $\theta_{\W}$, to give the neutral $\Z^{0}$ and $\gamma$ bosons. (The weak mixing angle [341]
relates the coupling constants of the electromagnetic and weak forces by $\tan \theta_{W} = [353]
\frac{g'}{g_{W}}$). [353]
[353]
It has been experimentally observed that both the \W bosons and the \Z boson have mass. Indeed, the strength [370]
of the electromagnetic force is of the same order as the weak force, but as a result of the weak gauge bosons [392]
having mass, the weak force appears weaker and has a shorter range. However, the local gauge invariance would [410]
be broken if terms to give the bosons mass were to be included. The theory of spontaneous breaking of the [430]
symmetry underlying the $SU(2) \times U(1)$ group addresses this problem, as explained in [441]
Section~\ref{ss:spontaneous_symmetry_breaking}. [442]
[442]
The weak force has been shown to change the flavour of quarks in an interaction, meaning flavour conservation [460]
is broken. %As stated, [462]
The quarks, like leptons, come in the form of left handed doublets within each generation, [477]
\begin{equation} [478]
\left(\begin{array}{c} u_{L} \\ d'_{L} \end{array}\right) , \left(\begin{array}{c} c_{L} \\ [478]
s'_{L} \end{array}\right) , \left(\begin{array}{c} t_{L} \\ b'_{L} \end{array}\right) [478]
\end{equation} [478]
with isospin $\frac{1}{2}$. Note that the lower quarks of the doublets are denoted with primes as they [495]
indicate a rotated state of the quark, called Cabibbo-rotated states, which are superpositions of the physical quarks. [512]
This means that in, for example, the decay of a down quark to an up quark via emittance of a $\W^{-}$, the [534]
down quark to which the $\W^{-}$ couples is actually a superposition of `down type' quarks, \ie down, charm [551]
and beauty quarks. The Cabbibo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) matrix, relates the weak interaction mixed states to [565]
the physical quark states. This is the degree of quark mixing between the different generations, and results in [583]
the measured values (see equation~\ref{CKM_matrix}) of $\abs{V_{12}}$ for the probability of a transition from [597]
quark 1 to quark 2 in a weak interaction~\cite{Agashe:2014kda}. In reference to top physics, the \abs{V_{tb}} value of almost 1 [618]
means that the top quark almost always decays to a \W boson and a \bquark. [631]
[631]
\begin{equation} [632]
\begin{pmatrix} [632]
V_{\cPqu\cPqd} & V_{\cPqu\cPqs} & V_{\cPqu\cPqb} \\ [632]
V_{\cPqc\cPqd} & V_{\cPqc\cPqs} & V_{\cPqc\cPqs} \\ [632]
V_{\cPqt\cPqd} & V_{\cPqt\cPqs} & V_{\cPqt\cPqb} [632]
\end{pmatrix} [632]
= [632]
\begin{pmatrix} [632]
0.974 & 0.225 & 0.004 \\ [632]
0.225 & 0.973 & 0.041 \\ [632]
0.009 & 0.041 & 0.999 [632]
\end{pmatrix} [632]
\label{CKM_matrix} [632]
\end{equation} [632]
[632]
\subsection{Quantum Chromodynamics} [2]
\label{ss:quantum_chromodynamics} [2]
[2]
In the theory of quantum chromodynamics (QCD), the charge of the strong force is colour, and the force is [21]
independent of other particle properties such as charge and flavour. Empirical data has led to the conclusion [38]
that there are three colour charges: red, green and blue~\cite{Griffiths:1987tj}. Colour conservation is a [52]
requirement of strong processes (cf. charge conservation in QED), although the colour of an individual quark [68]
can be changed in a strong interaction. The mediators of the strong force, gluons, carry a positive and a [87]
negative colour charge themselves, and so can interact directly with other gluons. The coupling constant of [103]
the strong force is a running coupling constant. At small distances of the order of the size of the proton [123]
(\textasciitilde0.1\fm), $\alpha_{S}$ is small and becomes smaller as distance decreases, leading to quarks [136]
and gluons being essentially free particles and interacting weakly with each other when confined within [151]
colourless bound states (though this interaction is still stronger than the electromagnetic force). This [165]
phenomenon is termed asymptotic freedom. [170]
[170]
The previously mentioned colourless bound quark states are called hadrons. The process in which free gluons [186]
and quarks form bound colourless states is called hadronisation, and at high momenta manifests as a cone of [204]
particles, termed jets. Hadrons are divided into two types: mesons are composed of a quark and an antiquark [222]
with the quark carrying a colour charge and the antiquark carrying the respective anticolour; baryons are [238]
composed of three quarks or three antiquarks. Recently, the LHCb experiment at CERN published first results of [255]
the observation of a pentaquark state~\cite{Aaij:2015tga}. [261]
[261]
The proton, a baryon, consists of two \uquarks, one \dquark and gluons binding the quarks together. However, [276]
the structure of the proton becomes more complicated, consisting of more particles, as the momentum of the [293]
probing particle increases. The aforementioned three-quark-structure of the proton is evident at low momenta, [307]
while at higher momenta, virtual pairs of quarks and antiquarks, and gluons are visible. These virtual quarks [324]
are termed sea quarks and, together with the gluons, can make up most of the mass of the proton at high energy [346]
scales. In any proton, each constituent particle carries some fraction, $x$, of the overall proton momentum. [362]
[362]
The quantum field theory of QCD is determined to have the underlying symmetry of the group $SU(3)$, based on [381]
the fact that there are three colour charges. Imposing local gauge invariance, the Lagrangian contains eight [397]
generators of the $SU(3)$ group. These generators lead to eight gauge fields, whose physical interpretation [412]
are the eight massless gluons that mediate the strong force. Therefore, although in principle there could be [429]
nine gluons, since there are three colours and gluons carry a colour and an anticolour charge, the $SU(3)$ [447]
symmetry leads to a colour octet and a colour singlet~\cite{Griffiths:1987tj}. [457]
[457]
Any particle that occurs in nature must be a colour singlet, and so the gluons in the colour octet are never [478]
seen in nature as free particles. However, although the final gluon is a colour singlet, it has not been [497]
observed and is thought not to exist. If it did exist, it would result in a long range strong force, but it is [520]
known that the strong force has a short range of action. [531]
[531]
\subsection{Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking} [3]
\label{ss:spontaneous_symmetry_breaking} [3]
[3]
The theory of spontaneous breaking of the electroweak $SU(2)$ symmetry, mentioned in [15]
Section~\ref{ss:electroweak_theory}, also known as the Higgs mechanism, was put forward in the [27]
1960s~\cite{Higgs:1964pj}. This theory was postulated as a mechanism by which the $\W^{\pm}$ and \Z gauge [41]
bosons could acquire mass, since the Lagrangian of the electroweak interaction contains no mass term for these [58]
particles, and their inclusion would violate local gauge invariance. [67]
[67]
The method by which this symmetry is spontaneously broken begins with the inclusion of two new complex scalar [85]
`Higgs' fields (so in total there are four components to these two complex fields). These fields are [102]
introduced with an additional scalar potential energy term in the Lagrangian, $V(\Phi)$, where $\Phi$ [116]
represents the newly introduced complex scalar fields. %in the form of a doublet. [123]
The potential $V(\Phi)$ is chosen to be [130]
\begin{equation} [131]
V(\Phi) = -\mu^{2} \Phi^\dagger \Phi + \lambda^{2} (\Phi^\dagger \Phi)^{2} [131]
\end{equation} [131]
Imposing the requirement of $\mu^{2}$ and $\lambda$ both being greater than 0, gives a potential of the [148]
geometry shown in Figure~\ref{fig:higgs_potential}. The minimum of this potential is clearly not at [161]
$\Phi=0$, rather, the minimum has a circular form given by the formula $\Phi^\dagger \Phi = [174]
\frac{\mu^{2}}{2\lambda} = \frac{v^{2}}{2}$, where $v = \frac{\abs{\mu}}{\sqrt\lambda}$, the `vacuum [178]
expectation value' of the Higgs field. Since the minimum, \ie the vacuum, is at a location other than $\Phi = [196]
0$, the new field is said to have a non-zero vacuum expectation value, and the $SU(2) \times U(1)$ symmetry is [213]
spontaneously broken. The observed Higgs boson is created as a result of perturbations in the potential about [230]
this minimum. % which removes three of the four $\Phi$ components as the \W^{+}, \W^{-} and \Z bosons, with [232]
% the remaining field being the scalar Higgs field. [232]
In addition to this new particle, introducing the new fields also results in the fields associated with the [250]
$\W^{\pm}$ and $\Z^{0}$ bosons in the Lagrangian acquiring mass. [259]
%One of these new fields, $\eta$ and $\xi$. One of these, known as the Goldsone boson, is eaten by the other [259]
%thereby acquiring mass. It is this field that is known as the Higgs field. [259]
[259]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [259]
  \centering [259]
   \includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{Chapters/03_Theory/Images/higgspot}\hfill [259]
   \caption[The Higgs field potential.]{The Higgs field potential $V(\Phi)$~\cite{Moss:2015fma}.} [264]
   \label{fig:higgs_potential} [264]
\end{figure} [264]
[264]
Terms known as Yukawa coupling terms can be introduced to specify the interactions of $\Phi$ with the fermion [282]
fields. It is this coupling of the Higgs field to any massive particle that gives them a proportional mass. [301]
The top quark, being the heaviest known particle at \textasciitilde173\GeV, has a Yukawa coupling to the [317]
Higgs field close to 1. [322]
%TODO: IMPORTANT BECAUSE? [322]
[322]
Results published at the discovery of the Higgs boson are shown in Figure~\ref{fig:higgs_results} in the [337]
Higgs$\rightarrow\gamma\gamma$ and Higgs$\rightarrow\Z\Z$ channels. These plots of the invariant masses of the [351]
$\gamma\gamma$ and $\Z\Z$ combinations show a clear excess of events around 125\GeV. The latest results from [367]
CMS and ATLAS state a Higgs mass of $125.09\pm0.21\pm0.11\GeV$~\cite{Aad:2015zhl}, where the first uncertainty [380]
is statistical and the second is systematic. Since the announcement of the discovery of the Higgs boson in 2012, [399]
studies have continued to determine its quantum properties. Thus far, results show it to be in agreement with [417]
predictions from the Standard Model~\cite{Khachatryan:2014jba}. [422]
[422]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [422]
  \centering [422]
   \includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{Chapters/03_Theory/Images/sbweightedmassunweightedinset1_5GeV}\hfill [422]
   \includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{Chapters/03_Theory/Images/H4l_mass_v3}\hfill [422]
   \caption[Invariant mass in $H\rightarrow\gamma\gamma$ (left) and $H\rightarrow\Z\Z$ (right) [422]
    channels.]{Invariant mass in $H\rightarrow\gamma\gamma$ (left) and $H\rightarrow\Z\Z$ (right) channels [422]
    ~\cite{Chatrchyan:2012xdj}.} [422]
    \label{fig:higgs_results} [422]
\end{figure} [422]
[422]
\section{Incompleteness of, and physics beyond, the SM} [7]
\label{s:Incompleteness_of_and_physics_beyond_the_SM} [7]
The Standard Model has proven to be an extremely successful theory thus far. However, its inability to [24]
describe many phenomena in the universe lead to it being considered currently incomplete. Indeed, a `Grand [40]
Unified Theory' combining the electromagnetic, weak, and strong interactions is considered to be the next step [56]
in the quest for a `Theory of Everything' including gravity, with all of these forces being different physical [74]
manifestations of one single force. [79]
[79]
There are many free parameters in the Standard Model and the very reason why it takes the form it has, with [100]
four fundamental forces, six quarks and six leptons, each divided into three generations, is not explained. [116]
The gravitational force is also conspicuous by its absence from the SM. The imbalance between matter and [133]
anti-matter in the universe, despite the generally accepted view that both were created in equal quantities in [150]
the Big Bang, is also not fully explained by the SM. Although the evident matter-antimatter asymmetry in the [168]
universe could be partially explained by the observed charge-parity (CP) symmetry violation in weak [182]
interactions~\cite{Christenson:1964fg}, this is not sufficient to account for the observed excess. [193]
[193]
Furthermore, the SM does not provide a theoretical explanation for neutrino mass. Originally thought to be [209]
massless, neutrinos are now thought to have mass, albeit extremely small, based on observations of neutrino [225]
oscillations between different flavours~\cite{Kajita:1998bw,Fukuda:1998mi}. [229]
[229]
The hierarchy problem, in terms of the Higgs boson, refers to the fact that the measured Higgs mass is many [249]
orders of magnitude smaller than the order of the Planck scale ($1.22\times10^{19}\GeV$). The expected [263]
% quadratically divergent [263]
quantum corrections to the Higgs mass from higher order interactions should result in a far larger mass. This [281]
disagreement suggests that there occurs some `fine tuning' of the bare Higgs mass, to lead to the [298]
experimentally observed mass of approximately 125\GeV. [304]
[304]
Supersymmetry (SUSY) is one potential solution to hierarchy problem. This theory proposes a symmetry between [319]
fermions (spin $\frac{1}{2}$) and bosons (spin 1). Each particle has an associated `superpartner' with [333]
identical quantum properties with the exception of spin, which differs by $\frac{1}{2}$, so that all SM [349]
fermions have a boson superpartner, and all SM bosons have a fermion superpartner. [362]
These super particles, or sparticles, are thought to have higher masses than their SM counterparts since they [379]
have not been discovered yet, making supersymmetry a broken symmetry. In many supersymmetry theories, the [394]
lightest SUSY particle (LSP) is stable and is a potential candidate to be a dark matter particle. [411]
[411]
Another potential solution is the theory of topcolor, an example of a composite model theory that suggests the [429]
existence of a top-quark-condensate (a composite field of the top and antitop [441]
quarks)~\cite{1990PhRvD..41.1647B,1991PhLB..266..419H} that acts effectively like the SM Higgs field. Such a [452]
theory gives rise to a new fundamental interaction between top quarks at high energies resulting in the large [470]
top mass. Theories of extra dimensions also exist, in which additional space-time dimensions are postulated in [486]
which only gravity propagates~\cite{ArkaniHamed:1998rs}. This could provide an explanation for the fact that [499]
the Planck scale is far larger than the electroweak force by solving the heirarchy problem. [514]
[514]
The universe is thought to constitute of about 27~\% dark matter, 68~\% dark energy and 5~\% ordinary [531]
matter (Figure~\ref{fig:universe_composition})~\cite{Ade:2013sjv}. The origins and nature of the dark energy and dark [543]
matter are currently unknown and they are as yet unobserved, but their existence has been inferred from their [561]
gravitational effects on galactic masses composed of stars, gases and dust. The relatively large amounts of [577]
dark matter and dark energy hypothesised suggests that they are made up of weakly interacting massive [593]
particles. [594]
[594]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [594]
  \centering [594]
   \includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{Chapters/03_Theory/Images/planck_cosmic_pie}\hfill [594]
   \caption[The composition of the universe showing the amounts of dark matter, dark energy and ordinary     matter.]{The composition of the universe showing the amounts of dark matter, dark energy and ordinary [609]
    matter based on latest results from Planck/ESA~\cite{Ade:2013sjv}} [617]
   \label{fig:universe_composition} [617]
\end{figure} [617]

  • Included file: Chapters/03_Theory/03a_TheStandardModel.tex
  • Encoding: ascii
  • Sum count: 3585
  • Words in text: 3405
  • Words in headers: 25
  • Words in float captions: 42

  • Number of floats: 4
  • Number of math inlines: 106
  • Number of math displayed: 7

  • 549+1+0 (1/0/12/0) Section: Introduction
  • 330+2+0 (1/0/9/0) Subsection: Gauge Principle
  • 439+2+15 (1/1/15/3) Subsection: Quantum Electrodynamics
  • 586+2+0 (1/0/41/3) Subsection: Electroweak Theory
  • 524+2+0 (1/0/5/0) Subsection: Quantum Chromodynamics
  • 393+3+4 (1/2/21/1) Subsection: Spontaneous Symmetry Breaking
  • 584+7+23 (1/1/3/0) Section: Incompleteness of, and physics beyond, the SM
    •

File: Chapters/03_Theory/03b_Top_Physics.tex

\chapter{Top Physics at the LHC} [5]
\label{c:top_physics_at_the_lhc} [5]
[5]
\section{Introduction} [1]
\label{s:top_physics_intro} [1]
The top quark was discovered by the CDF and D{\O} collaborations at the Tevatron at Fermilab in 1995 [19]
\cite{Abe:1995hr, Abachi:1995iq} and is still one of the less well studied fundamental particles in the [32]
Standard Model. The top quark is the heaviest fermion with its mass currently placed at $173.29 \pm 0.23 [48]
(\stat) \pm 0.92 (\syst) \mathrm{\GeV/c^{2}}$~\cite{top_mass}. Since the lifetime of the top quark is very [57]
short, approximately $5 \times 10^{25}\mathrm{\s}$~\cite{Agashe:2014kda}, it is the only one of the quarks to [69]
decay before it hadronises, meaning that the bare quark properties can be investigated. These unique [84]
properties of the top quark within the Standard Model mean it is an interesting focus of study. [101]
[101]
\subsection{Top Quark Production and Decay} [5]
\label{ss:top_quark_production_and_decay} [5]
Top quarks can be produced either in top-antitop (\ttbar) production through the strong interaction or single [20]
top (\tquark) production through the electroweak mechanism. During Run~1 of data taking at the LHC produced [36]
millions of top quark pair events with gluon-gluon fusion or quark-antiquark annihilation being the primary [51]
production mechanisms (shown in Figure~\ref{fig:ttbar_production}). Gluon-gluon fusion dominates at the LHC [62]
since protons are collided with protons, meaning antiquarks are only available from sea quarks in the proton. [79]
At low momentum fractions, $x$, the gluon density in the proton is large compared to the sea quarks, and [98]
increases towards lower $x$ at a higher rate than that of the sea quarks. Figure~\ref{fig:proton_parton_pdfs} [113]
shows the proton parton distribution functions (PDFs) at a momentum transfer, $Q^{2}=10\GeV^{2}$, of the order [128]
required for \cPqt/\W/\Z production. At low $x$, it can be seen that the sea quarks and gluons dominate, while [146]
the valence quarks increase in number at high $x$. [155]
[155]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [155]
  \centering [155]
   \includegraphics[width=0.9\textwidth]{Chapters/03_Theory/Images/ttbar_production}\hfill [155]
   \caption[Feynman diagrams of leading order \ttbar production processes.]{Feynman diagrams of leading [155]
    order \ttbar production processes. (a) depicts quark-antiquark annihilation, and (b, (c) and (d) depict [155]
    gluon-gluon fusion in the s, t and u channels respectively.)} [155]
    \label{fig:ttbar_production} [155]
\end{figure} [155]
[155]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [155]
  \centering [155]
   \includegraphics[width=0.7\textwidth]{Chapters/03_Theory/Images/proton_pdfs} [155]
    \hfill [155]
   \caption[Proton parton distribution functions at $Q^{2}=10\GeV^{2}$.]{Parton Distribution Functions [155]
    (PDFs) from HERA as a function of proton momentum fraction for [155]
    $Q^{2}=10\GeV^{2}$~\cite{Placakyte:2011az}} [155]
    \label{fig:proton_parton_pdfs} [155]
\end{figure} [155]
[155]
At $\sqrt{s}=7\TeV$, gluon-gluon fusion accounts for approximately 80~\% of the total \ttbar production, [167]
increasing to approximately 90~\% at $\sqrt{s}=14\TeV$ \cite{Agashe:2014kda}. [173]
% A \ttbar production cross section of has been measured at $\sqrt{s}=7\TeV$ and at $\sqrt{s}=8\TeV$. [173]
[173]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [173]
  \centering [173]
   \includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{Chapters/03_Theory/Images/toplhcwg_ttxsec_sqrts_may2015}\hfill [173]
   \caption[\ttbar production cross sections at 1.96\TeV at CDF and D{\O} at the TeVatron and at 7\TeV and [173]
    8\TeV at CMS and ATLAS at the LHC.]{\ttbar production cross sections at 1.96\TeV at CDF and D{\O} at the [173]
    TeVatron and at 7\TeV and 8\TeV at CMS and ATLAS at the LHC~\cite{TOPLHC_WG}} [173]
    \label{fig:ttbar_cross_sections} [173]
\end{figure} [173]
[173]
Top quarks decay almost 100~\% of the time to a \W boson and a \cPqb flavour jet. The \W boson then decays [192]
either hadronically (into two jets) or leptonically (lepton + neutrino). Top pair events are characterised by the [208]
decay of the \W bosons: [212]
\begin{itemize} [212]
  \item Leptonic: $\ttbar \rightarrow \W^{+} \cPqb \W^{-} \cPaqb \rightarrow l \nu_{l}\cPqb [214]
 l' \bar{\nu_{l'}} \cPaqb$. [214]
  Both \W bosons decay to a lepton and a neutrino. The event would consist of 2 jets, 2 leptons and 2 [234]
  neutrinos (which would show up as missing transverse energy (\met) in the event). (10.5~\%) [247]
  \item Hadronic: $\ttbar \rightarrow \W^{+} \cPqb \W^{-} \cPaqb \rightarrow \cPq \cPaq \cPqb \cPq \cPaq [249]
 \cPaqb$. Both \W bosons decay to two jets. The event would consist of 6 jets. (45.7~\%) [263]
  \item Semi-Leptonic: $\ttbar \rightarrow \W^{+} \cPqb \W^{-} \cPaqb \rightarrow \cPq \cPaq \cPqb l \nu_{l} [265]
  \cPaqb$. One \W boson decays to a lepton and a neutrino, the other decays to two jets. The event would [283]
  consist of 4 jets, 1 lepton and 1 neutrino. This decay is shown in Figure~\ref{fig:semileptonic_decay}. [298]
  (43.8~\%) [299]
\end{itemize} [299]
[299]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [299]
  \centering [299]
   \includegraphics[width=0.7\textwidth]{Chapters/03_Theory/Images/semileptonic_decay}\hfill [299]
   \caption[Feynman diagram of the electron+jets semi-leptonic \ttbar decay channel.]{Feynman diagram of the [299]
    electron+jets semi-leptonic \ttbar decay channel.} [299]
    \label{fig:semileptonic_decay} [299]
\end{figure} [299]
[299]
The branching ratios for each decay mode are quoted in brackets \cite{Agashe:2014kda}, and are represented [313]
graphically in Figure~\ref{fig:ttbar_branching_ratios}. The numbers of jets in the final state of each channel [327]
could be higher than the numbers quoted above as a result of higher order processes such as initial state [346]
radiation (radiation from the gluons before the \ttbar production) or final state radiation. The hadronic [360]
decay channel, with multiple jets and no leptons in the final state, is difficult to distinguish from the QCD [379]
multijet, W+jets and Z+jets backgrounds. Conversely, the leptonic channel has a very clean signature with two [397]
leptons, however the low branching ratio would limit the available statistics. The semi-leptonic channel, with [412]
one lepton and four jets provides a good balance between statistics and event identification. The lepton can [429]
be any of an electron, muon or $\tau$, but $\tau$s are not included in semi-leptonic \tquark analyses in [447]
general as they are more difficult to identify (see Section~\ref{ss:experimental_uncertainties}). [457]
[457]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [457]
  \centering [457]
   \includegraphics[width=0.5\textwidth]{Chapters/03_Theory/Images/top_pair_decay_channels}\hfill [457]
   \caption[Relative branching ratios of the \ttbar system]{Relative branching ratios of the \ttbar system} [457]
    \label{fig:ttbar_branching_ratios} [457]
\end{figure} [457]
[457]
The signal channel for the analysis described in this work is semi-leptonic \ttbar decay, also referred to as [474]
the lepton+jets channel, where the lepton is either an electron or a muon. These channels have a branching [493]
ratio of apprimxately 14.2~\% and 14.4~\% respectively \cite{Agashe:2014kda}. [500]
[500]
\subsection{Single Top background} [3]
\label{ss:single_top} [3]
Single top production is one of the backgrounds considered in this analysis, and can occur via the electroweak [21]
interaction in one of three channels: s-channel or t-channel which involve the exchange of a virtual \W boson, [38]
or tW-channel which involves the associated production of a \W boson and a top quark. Although semi-leptonic [54]
\ttbar decays have more jets in the final state than these single top production modes, initial state [70]
radiation and final state radiation, where low energy gluons and quarks are produced before and after the [87]
interaction that produces the single \tquark, can increase the numbers of jets in single top events. This can [104]
lead to such events having a similar signature to \ttbar events, and providing a non-negligble background. [119]
[119]
\subsection{W/Z+jets background} [4]
\label{ss:w_z_plus_jets} [4]
\WpJets production presents a significant background to semi-leptonic \ttbar analyses. This background [14]
consists of events in which a real \W boson is produced together with additional jets. Events in which these [32]
\W bosons decay leptonically can provide a similar event signature after reconstruction to that of a [47]
semi-leptonic \ttbar decay. In general, these processes can be removed from the signal selection because the [62]
final decay products in \WpJets events typically have lower energies than those from semi-leptonic \ttbar [75]
decays, since the top quark has a high mass. Another characteristic of \WpJets events is that the jets are [93]
more likely to be light quark jets and therefore less likely to be \bjets than in \ttbar events. Thus, \WpJets [110]
events can be separated from the \ttbar signal by using jet multiplicity, jet \pt and \bjet multiplicity. [124]
[124]
Similarly, \ZpJets events can mimic \ttbar events where the leptonic decay of a \Z boson to a lepton and an [141]
anti-lepton takes place. This background can be distinguished from semi-leptonic \ttbar decays by [153]
vetoing on a second lepton and imposing jet multiplicity requirements. Misidentification and misreconstruction [166]
of these leptons as jets, however, can result in such events mimicking \ttbar events and passing the signal [183]
selection, although this contamination is small. [189]
[189]
\subsection{QCD background} [2]
\label{ss:qcd} [2]
The multijet background from QCD events presents a significant obstacle in many measurements at LHC, including [18]
this semi-leptonic \ttbar analysis. Gluon-gluon fusion and quark-antiquark annihilation in proton-proton [28]
collisions can produce energetic jets. Although these processes have only two jets in their final state, [44]
higher order processes, including initial state radiation and final state radiation, can also produce [58]
additional jets, leading to potential mimicking of the semi-leptonic \ttbar signal. The leptons required for [72]
this to happen can come from jets which are misreconstructed and misidentified as leptons, or real leptons in [90]
heavy flavour (\cPqb and \cPqc) jets. Unfortunately the cross section of these processes is several orders of [105]
magnitude larger than the signal cross section. Although the lepton (either fake or real) is rarely one that [123]
passes selection, the much higher QCD cross section means that its contribution as a background is [139]
significant. [140]
% TODO: READ LUKE'S THESIS FOR WAYS IN WHICH JETS CAN FAKE AN ELECTRON OR A MUON [140]
[140]
In the muon+jets channel, only highly energetic jets ($\pt>500\GeV$) are capable of ``punching through'' from [156]
the calorimeters to leave tracks in the muon chambers. Such events can be removed by isolation requirements [173]
(since they deposit significant amounts of energy in the calorimeters). Events with real electrons and muons [189]
from heavy quark jets can be identified by the track quality requirements in the selection since they would [207]
not begin from the primary vertex and so would have a distinct track signature compared to prompt leptons. [225]
[225]
On the other hand, the electron channel poses a more problematic QCD background, due mainly to the conversion [243]
of photons, whether produced at the interaction point or through subsequent decays and radiation, into [258]
electrons and positrons. The identification and removal of such events is described in [271]
Section~\ref{ss:electron_reconstruction}. However, the large uncertainty in the cross sections of QCD events, [283]
large contamination from higher order processes with additional jets in the signal region of this analysis and [300]
the difficulty in modelling such contributions, lead to incorrect event kinematics and significant [313]
disagreements in the QCD background distributions in data and in simulation. Therefore, the QCD background is [329]
modelled using a data driven method, described in Section~\ref{ss:background_selection}, and then normalised [341]
to the number of events passing the signal selection in simulation. [352]
[352]
\section{Monte Carlo Simulation} [3]
\label{s:monte_carlo_simulation} [3]
[3]
Monte Carlo event simulation is used to simulate the aforementioned signal and background processes, and to [19]
compare the theoretical knowledge of the SM incorporated therein with real data. Differences [32]
between simulation and data would then indicate the presence of new physics processes which are not present in [50]
the theoretical assumptions made in the SM, or perhaps that the simulation process is sub-optimal. [65]
Different event generators exist, and samples produced by the \MADGRAPH, \PYTHIA, \POWHEG and \HERWIG [75]
generators are used in this analysis. [81]
[81]
Different generators have characteristics which optimise them for different aspects of the production chain: [95]
the initial hard process scattering of the partons in the hadrons (protons), decay showers of the resulting [112]
partons, subsequent decays of resulting hadrons and hadronisation of resulting partons, and the underlying [126]
event (the parton showers produced from soft scattering between the remaining contents of the colliding [141]
protons). [142]
[142]
\subsection{MadGraph} [1]
\label{ss:madgraph} [1]
\MADGRAPH \cite{madgraph5}, a matrix element generator, works by taking into account next-to-leading-order [11]
Feynman diagrams for a given process and subsequently calculating the matrix elements for these diagrams over [27]
all phase space. The Parton Distribution Functions are used to generate the incoming partons. [41]
The cross section of the process and various subprocesses and the structure and contents of the event (such as [60]
the partons present and their kinematics) are thus produced. %Also spin correlations. Also tau lepton decays [69]
Proton fragmentation and subsequent hadronisation are simulated using the \PYTHIA generator, as explained in [82]
Section~\ref{ss:pythia}. [83]
[83]
The parton showers are then matched with the matrix element partons via the MLM method~\cite{mlm}. This [99]
method ensures that parton showers with a highly energetic jet are not double counted. Matching is carried out [117]
between parton showers in the hadronisation and the partons from the matrix element calculations. The matching [133]
is carried out by satisfying distance requirements in $\eta$ and $\phi$ between the parton and parton shower. [150]
Only if the parton has a transverse energy above a certain threshold, is it considered for this matching, and [169]
if an event contains either too few or too many matching jets, it is discarded. The matching threshold is [188]
process dependent as follows: [192]
[192]
\onehalfspacing [193]
\begin{itemize} [193]
  \item \ttbar: 20\GeV [194]
 \item \WpJets: 10\GeV [195]
 \item \ZpJets: 10\GeV [196]
\end{itemize} [196]
\doublespacing [196]
[196]
\subsection{MCatNLO} [1]
\label{ss:mcatnlo} [1]
The \MCATNLO \cite{mcatnlo_Frixione1, mcatnlo_Frixione2} generator is a next-to-leading-order generator. These [8]
aditional corrections provide more accurate simulations of physics processes in comparison to leading-order [21]
generators by including additional partons from the initial hard process in the final state of the event. [38]
[38]
\subsection{PYTHIA} [1]
\label{ss:pythia} [1]
\PYTHIA \cite{pythia8} then simulates the proton fragmentation, the subsequent hadronisation of the [11]
resulting quarks and gluons resulting from the hard interaction and the underlying event. \PYTHIA is [25]
considered to be particuarly good at multi-particle simulation, modelling fragmentation and hadronisation, and [38]
matching parton showers. Therefore, \PYTHIA carries out these steps after the initial partons are provided [52]
by other generators in most simulated samples, if it is not already used for the whole production chain (as is [72]
common in QCD multijet simulations). [77]
[77]
\subsection{POWHEG} [1]
\label{ss:powheg} [1]
One problem with the \MCATNLO generator is that some events are given negative weights when matching [16]
the next-to-leading-order QCD multijet calculations to parton showers.  The Positive Weight Hardest Emission [29]
Generator, \POWHEG \cite{powheg_Frixione, powheg_Nason, powheg_Alioli}, is another next-to-leading-order [33]
generator which generates the hardest processes in the event first, which avoids double counting of [48]
softer radiation produced later in the chain, which is the cause of negative event weights. [63]
[63]
%\subsection{HERWIG} [63]
%\label{ss:herwig} [63]
%\HERWIG \cite{herwig} [63]
%TODO:HERWIG [63]
[63]
\section{Theoretical Systematics} [2]
\label{s:Theoretical Systematics} [2]
\subsection{Factorisation \& Matching Threshold} [3]
\label{ss:factorisation_and_matching_threshold} [3]
The models used in generators use an essentially arbitrary choice for the threshold transverse energy above [19]
which matrix-element partons are matched to parton showers. To account for the systematic uncertainties as a result [36]
of this threshold, simulated samples in which the threshold is increased and decreased by a factor of 2 (see [55]
Table~\ref{tab:matching_uncertainty_thresholds}) are used to estimate the affect of this uncertainty on this [67]
analysis. Similarly, the factorisation scale at which $\alpha_{S}$ is varied up and down from the nominal [83]
value of $Q^{2} = m^{2} + \Sigma p_{T}^{2}$ by a factor of 2 (see Table~\ref{tab:matching_uncertainty_thresholds}) to [94]
produce simulation samples to evaluate the systematic uncertainty resulting from this. The uncertainty [107]
resulting from these variations are evaluated in both \ttbar and \W/\ZpJets processes. [117]
[117]
\input{Chapters/03_Theory/tables/theoretical_systematics} [117]
[117]
\subsection{Detector Simulation (GEANT)} [3]
\label{ss:detector_simulation} [3]
Following creation of the physics processes in proton-proton collisions, the simulated events are then put [18]
through a detector simulation to evaluate the interaction of the detector with the products of collisions. The [35]
Geometry and Tracking 4 (\GEANTfour) package~\cite{Agostinelli:2002hh,Allison:2006ve} is used for this [44]
purpose, which simulates what happens to particles as they travel through the geometry of the detector, [60]
including simulation of the detector components and materials and the interaction of particles with the [75]
detector such as particle tracks and energy deposits.

  • Included file: Chapters/03_Theory/03b_Top_Physics.tex
  • Encoding: ascii
  • Sum count: 1984
  • Words in text: 1930
  • Words in headers: 35
  • Words in float captions: 0
  • Number of headers: 14
  • Number of floats: 5
  • Number of math inlines: 19
  • Number of math displayed: 0
  • Subcounts:

File: Chapters/04_Analysis/04a_BTags/04a_BTagStudies.tex

\chapter{\btagging Study} [1]
\label{c:b_tagging_study} [1]
[1]
The decay of the \tquark to a \W boson and a \bquark necessitates a thorough understanding of these decay [17]
products in \ttbar events. In particular, methods to identify jets coming from a \bquark, known as \btagging, [31]
are commonly used to increase the efficiency of $\tquark\rightarrow\bquark\W$ signal selection. CMS has [44]
several algorithms for \btagging: TrackCounting (High Efficiency) and TrackCounting (High Purity), [54]
JetBProbability; JetProbability; SoftMuon; SoftMuonByPt; SoftMuonByIP3d; SimpleSecondaryVertex (High [61]
Efficiency); SimpleSecondaryVertex (High Purity); CombinedSecondaryVertex and CombinedSecondaryVetexMVA. These [69]
algorithms produce a discriminator output for each jet which indicates how likely it is to be a \bquark [86]
flavour jet. In all cases, a more positive discriminator value indicates a jet that is more likely to be a [106]
\bquark flavour jet. [108]
[108]
The relatively long lifetime (of the order of $10^{-12}\s$) of \bquarks means that they travel a significant [124]
distance (of the order of a few \mm) before decaying. This leads to events with \bjets possessing a secondary [141]
vertex at a distinguishable distance from the primary interaction vertex, as seen in [154]
Figure~\ref{fig:secondary_vertex}. This secondary vertex information, together with track based information [164]
such as the number of tracks in the jet, the invariant mass of the secondary vertex and the impact parameter [184]
significance (described below) of each jet track, is used by the CSV algorithm to produce a discriminator [201]
ranging from 0 to 1, with larger numbers corresponding to a higher probability of a jet being a \bjet. Three [220]
\btagging working points are used in CMS: tight, medium and loose. The medium working point is used in the [238]
different cross sections analysis, which carries a 1~\% mis-tag rate (the rate at which non-\bjets are [254]
mistakenly tagged as \bjets) and approximately 70~\% \btag efficiency. [261]
The tight and loose working points have mis-tag rates of 0.1~\% and 10~\% [274]
respectively~\cite{Chatrchyan:2012jua}. [275]
[275]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [275]
  \centering [275]
   \includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04a_BTags/Images/b_tagging_graphic}\\ [275]
   \caption[Graphical representation of a secondary vertex.]{Graphical representation of an [279]
    interaction originating at the primary vertex producing three jets, one of which is a \bjet with a [295]
    secondary vertex~\cite{d0_fnal}.} [297]
   \label{fig:secondary_vertex} [297]
\end{figure} [297]
[297]
\section{Observables used in \btagging algorithms} [4]
\label{s:observables_used_in_btagging_algorithms} [4]
[4]
The impact parameter (IP) of a track is defined as the distance between the track and the vertex at the point [25]
of closest approach~\cite{CMS-PAS-BTV-09-001}. Figure~\ref{fig:impact_parameter} shows a schematic [32]
representation of the impact parameter for one single track. The IP measurement can be made in either the [50]
plane transverse to the beam line, or in three dimensions. The impact parameter significance [64]
(IP/$\sigma_{IP}$) is often used instead as an input to \btagging algorithms to allow for the experimental [80]
resolution, due to the fact that the uncertainty on the IP value alone can be as large as the IP itself. The [102]
IP significance distribution of light jets ($\cPqu$, $\cPqd$, $\cPqs$) and gluon jets form a Gaussian [117]
distribution about a mean of zero and width of one, with a slightly extended tail due to tracks from particles [137]
in the jet with long lifetimes. The equivalent distribution for \cjets and \bjets show an asymmetric [151]
distribution at positive values due to the long lifetime of B and C hadrons, making the IP significance a [170]
useful parameter to distinguish between light and heavy flavour jets~\cite{CMS-AN-2005-041}. [180]
[180]
The signed IP is also used, in which the sign is obtained from the sign of the scalar product of the IP vector [203]
and the jet direction, so that it is positive if the angle between the IP vector and the jet direction is less [225]
than 90$^{\circ}$, and negative if the angle is greater than 90$^{\circ}$. Tracks belonging in a \bjet would [243]
have an IP sign >0, since the jet direction is an estimate of the direction of travel of the B hadron. [264]
However, the sign could be inaccurately calculated in cases with badly reconstructed jet directions or primary [280]
vertices, or badly measured track parameters~\cite{CMS-AN-2005-041}. Another parameter based on track length, [292]
the 3D decay length significance (the ratio of the three dimensional distance between the primary vertex and [309]
the secondary vertex, and the uncertainty on this value) is also used by some \btagging algorithms. [324]
[324]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [324]
  \centering [324]
   \includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04a_BTags/Images/impact_parameter}\\ [324]
   \caption[Graphical representation of a track impact parameter.]{Graphical representation of a track [329]
    impact parameter~\cite{CMS-PAS-BTV-09-001}.} [331]
   \label{fig:impact_parameter} [331]
\end{figure} [331]
[331]
Identification of vertices in CMS consists of two stages: vertex finding and vertex fitting. Vertex finding [347]
deals with the creation of vertex candidates by grouping reconstructed tracks together. Vertex fitting then [362]
deals with obtaining the vertex parameters such as position of the vertex and track parameters, and the [379]
quality of the fit. An adaptive vertex fitter~\cite{0954-3899-34-12-N01} calculates an estimate of the vertex [393]
position and weights tracks based on their compatibility with the vertex. This first fit is constrained to the [411]
interaction region to identify prompt tracks. After removing tracks with weights >0.5, subsequent fits are [426]
carried out to identify potential decay vertices, until no new vertex is identified. [439]
[439]
\section{\btagging algorithm descriptions} [2]
\label{s:btagging_algorithm_descriptions} [2]
[2]
\subsection{Track Counting} [2]
\label{ss:track_counting} [2]
The simplest \btagging algorithms available in CMS are the track counting [12]
algorithms~\cite{CMS-PAS-BTV-09-001}, which positively identifies a \bjet if it contains N or more tracks with [25]
IP significance above some theshold value. They function by ordering all good tracks in a jet by order of [44]
decreasing IP significance, with the discriminator being the IP significance of the Nth track. The high [60]
efficiency version of this algorithm uses N=2, i.e. the second track, and the high purity version uses N=3, [80]
i.e. the third track~\cite{CMS-AN-2005-041}. [84]
[84]
\subsection{Jet Probability} [2]
\label{ss:jet_probability} [2]
The ``jet probability'' algorithms~\cite{CMS-PAS-BTV-09-001} produce a discriminator based on the probability that [14]
the set of tracks come from the primary vertex: a high probability would indicate that the jet is not a \bjet, [34]
which would originate at a secondary vertex. These algorithms use all tracks as input and for each track [52]
define an individual probability of coming from the primary vertex. By combining these probabilities, a jet [68]
probability is produced, and the discriminator is the negative log of this confidence [81]
level~\cite{CMS-AN-2005-041}. The ``jet B probability'' variant is based on the four most displaced tracks in [96]
the jet, since the mean number of tracks in a \bjet is approximately 5 and the reconstruction of tracks within [115]
jets has an efficiency of approximately 0.8 in CMS~\cite{CMS-PAS-BTV-09-001}. The ``jet B probability'' in this [130]
case is based on the confidence level that the four most displaced tracks originate from the primary vertex. [148]
[148]
\subsection{Soft Muon} [2]
\label{ss:soft_muon} [2]
The ``soft muon'' algorithms make use of global muons reconstructed in the vicinity of the reconstructed jet, [19]
which may indicate a semi-leptonic decay of B hadrons to a muon~\cite{CMS-AN-2009-085}. Two soft muon [34]
algorithms exist in CMS. The ``soft muon by \pt'' algorithm uses the relative \pt of the muon with respect to [52]
the jet ($p_{T}{rel}$), which is expected to be larger than that for muons in light flavour jets due to the [72]
large \bquark mass~\cite{CMS-AN-2009-085, Ferro:2012tg}. A ``soft muon by IP algorithm'' also exists which [83]
uses the IP significance of positive IP muons. In jets containing more than one muon, the muon with the [102]
highest discriminator is used. [106]
[106]
\subsection{Simple Secondary Vertex} [3]
\label{ss:simple_secondary_vertex} [3]
The simple secondary vertex (SSV) algorithm uses the Adaptive Vertex Fitter to reconstruct the secondary [18]
vertex~\cite{0954-3899-34-12-N01}. The discriminator is calculated based on the 3D decay length significance. [30]
If no secondary vertex is reconstructed, no discriminator is produced, meaning that the efficiency of this [46]
algorithm is limited to the maximum efficiency of secondary vertex reconstruction (approximately [58]
65~\%)~\cite{Chatrchyan:2012jua}. There are two variants of the simple secondary vertex algorithm: the high [71]
efficiency version uses vertices with at least two compatible tracks, whereas the high purity version uses [87]
vertices with at least three tracks. Since this algorithm does not directly use track-based lifetime [102]
parameters, it is less sensitive than other algorithms to tracker misalignment. [113]
[113]
\subsection{Combined Secondary Vertex} [3]
\label{ss:combined_secondary_vertex} [3]
The current CMS recommendation for physics analyses (and therefore the algorithm used in the differential [18]
cross section analysis presented in [23]
Chapters~\ref{c:Differential_Cross_Section:data_simulation_and_selection}-\ref{c:Differential_Cross_Section:systematics_and_results}) [24]
is the Combined Secondary Vertex (CSV) algorithm~\cite{Weiser:2006md}. This algorithm reconstructs the event [36]
vertices using the Trimmed Kalman Vertex Finder~\cite{Speer:927395}. This vertex finding algorithm fits tracks [49]
to a primary vertex after removing incompatible tracks and applies cuts to these vertices in order to find a [68]
secondary vertex. The CSV algorithm then combines track-based lifetime parameters, such as IP and flight [83]
distance significance, with secondary vertex information to produce a discriminator. The increased number of [97]
input parameters means that even in cases with no reconstructed secondary vertex a discriminator can be [113]
produced, thereby increasing the maximum efficiency compared to the SSV algorithms~\cite{Chatrchyan:2012jua}. [124]
A variant of this algorithm in which a multi-variate analysis (MVA) is performed using the CMSSW MVA Tools to [143]
produce a discriminator. [146]
[146]
\section{Performance Comparison} [2]
\label{s:performance_comparison} [2]
[2]
Distributions of the discriminators produced by the above algorithms were created for a \ttbar \MADGRAPH Monte [16]
Carlo simulation sample (/TTJets\_TuneZ2\_7TeV-madgraph-tauola/, produced in the Fall2011 production cycle [28]
using CMSSSW version 44X). A comparison of the discriminator distributions, after normalising to unit area, [43]
for the described algorithms were carried out. Figure~\ref{fig:CSV_discriminators} shows a comparison between [55]
the distributions obtained by the CSV algorithm for the different jets present in the sample: \bjets, light [71]
jets (up, down and strange flavour: \udsjets), gluon jets (\gjets) and charm flavour jets (\cjets). All [84]
distributions were normalised to unity in order to facilitate shape comparision. Equivalent plots for other [99]
algorithms are included in Figure~\ref{fig:all_algorithm_discriminators} in Appendix~\ref{ac:b_tagging_plots}. [106]
In all cases, it can be seen that higher discriminator values were produced for \bjets than for \udsjets, [122]
\gjets and \cjets, as expected. [125]
[125]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [125]
  \centering [125]
   \includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04a_BTags/Images/CombinedSecondaryVertex_norm_discriminator_combined}\\ [125]
   \caption[Discriminator values produced by the Combined Secondary Vertex algorithm after     normalisation.]{Discriminator values produced by the Combined Secondary Vertex algorithm for all \bjets, [136]
    \cjets, \gjets and \udsjets after normalisation.} [139]
   \label{fig:CSV_discriminators} [139]
\end{figure} [139]
[139]
\section{Efficiency} [1]
\label{s:efficiency} [1]
[1]
Analyses in CMS make use of \btagging algorithms by placing cuts on the discriminators. The efficiency of a [18]
cut can be defined as the ratio of number of jets passing the selection cut to the total number of jets before [40]
the selection cut. The efficiency was calculated for cut values spanning the whole range of discriminator [56]
values, thereby producing a plot of \btag efficiency as a function of CSV discriminator cut value [71]
(Figure~\ref{fig:CSV_jet_efficiencies}). In practice, the aim is to acheive a high \bjet efficiency and a low [85]
efficiency for all other jet flavours, \ie towards the bottom right of the plot. It can be seen that \udsjets [103]
and \gjets have similar rates of increase in efficiencies with respect to cut value, owing to their similar [120]
discriminator distributions. The \cjet discriminator distribution (Figure~\ref{fig:CSV_discriminators}), [126]
however, has a noticeably different shape. This leads to the undesirable trend of higher \cjet efficiencies [141]
than for \udsjets and \gjets. Equivalent plots for other algorithms can be found in [153]
Figure~\ref{fig:all_algorithm_efficiencies} in Appendix~\ref{ac:b_tagging_plots}. [156]
[156]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [156]
  \centering [156]
   \includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04a_BTags/Images/CombinedSecondaryVertex_nonBJetEfficiency_v_bJetEfficiency}\\ [156]
   \caption[Non \bjet efficiencies as a function of \bjet efficiency for the CSV algorithm.]{Non \bjet [156]
   efficiencies as a function of \bjet efficiency for the CSV algorithm.} [156]
    \label{fig:CSV_jet_efficiencies} [156]
\end{figure} [156]
[156]
\section{Algorithm Comparison} [2]
\label{algorithm_comparison} [2]
[2]
The performances of the various algorithms can be compared in Figure~\ref{fig:uds_eff_v_b_eff}. [13]
[13]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [13]
  \centering [13]
   \includegraphics[width=\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04a_BTags/Images/udsJetEfficiency_v_bJetEfficiency_withLegend_wp}\\ [13]
   \caption[udsjet efficiencies as a function of \bjet efficiencies for all algorithms.]{\udsjet [13]
   efficiencies as a function of \bjet efficiencies for all algorithms.} [13]
    %TODO: MAKE PLOT MORE LEGIBLE IF TIME PERMITS [13]
    \label{fig:uds_eff_v_b_eff} [13]
\end{figure} [13]
[13]
It can be seen that not all algorithms reach 100~\% \bjet efficiency due to being inherently limited by their [31]
methods. For example, the soft muon algorithms are limited by the muon identification efficiency within \bjets [46]
and also by the branching fraction of B hadrons to muons. The soft muon algorithms all show low maximum \bjet [65]
efficiencies due to the low B hadron semi-leptonic branching ratio to muons of approximately 11~\% (or 20~\% [82]
when further decays are included such as $\cPqb \rightarrow \cPqc \rightarrow l$) \cite{Ferro:2012tg}. [90]
Similarly, the SSV algorithms are limited by the efficiency of reconstructing a secondary vertex in the jet of [108]
approximately 65~\%. [110]
[110]
The 2011 and 2012 CMS recommended \btagger is the Combined Secondary Vertex with operating point discriminator [125]
cuts of 0.244 (loose), 0.679 (medium) and 0.898 (tight) corresponding to 10\%, 1\% and 0.1\% light jet [142]
efficiency. These cuts are indicated by the horizontal lines on Figure~\ref{fig:uds_eff_v_b_eff}. It can be [156]
seen that for the tight and medium cuts, the CSV MVA algorithm provides the highest \bjet efficiency and [173]
lowest light jet efficiency, followed closely by the CSV algorithm. The multiple variables that are used as [190]
input allow the CSV algorithm to produce higher efficiencies than the SSV algorithms, while the MVA analysis [207]
variant provides a slightly improved performance. At approximately 3\% light jet efficiency, there is a [222]
convergence of many algorithms that all provide similar performance. At the loose working point also, many of [239]
the algorithms provide similar performance with \bjets, with the ``jet probability'' algorithms marginally [251]
outperforming the CSV algorithms. In early CMSSW versions, it was known that the jet probability algorithm [267]
provided optimal performance, leading to it being recommended for early CMS analyses. [279]
Ultimately, the CSV algorithm provides better performance in CMSSW versions after CMSSW\_2\_X\_Y, at which [294]
point it became the recommended \btagging method. [300]
