File: Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/04b_DifferentialTTbarCrossSections_1.tex

\chapter{Differential Cross Sections: Data, Simulation and Selection} [7]
\label{c:Differential_Cross_Section:data_simulation_and_selection} [7]
[7]
\section{Outline} [1]
\label{s:analysis1_outline} [1]
This chapter describes the first part of the main \ttbar differential cross section analysis in bins of global [18]
event variables. Following an introduction to the variables under investigation and motivations, the datasets [32]
used and the selection process is explained, including scale factors and corrections applied to ensure [47]
agreement between Monte Carlo simulation and data. [54]
[54]
The analysis measures the normalised differential \ttbar cross section in the semi-leptonic channel and is [68]
carried out on 2011 and 2012 data recorded from the CMS detector. The measurement is carried out with respect [87]
to the following global, or primary, variables: [94]
\begin {itemize} [94]
[94]
  \item {\met, the missing transverse energy in an event, defined as the magnitude of the missing transverse [109]
  momentum vector \ptvecmiss} [111]
  \[\met = \left[ \left(\sum_i{p_{x}^i}\right)^2 + \left(\sum_i{p_{y}^i}\right)^2 [112]
  \right]^{\frac{1}{2}},\] [112]
  where $p_x^i$ and $p_yi$ are momentum components of the \textit{i}th object in an event, and the sums [129]
  include all objects in the event. [135]
[135]
  \item {\HT, the sum of the transverse momenta of all jets with $\pt>20\GeV$ and $\abseta<2.5$ in an [150]
  event} [151]
  \[\HT = \sum_{\text{all jets}}\pt^{\mathrm{jet}}\]. [152]
[152]
  \item {\st, the sum of all observed transverse momenta in an event, \ie the scalar sum of \HT, \met, and [167]
  lepton \pt} [168]
  \[\st = \HT + \met + p_\mathrm{T}^\mathrm{lepton}.\] [169]
[169]
  \item {\wpt, the transverse momentum of the leptonically decaying \W boson, obtained from \met and the \pt [181]
 of the lepton} [184]
\[\wpt = \sqrt{\left(p_x^{\mathrm{lepton}} + p_x^{\mathrm{miss}}\right)^2 + \left(p_y^{\mathrm{lepton}} + [185]
p_y^{\mathrm{miss}}\right)^2},\] [185]
where $p_{x}^{\mathrm{lepton}}$ and $p_{y}^{\mathrm{lepton}}$ are the transverse components of [194]
$\vec{p}^{\mathrm{lepton}}$, and $p_x^{\mathrm{miss}}$ and $p_y^{\mathrm{miss}}$ are the transverse [202]
components of \ptvecmiss. [204]
[204]
  \item {\mt, the transverse mass of the leptonically decaying \W boson, also obtained from \met and the \pt [217]
 of the lepton} [220]
    \[\mt = \sqrt{\et\left(\text{lepton}, \met\right)^{2} - (\wpt)^{2}},\] [221]
    where $\et\left(\text{lepton}, \met\right)$ is the scalar sum of \met and the transverse energy of the [234]
    lepton, \ie $\met + \et^{\text{lepton}}$ [236]
[236]
\end{itemize} [236]
[236]
% Previous analyses using 7\TeV data investigating \met and using 8\TeV data investigatin all the [236]
% global variables listed above can be found in \cite{CMS-PAS-TOP-12-019} and \cite{CMS-PAS-TOP-12-042} respectively. [236]
[236]
\section{Data and Simulated Samples} [4]
\label{s:data_and_simulated_samples} [4]
[4]
\subsection{Data} [1]
\label{ss:data} [1]
[1]
Data collected in 2011 at a centre-of-mass energy of 7\TeV corresponding to an integrated luminosity of [17]
5.0\fbinv, and in 2012 at a centre-of-mass energy of 8\TeV corresponding to an integrated luminosity of [33]
19.7\fbinv are used in this analysis. The datasets are determined by the triggers that were used to record [51]
them. For 7\TeV, the ``ElectronHad'' dataset is used in the electron channel. It was recorded with triggers [68]
that select based on at least one, isolated electron and additional jets. At 8\TeV, the ``SingleElectron'' [84]
dataset was used for the electron channel which is based only on at least one, isolated electron. In the muon [104]
channel, the ``SingleMu'' dataset was used for both centre-of-mass energies, requiring a single, isolated [118]
muon. [119]
[119]
These datasets are produced from CMS data by requiring events to pass a trigger. The triggers used in both [138]
7\TeV and 8\TeV data are shown in Table\ref{tab:HLTTriggers} in Appendix~\ref{as:datasets}. In the electron [151]
channel, an electron+jets trigger was used in 2011 with a requirement of at least one electron with [169]
\Et$>25\GeV$ and at least three jets with \pt$>30\GeV$; and a single electron trigger was used in 2012 with at [188]
least one electron with \Et$>27\GeV$. In the muon channel, a single muon trigger was used in both data taking [207]
periods with a requirement of at least one muon with \pt$>24\GeV$. In addition to these kinematic [223]
requirements, the triggers also have cuts on the ratio between the HCAL and the ECAL energy ($H/E$), track matching with [243]
ECAL ($\Delta\eta$ and $\Delta\phi$), cluster shape ($\sigma_{i\eta i\eta}$), ECAL isolation [252]
($\frac{\text{ECAL iso}}{E_\text{T}}$), HCAL isolation ($\frac{\text{HCAL iso}}{E_\text{T}}$) and tracker [258]
isolation ($\frac{\text{tracker iso}}{\pt}$). In both channels, the final selection is tighter than these [270]
trigger requirements. [272]
% TODO: see Luke P76-77 for descriptions of these variables. [272]
[272]
The datasets used are shown in Tables~\ref{tab:datasets7TeV} and \ref{tab:datasets8TeV}. %in [280]
%Appendix~\ref{as:datasets}. [280]
Only data that is certified as ``golden'' (data taken with the CMS detector [293]
working without any major faults) is used. The masks used to filter out data taken in other periods are [312]
specified in Table~\ref{tab:JSONfiles} in Appendix~\ref{as:datasets}. [317]
[317]
\input{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/tables/datasets/data_7TeV} [317]
\input{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/tables/datasets/data_8TeV} [317]
[317]
\FloatBarrier [317]
[317]
\subsection{Simulated Samples} [2]
\label{ss:simulated_samples} [2]
The Monte Carlo generators used in this analysis are \MADGRAPH \cite{madgraph5}, \PYTHIA \cite{pythia8}, [11]
\POWHEG \cite{powheg_Nason, powheg_Frixione, powheg_Alioli}, \HERWIG \cite{herwig} and \MCATNLO [12]
\cite{mcatnlo_Frixione1, mcatnlo_Frixione2}. See Section~\ref{s:monte_carlo_simulation} for more details of [18]
these Monte Carlo generators. [22]
[22]
The signal for this analysis is the production of a \ttbar pair which decays semi-leptonically, \ie each of [38]
the \tquarks decays to a \W boson and a \bjet, with one of the \W bosons decaying hadronically to two jets and [56]
the other decaying leptonically to a lepton (electron or muon) and an associated neutrino. [70]
Section~\ref{c:top_physics_at_the_lhc} outlines the signal and background events considered. Additional, lower [80]
energy jets, can be produced from other scatterings in the same proton-proton interaction and from gluon [96]
radiation from quarks in the decay. See Section~\ref{c:top_physics_at_the_lhc} for detailed descriptions of [108]
the signal and backgrounds in this analysis. [115]
[115]
Tables~\ref{tab:signaldatasets7TeV} and~\ref{tab:signaldatasets8TeV} show the Monte Carlo signal samples used [124]
in this analysis at 7\TeV and 8\TeV respectively. Tables~\ref{tab:backgrounddatasets7TeV} [133]
and~\ref{tab:backgrounddatasets8TeV} %in Appendix~\ref{as:datasets} [134]
list the background simulation samples used. Top pair production is modelled using \MADGRAPH, single top [148]
events are modelled with \POWHEG, \W and \Z boson plus jets production is modelled using \MADGRAPH and QCD [162]
multi-jet events are modelled with \PYTHIA. In all cases, \PYTHIA is used to model radiation and hadronisation [177]
processes. Tables~\ref{tab:7TeVsystematicdatasets} and \ref{tab:8TeVsystematicdatasets} show the samples used [184]
to evaluate the factorisation scale, matching threshold, and top quark mass uncertainties. \WpJets and \ZpJets [197]
samples were not made available at 7\TeV, so the scaled distributions from 8\TeV were used, as described in [215]
Section~\ref{sss:7TeV_vjets_theory_systematic_template}. [216]
[216]
\input{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/tables/datasets/signal_samples_7TeV} [216]
\input{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/tables/datasets/signal_samples_8TeV} [216]
\input{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/tables/datasets/background_samples_7TeV} [216]
\input{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/tables/datasets/background_samples_8TeV} [216]
[216]
\begin{landscape} [216]
\input{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/tables/datasets/systematic_samples_7TeV} [216]
\input{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/tables/datasets/systematic_samples_8TeV} [216]
\end{landscape} [216]
[216]
\FloatBarrier [216]
[216]
\section{Selection} [1]
\label{s:selection} [1]
Selection algorithms are run on the data and samples listed in Sections~\ref{s:data_and_simulated_samples} and [14]
\ref{ss:simulated_samples} to identify \ttbar events. The selection process is performed in two stages: a [26]
``pre-selection'' using loose criteria to produce ntuples and a second full selection when processing these [41]
ntuples to produce the final sample. The selection used follows the recommended criteria by the CMS TOP [58]
Physics Analysis Group (PAG) and is the same for 7\TeV and 8\TeV. [70]
[70]
\subsection{Preselection} [1]
\label{ss:preselection} [1]
The preselection is performed on the AOD datasets, with the aim of making the resulting ntuples smaller [18]
in size but still versatile enough for adjustments later in the analysis chain. [31]
[31]
The preselection requires at least one good primary vertex with at least four degrees of freedom, located [48]
within 24\cm of the centre of the CMS detector in the $z$ direction and within 2\cm of the centre of the beam [70]
trajectory in the transverse plane. In addition, events are required to have at least one lepton candidate. In [88]
the case of electrons, a transverse energy of at least 30\GeV and \abseta$<2.5$ and in the muon channel a [107]
transverse momentum of at least 26\GeV and \abseta$<2.1$ are required. [117]
[117]
Several filters are also applied in the preselection stage to remove events with significant levels of noise [134]
due to elements of the detector with sub-optimal performance during data-taking. These filters include an HCAL [150]
noise filter to remove events with high HCAL noise, a tracking failure filter to remove events with too few [169]
tracks, ECAL filters to remove events with signals in dead and/or noisy modules of the ECAL and a beam [189]
scraping veto which requires tracks of high purity in events with high track multiplicity. [203]
[203]
\subsection{Electron selection} [2]
\label{electronplusjetschannelselection} [2]
The final selection in the electron+jets channel follows that recommended by the CMS TOP Physics Analysis [19]
Group (PAG). After having passed the electron trigger, events are further required to have an electron with an [37]
MVA electron identification of $>0.5$, with \Et$>30\GeV$ and $\abseta<2.5$ (excluding the transition region [50]
between the ECAL barrel and endcap of $1.4442<\abseta<1.5660$). A transverse impact parameter, the distance [64]
between the electron and the primary vertex, of $d_{xy}<0.02\cm$ is also required. In addition, a $\rho$ [80]
corrected (explained in Section~\ref{ss:pileup_subtraction}) relative isolation of~$<0.1$, within a cone of [92]
size $\Delta R=0.3$ is required and electrons that are matched to a photon conversion are rejected. [107]
A veto is placed on additional electrons with looser identification criteria than the signal requirements. [122]
These include an MVA identification of $>0.5$, \Et$>20\GeV$, $\abseta<2.5$ and a $\rho$ corrected relative [136]
isolation of $<0.15$. [139]
[139]
\subsection{Muon selection} [2]
\label{muonplusjetschannelselection} [2]
As in the electron channel, the final selection in the muon channel is taken from the CMS TOP PAG [21]
recommendations. In this case, the muon identification requirement comprises several cuts: at least five hits [36]
in the tracker and at least one hit in the muon chambers associated to the track, at least one layer of the [58]
muon chamber hits must be matched to a global muon (described in Section~\ref{ss:muon_reconstruction}), and [72]
the inner track must include at least one hit in the pixel sub detector. Furthermore, the normalised [89]
chi-squared of the track fit should be less than 10. In addition, the muon identification algorithms should [106]
identify the particle as a global, particle flow (PF) muon, the muon track should pass within a z-distance of [125]
$d_{z}<0.5\cm$ of the primary vertex and the transverse impact parameter is required to be $d_{xy}<0.2\cm$. [140]
The signal selection also requires that the muon has a $\pt>26\GeV$, $\abseta<2.1$ and a $\Delta\beta$ [155]
corrected (explained in Section~\ref{ss:pileup_subtraction}) relative isolation of~$<0.12$, within a cone of [167]
size $\Delta R=0.4$. Loose muons are vetoed, that satisfy the looser requirements of passing the particle [182]
flow identification, $\pt>10\GeV$, $\abseta<2.5$ and a $\Delta\beta$ corrected relative isolation of~$<0.2$. [194]
[194]
\subsection{Jets selection} [2]
\label{jets_selection} [2]
In addition to the signal lepton, all events must also have at least four particle flow jets as reconstructed [21]
using the anti-kt algorithm (see Section~\ref{ss:jet_reconstruction}) with a cone of $\Delta R=0.5$. These [33]
jets are also required to have \pt $>30\GeV$, $\abseta<2.5$, be at least $\Delta R=0.3$ from the signal [48]
electron or muon and satisfy the criteria for the loose particle flow jet identification. These criteria are [65]
outlined in Section~\ref{ss:jet_reconstruction}. Candidate particle flow jets from pileup are removed from the [78]
event; this is known as charged hadron subtraction. Events with at least four jets passing these criteria are [96]
permitted to have other lower energy jets passing the same requirements mentioned above, down to $\pt=20\GeV$. [112]
At least two of the four primary jets are further required to originate from b quarks (the process of [131]
identifying b jets is explained in Section~\ref{ss:b_tagging}.) [138]
[138]
\subsection{Multi-jet background selection} [3]
\label{ss:background_selection} [3]
The QCD background is difficult to model in simulation, therefore this background distribution is modelled [18]
from data. In the electron+jets channel, a control region comprised primarily of QCD events in the [35]
photon conversion region can be obtained by applying the full event selection with the exception of an [52]
inverted conversion veto, \ie the veto on electrons that are matched to a photon conversion is reversed such [69]
that events will only pass the selection if they are matched to a photon converison. The $\geq 2$ b tags [88]
requirement is also relaxed to select only events with 0 \btags to enrich the selection with QCD events. In [106]
order to evaluate a systematic uncertainty on the shape of this QCD background, an alternative control region is obtained by using the full signal selection but with the electron isolation requirement changed from [139]
$< 0.1$ to $> 0.2$. [142]
[142]
In the case of the muon+jets channel, the full selection is applied with the exception of the muon relative [162]
isolation requirement, which is switched from $< 0.12$ to $> 0.3$ and with the b tag requirement reduced to [179]
only events with 0 b tags in order to remove most other \ttbar background processes and produce a high purity [198]
QCD sample, as shown in Figure~\ref{fig:muon_qcd_isolation}. In order to increase statistics the jet [211]
multiplicity requirement is reduced to require at least three jets. [221]
[221]
Due to the low statistics of the QCD samples obtained from data, the inclusive QCD sample over all [239]
bins is used in every bin for each primary variable. The remaining contribution from \ttbar, [253]
single-top and \W/\ZpJets processes is subtracted from the data sample using the estimation from [266]
Monte Carlo simulation. The resulting template of QCD events from data is then used later in the fitting [284]
procedure, in place of the equivalent Monte Carlo template. [293]
[293]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [293]
    \centering [293]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/qcd_plots/QCD_muon_pfIsolation_0btag}\hfill [293]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/qcd_plots/QCD_muon_pfIsolation_0btag}\\ [293]
   \caption[PF relative isolation distributions in the muon+jets channel at $\roots=7\TeV$ and [293]
      $\roots=8\TeV$]{PF relative isolation distributions in the muon+jets channel, before subtraction of [293]
      \ttbar, single top and \VpJets at $\roots=7\TeV$ (left) and $\roots=8\TeV$ (right).} [293]
    \label{fig:muon_qcd_isolation} [293]
\end{figure} [293]
[293]
A comparison between data and simulation in the electron+jets QCD selections is shown in [308]
Figure~\ref{fig:data_mc_comparison_electron_QCD}. There is reasonably good agreement between the data and [318]
simulation in the conversion selection but low statistics in the simulation lead to some events with large [335]
weights, leading to peaks in the distribution. [342]
%It can also be seen that there are more conversion events in the regions of the endcaps, where the larger [342]
% amount of detector material for electrons to traverse leads to a higher number of conversions. [342]
The non-isolated QCD selection shows more discrepancies between the simulation [352]
and data, but it should be noted that at $\roots=7\TeV$ the simulation does not contain the triggers used in [371]
this analysis, unlike at $\roots=8\TeV$, therefore the simulation distribution at $\roots=7\TeV$ is not [384]
affected by the trigger isolation requirements. [390]
[390]
The true QCD background distribution is a mixture of the conversion and non-isolated distributions. A [405]
comparison of the two QCD background selections at $\roots=7\TeV$ and $\roots=8\TeV$ is also shown in the [421]
lower plots in Figure~\ref{fig:data_mc_comparison_electron_QCD}. Background events in which electrons come [431]
from jets misreconstructed as electrons or from \bquark or \cquark decays will pass the non-isolated [444]
selection, whereas conversion events in which the second electron is not rejected by the electron veto will [461]
pass the conversion selection. Another point to note is that, while the general shape of the conversion [478]
selection is expected to be the same in both signal and QCD background selections, the same may not be true of [499]
the non-isolated selection due to the isolation requirement in the signal selection. In addition, the number [515]
of events passing the QCD background selections will be very small compared to the number of events passing [533]
the signal selection, so the effect of even large uncertainties in the QCD background on the total number of [552]
events will be minimal. In the muon+jets channel, similarly, it is clear that the data and simulation are not [572]
in agreement and that there is a low amount of statistics available in simulation. [586]
[586]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [586]
    \centering [586]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/qcd_plots/QCD_electron_AbsEta_conversion_control_region_0btag_with_ratio}\hfill [586]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/qcd_plots/QCD_electron_AbsEta_conversion_control_region_0btag_with_ratio}\\ [586]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/qcd_plots/QCD_electron_AbsEta_non_iso_control_region_0btag_with_ratio}\hfill [586]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/qcd_plots/QCD_electron_AbsEta_non_iso_control_region_0btag_with_ratio}\\ [586]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/qcd_plots/shape_comparisons/QCD_electron_AbsEta_control_region_comparison_0btag}\hfill [586]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/qcd_plots/shape_comparisons/QCD_electron_AbsEta_control_region_comparison_0btag}\\ [586]
   \caption[Comparison of QCD selections in the electron+jets channel at $\roots=7\TeV$ and at [586]
    $\roots=8\TeV$.]{Comparison of QCD selections in the electron+jets channel at $\roots=7\TeV$ on the left [586]
    and at $\roots=8\TeV$ on the right. Conversion region is shown at the top, non-isolated selection in the [586]
    middle and a comparison of the two selections in data is shown in the lower plots.} [586]
    \label{fig:data_mc_comparison_electron_QCD} [586]
\end{figure} [586]
[586]
\section{Data-MC scale factors} [3]
\label{s:data_mc_scale_factors} [3]
There exist small but significant discrepancies between data and simulation distributions regarding pileup [16]
modelling; b tagging; trigger, identification and isolation efficiency; jet energy scale and jet energy [30]
resolution, and \met calculation. Scale factors and corrections are applied to both MC and data to account for [47]
these differences. The data-MC scale factors used are in accordance with the CMS TOP PAG, and the relevant [65]
corrections are implemented for 7\TeV and 8\TeV. [72]
[72]
\subsection{Pileup} [1]
\label{ss:pileup} [1]
Monte Carlo simulation events are produced by first creating the hard proton-proton interaction of interest in [17]
a proton bunch crossing, and then introducing the additional interactions, pileup, are added. The pileup [32]
distribution in simulation does not reflect the true distribution in data, therefore pileup reweighting is [47]
carried out. The instantaneous luminosity is used to estimate the number of pileup instances in an event at [65]
$\roots=7\TeV$ and $\roots=8\TeV$ using a tool provided by the CMS Physics Validation Group. For each number [81]
of pileup interactions in simulation, a weight is then produced to match the respective distribution in data. [98]
[98]
The estimation of the pileup distribution in data is obtained using the instantaneous luminosity measured in [114]
each proton bunch crossing, and the total inelastic proton-proton cross section. There is an uncertainty on [130]
the measured luminosity which is currently 2.6~\% for 2012 data \cite{CMS:2013gfa} and 2.2~\% for 2011 data [145]
\cite{CMS:2012eui}. The total inelastic cross section has been reported using CMS forward calorimetry [157]
\cite{Chatrchyan:2012gwa} and by the TOTEM collaboration \cite{Antchev:2011vs}. Based on these findings, the [167]
CMS recommended central values of 68\mb~ for $\roots=7$ and 69.3\mb~ for $\roots=8$ have been used, with a [184]
$\pm5~\%$ uncertainty to account for pileup and physics modelling in simulation. The distributions of the [199]
number of reconstructed vertices before and after applying pileup reweighting in the electron+jets channel [214]
is shown in Figure~\ref{fig:nvertices_before_and_after_pileup_reweighting_electrons}, and in the muon+jets [223]
channel is shown in Figure~\ref{fig:nvertices_before_and_after_pileup_reweighting_muons} in [229]
Appendix~\ref{as:data_monte_carlo_corrections}. [230]
The distributions show good agreement after reweighting. [237]
[237]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [237]
    \centering [237]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/EPlusJets_nVertex_with_ratio}\hfill [237]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/EPlusJets_nVertex_reweighted_with_ratio}\\ [237]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/EPlusJets_nVertex_with_ratio}\hfill [237]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/EPlusJets_nVertex_reweighted_with_ratio}\\ [237]
   \caption[Distributions of the number of reconstructed vertices in an event in the electron+jets channel [237]
    before and after implementing pileup reweighting at $\roots=7\TeV$ and $\roots=8\TeV$.]{Distributions of [237]
    the number of reconstructed vertices in an event in the electron+jets channel before implementing pileup [237]
    reweighting (left) and after implementation (right) at $\roots=7\TeV$ (upper) and $\roots=8\TeV$ (lower). [237]
    Both data and sum of MC simulations are normalisated to one.} [237]
    \label{fig:nvertices_before_and_after_pileup_reweighting_electrons} [237]
\end{figure} [237]
[237]
\subsection{\btagging} [0]
\label{ss:b_tagging} [0]
The combined secondary vertex \btagging algorithm (CSV) described in Section~\ref{sss:b_jets} is used in this [13]
analysis to identify jets originating from \bquarks in \ttbar events. The medium working point, CSVM, which [27]
corresponds to a cut on the discriminator output by the algorithm of 0.679, is used in this analysis. This [46]
corresponds to a \btagging efficiency of $\approx$70~\% and a mis-tag efficiency of 1~\% for jets from light [63]
quarks ($\cPqu$, $\cPqd$, $\cPqs$) and gluons. Discrepancies between the \btagging efficiency in data and [76]
Monte Carlo simulation have been noted in $\roots=7\TeV$~\cite{Chatrchyan:2012jua} and [85]
$\roots=8\TeV$~\cite{CMS-PAS-BTV-13-001}. To account for these differences, events are reweighted based on the [97]
recommendation of the CMS \btagging Physics Object Group (POG), with the aim of ensuring that the probability [113]
of an event passing selection criteria in simulation matches the probability of an event in data with the same [132]
jet(s) passing the same selection. The result of this reweighting in the electron+jets channel is shown in [151]
Figure~\ref{fig:nbjets_before_and_after_btag_scale_factors_electrons}, and in the muon+jets channel in [159]
Figure~\ref{fig:nbjets_before_and_after_btag_scale_factors_muons} in [161]
Appendix~\ref{as:data_monte_carlo_corrections}. The \btagging efficiency uncertainty is evaluated by varying [169]
the scale factors by $\pm1\sigma$. [174]
[174]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [174]
    \centering [174]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/EPlusJets_N_BJets_with_ratio}\hfill [174]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/EPlusJets_N_BJets_reweighted_with_ratio}\\ [174]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/EPlusJets_N_BJets_with_ratio}\hfill [174]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/EPlusJets_N_BJets_reweighted_with_ratio}\\ [174]
   \caption[Distributions of the number of \btags in an event in the electron+jets channel before [174]
    and after applying \btag scale factors at $\roots=7\TeV$ and $\roots=8\TeV$.]{Distributions of [174]
    the number of \btags in an event in the electron+jets channel before applying \btag scale factors (left) [174]
    and after application (right) at $\roots=7\TeV$ (upper) and $\roots=8\TeV$ (lower).} [174]
    \label{fig:nbjets_before_and_after_btag_scale_factors_electrons} [174]
\end{figure} [174]
[174]
%At bins of lower multiplicity, there is a clear excess in the data distribution over the simulation, but [174]
% since only the $\geq2$ \btags region is used for the signal region, this disagreement in low bins is not of [174]
% importance. [174]
%TODO: mention also not important because of fitting? [174]
[174]
\subsection{Jet Energy Scale} [3]
\label{sss:jet_energy_scale} [3]
Jet energies are corrected to take into account energy coming from other sources. Level 1 (L1 Pileup) [20]
corrections remove energy that comes from pileup collisions, Level 2 (L2 Relative) corrections remove the [35]
dependence of jet response on $\eta$, and Level 3 (L3 Absolute) corrections correct for the jet response [52]
dependence on \pt~\cite{Chatrchyan:2011ds}. These corrections are applied to both data and Monte Carlo [64]
simulation events. An additional residual correction (L2L3Residual) is applied to data only for fine tuning of [80]
the agreement between data and simulation. [86]
[86]
Furthermore, jet energy resolution corrections are applied to simulation (known as jet smearing) to account [101]
for the fact that jet energy resolution has been measured to be worse in data than in simulation. These PF jet corrections [123]
are provided by the CMS JETMET Physics Object Group using 0.8\fbinv of dijet data at [138]
$\roots=7\TeV$~\cite{Chatrchyan:2011ds} and 19.7\fbinv of dijet data at $\roots=8\TeV$~\cite{jet_res_2012}. [146]
[146]
\subsection{Missing Transverse Energy Corrections} [4]
\label{ss:met_corrections} [4]
The adjustments to the jet energies as a result of the corrections mentioned in [18]
Section~\ref{sss:jet_energy_scale} in turn affect the distributions of \met and \met $\phi$ in the event. [30]
Corrections known as Type-I \met corrections are applied to propagate these changes to the \met distributions. [44]
In addition, Type-0 corrections are applied to account for pileup interactions in the event, and \met $\phi$ [60]
corrections are applied to mitigate a known modulation of the \met distribution with respect to $\phi$. [75]
[75]
\subsection{Trigger, Lepton ID and Isolation Efficiencies and Corrections} [8]
\label{ss:trigger_ID_isolation_corrections} [8]
Corrections are also required for the trigger, identification and isolation efficiencies for muons and [22]
electrons. In the muon+jets channel, the corrections were provided by the CMS muon Physics Object Group [39]
for $\roots=8\TeV$ %TODO:FINDREF (ONLY A TWIKI, WOULD THIS BE OK?) [41]
and $\roots=7\TeV$~\cite{CMS-PAS-SMP-13-013}. [43]
[43]
For the electron+jets channel, the corrections were provided by the CMS EGamma Physics Object Group for [60]
$\roots=8\TeV$, %TODO:FINDREF (ONLY A TWIKI, WOULD THIS BE OK?) [61]
however the corrections for the $\roots=7\TeV$ data were not provided and so were derived independently in [77]
this analysis using the same tag and probe methods as used by the EGamma POG. [92]
[92]
The 7\TeV triggers used (ElectronHad) in this analysis were not present in the 7\TeV simulation, [107]
and so the trigger efficiency was calculated with respect to the full selection. This efficiency was then [124]
implemented in the Monte Carlo simulation, thereby imitating the trigger. It should be noted that it is [141]
assumed that the electron and hadron legs of the trigger are not correlated, since electrons are cleaned from [159]
the jet collection at HLT level. [165]
[165]
A tag and probe method~\cite{CMS:2011aa} was used to derive identification, isolation scale factors and [179]
electron trigger efficiencies. The full reference selection was first applied with the exception of trigger, [194]
\btagging and electron veto requirements, while in addition, a second loose electron was required. A \Z mass [209]
constraint was placed on the two electrons in the event by requiring them to have an invariant mass of between [229]
60\GeV and 120\GeV, thus ensuring that the pair of electrons originated from a \Z boson decay. The tight [246]
('tag') electron requirements were \pt$>30\GeV$, \abseta$<0.8$, relative isolation~$<0.1$, MVA [256]
identification$>0.9$, $d_{xy}<0.02\cm$ and reconstructed at HLT level. The loose ('probe') electron [268]
requirements were \pt$>30\GeV$, \abseta$<2.5$ and $d_{xy}<2\cm$. [274]
[274]
Fits were then performed, firstly of the invariant mass of all pairs of tag and probe electrons, and secondly [293]
after applying the identification and isolation criteria to the probe electrons, to the invariant mass [308]
distribution of pairs of tag and probe electrons in which the probe electron passed the identification and [325]
isolation criteria. The fit was implemented in both Monte Carlo simulation and in data, and a Breit-Wigner [342]
distribution convoluted with a Crystal Ball function is used to model the invariant mass of the tag and probe [361]
electrons, with a falling exponential used to model the background distribution. The Breit-Wigner distribution [375]
takes a form similar to that of a Gaussian distribution, with flatter tails~\cite{PhysRev.49.519}. The Crystal [390]
Ball function is also based on a Gaussian distribution, but with a power-law tail to the lower end [408]
~\cite{Oreglia,Gaiser,Skwarnicki}. Both of these functions are commonly used to model the mass peaks of [421]
resonances. The result of this fitting procedure in data can be seen in [434]
Figure~\ref{fig:electron_id_iso_efficiency_invariant_Z_mass_fits_data}. [435]
[435]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [435]
    \centering [435]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/lepton_scale_factors/CBConvolution/electron/data/id_iso/tagProbe_total_Z_peak}\hfill [435]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/lepton_scale_factors/CBConvolution/electron/data/id_iso/tagProbe_passed_Z_peak}\\ [435]
   \caption[Fits of the invariant mass distribution of all tag-and-probe pairs and tag-and-probe pairs in     which the probe satisfies the identification and isolation criteria.]{Fits of the invariant mass [440]
    distribution of all tag-and-probe pairs (left) and tag-and-probe pairs in which the probe satisfies [454]
    the identification and isolation criteria (right).} [460]
   \label{fig:electron_id_iso_efficiency_invariant_Z_mass_fits_data} [460]
\end{figure} [460]
[460]
The efficiency of the identification and isolation process is then calculated using the numbers extracted [475]
from the fits, in bins of \pt and $\eta$ of the probe electron, as follows: [489]
[489]
\begin{equation} [490]
\epsilon(\text{identification and isolation}) = \frac{N^{\text{fit}}_{\text{probe, passing}}}{N^{\text{fit}}_{\text{probe, all}}} [490]
\end{equation} [490]
where $N^{\text{fit}}_{\text{probe, all}}$ is the total number of events with tag and probe electrons and [504]
$N^{\text{fit}}$ is the subset in which the probe passes identification and isolation criteria. [517]
[517]
The scale factor is then calculated as the ratio between the efficiencies in simulation and in data. The [535]
efficiencies in both can be seen to be similar in Figure~\ref{fig:electron_id_iso_efficiencies_wrt_eta_pt}, [546]
leading to scale factors close to one. [553]
[553]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [553]
    \centering [553]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/lepton_scale_factors/CBConvolution/electron/efficiency_eta_id_iso}\hfill [553]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/lepton_scale_factors/CBConvolution/electron/efficiency_pt_id_iso} [553]
      \caption[Identification and isolation efficiencies as a function of $\eta$ and \pt in data and \ttbar [553]
   Monte Carlo simulation.]{Identification and isolation efficiencies as a function of $\eta$ and \pt in data and \ttbar [553]
   Monte Carlo simulation.} [553]
    \label{fig:electron_id_iso_efficiencies_wrt_eta_pt} [553]
\end{figure} [553]
[553]
The efficiency of the electron part of the trigger is then similarly calculated, with respect to the [570]
identification and isolation requirements, meaning the events passing the identification and isolation [582]
requirements in the previous stage are then used as the baseline for the trigger efficiency. The subset of [600]
these in which the probe electron matches a HLT electron is then used to calculate the efficiency as follows: [619]
[619]
\begin{equation} [620]
\epsilon(\text{trigger}) = \frac{N^{\text{fit}}_{\text{probe, matching HLT}}}{N^{\text{fit}}_{\text{probe,identification and isolation}}} [620]
\label{eq:electron_leg_efficiency} [620]
\end{equation} [620]
where $N^{\text{fit}}_{\text{probe,identification and isolation}}$ is the number of [626]
events passing from equation~\ref{eq:electron_leg_efficiency} and $N^{\text{fit}}_{\text{probe, matching [632]
HLT}}$ is the subset in which the probe is matched to an HLT electron object. [646]
[646]
In order to calculate the efficiency of the hadron leg of the trigger, the full selection with only the [665]
electron part of the trigger and without \btagging, applied to the SingleElectron dataset, is taken as the [681]
baseline. The number of these events passing the hadronic leg of the trigger is then used to calculate the [700]
hadronic leg efficiency as follows: [705]
[705]
\begin{equation} [706]
\epsilon(\text{hadron leg}) = \frac{N_{\text{hadron leg, passing}}}{N_{\text{passing selection}}} [706]
\end{equation} [706]
where $N_{\text{passing selection}}$ is the number of events passing the baseline selection with [718]
the electron leg of the trigger and no \btagging requirements, and $N_{\text{hadron leg, passing}}$ is the [731]
subset in which the hadron leg of the trigger is satisfied. [742]
[742]
The scale factors are produced in bins of \pt and $\eta$ of the fourth most energetic jet, since this is the [762]
lowest energy jet that is selected. Parametrising as a function of higher energy jets would lead to a bias [781]
towards high efficiencies as the trigger will have a higher efficiency at higher jet energies. [796]
[796]
Equivalent fit and efficiency plots for the trigger are included in [807]
Figures~\ref{fig:electron_trigger_efficiency_invariant_Z_mass_fits} and [809]
\ref{fig:electron_trigger_efficiencies_wrt_eta_pt} in Appendix~\ref{as:data_monte_carlo_corrections}. [811]
% TODO:HAVE NOT INCLUDED MUON ID-ISO OR TRIGGER PLOTS ANYWHERE, ASSUMING OK WITH JUST ELECTRON PLOTS. [811]

File: Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/04b_DifferentialTTbarCrossSections_2.tex

\chapter{Differential Cross Sections: Fitting, Unfolding and Measurement} [7]
\label{c:Differential_Cross_Section:fitting_unfolding_and_measurement} [7]
[7]
% \section{Introduction} [7]
% \label:{s:analysis2_introduction} [7]
% Following event selection it is important to perform a comparison of simulation to data to verify that the [7]
% processes modelled as backgrounds [7]
[7]
\section{Data-MC Comparison} [2]
\label{ss:data-mc_comparison} [2]
Following the full event selection, the simulated events are scaled to match the luminosity of the data using [20]
the scale factor: [23]
\begin{equation} [24]
  S = \frac{{\cal L} \times \sigma}{N_{\rm processed}} [24]
\end{equation} [24]
where $N_{\rm processed}$ is the total number of events processed for each Monte Carlo sample and $\sigma$ is [41]
the production cross section of each process. The numbers of events passing each selection step in data and [59]
in Monte Carlo simulation, after scaling to the measured luminosity, are shown for both the electron+jets and [77]
muon+jets channels in Table~\ref{tab:cut_flow_7TeV} at $\roots=7\TeV$, and in Table~\ref{tab:cut_flow_8TeV} [87]
at $\roots=8\TeV$. [89]
[89]
\input{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/tables/cutflow/cut_flow_7TeV} [89]
\input{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/tables/cutflow/cut_flow_8TeV} [89]
[89]
The distributions of the primary variables \met, \HT, \st, \wpt and \mt after the full selection requirements [101]
are applied, are shown in Figures~\ref{fig:data_mc_comparison_7TeV_electron} and [108]
\ref{fig:data_mc_comparison_7TeV_muon} for the electron and muon channels respectively at $\roots=7\TeV$; and [118]
in Figures~\ref{fig:data_mc_comparison_8TeV_electron} and \ref{fig:data_mc_comparison_8TeV_muon} respectively [122]
at $\roots=8\TeV$. The normalisations and shapes are all obtained from simulation except in the case of QCD [139]
which is taken from data: the conversion region is used in the electron channel and the non-isolated region is [158]
used in the muon channel. In general there is good agreement between data and simulation. The distributions in [176]
simulation peak at slightly higher energies because event reweighting to account for the \pt mismodelling of [191]
the top quark in simulation (see Section~\ref{ss:theoretical_uncertainties}) has not yet been carried out at [205]
this stage. [207]
[207]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [207]
    \centering [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/EPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\hfill [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/EPlusJets_HT_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\\ [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/EPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_ST_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\hfill [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/EPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_WPT_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\\ [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/EPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_MT_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\hfill [207]
   \caption[Comparison of Monte Carlo simulation to data in the electron+jets channel after final [207]
    selection at $\roots=7\TeV$.]{Comparison of Monte Carlo simulation to data in the electron+jets channel [207]
    after final selection at $\roots=7\TeV$ for \met (upper left), \HT (upper right), \st (middle left), \wpt (middle [207]
    right) and \mt (lower). The shaded region represents the \ttbar MC normalisation uncertainty. The lower [207]
    plots show the ratio of the sum of simulated events to the data.} [207]
    \label{fig:data_mc_comparison_7TeV_electron} [207]
\end{figure} [207]
[207]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [207]
    \centering [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/MuPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\hfill [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/MuPlusJets_HT_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\\ [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/MuPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_ST_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\hfill [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/MuPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_WPT_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\\ [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/7TeV/MuPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_MT_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\hfill [207]
   \caption[Comparison of Monte Carlo simulation to data in the muon+jets channel after final [207]
    selection at $\roots=7\TeV$.]{Comparison of Monte Carlo simulation to data in the muon+jets channel after [207]
    final selection at $\roots=7\TeV$ for \met (upper left), \HT (upper right), \st (middle left), \wpt (middle [207]
    right) and \mt (lower). The shaded region represents the \ttbar MC normalisation uncertainty. The lower [207]
    plots show the ratio of the sum of simulated events to the data.}    [207]
    \label{fig:data_mc_comparison_7TeV_muon} [207]
\end{figure} [207]
[207]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [207]
    \centering [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/EPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\hfill [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/EPlusJets_HT_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\\ [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/EPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_ST_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\hfill [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/EPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_WPT_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\\ [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/EPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_MT_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\hfill [207]
   \caption[Comparison of Monte Carlo simulation to data in the electron+jets channel after final [207]
    selection at $\roots=8\TeV$.]{Comparison of Monte Carlo simulation to data in the electron+jets channel [207]
    after final selection at $\roots=8\TeV$ for \met (upper left), \HT (upper right), \st (middle left), \wpt (middle [207]
    right) and \mt (lower). The shaded region represents the \ttbar MC normalisation uncertainty. The lower [207]
    plots show the ratio of the sum of simulated events to the data.} [207]
    \label{fig:data_mc_comparison_8TeV_electron} [207]
\end{figure} [207]
[207]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [207]
    \centering [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/MuPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\hfill [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/MuPlusJets_HT_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\\ [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/MuPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_ST_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\hfill [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/MuPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_WPT_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\\ [207]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/before_fit/8TeV/MuPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_MT_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\hfill [207]
   \caption[Comparison of Monte Carlo simulation to data in the muon+jets channel after final [207]
    selection at $\roots=8\TeV$.]{Comparison of Monte Carlo simulation to data in the muon+jets channel after [207]
    final selection at $\roots=8\TeV$ for \met (upper left), \HT (upper right), \st (middle left), \wpt (middle [207]
    right) and \mt (lower). The shaded region represents the \ttbar MC normalisation uncertainty. The lower [207]
    plots show the ratio of the sum of simulated events to the data.} [207]
    \label{fig:data_mc_comparison_8TeV_muon} [207]
\end{figure} [207]
[207]
[207]
\section{Binning Choice} [2]
\label{s:binning_choice} [2]
The different cross sections in this analysis are measured in bins of the primary variable distributions. The [19]
choice of bin sizes and boundaries are significant because events generated in one bin can migrate to another [37]
bin after reconstrution due to the finite resolution of the detector. This altering of the number of events, [55]
as a result of events moving into, or out of, a bin is important to understand so that the final reconstructed [76]
distribution can be deconvoluted (unfolded) to the true distribution. In light of this, the binning choice is [93]
made based on two variables defined as purity ($p^k$) and stability ($s^k$): [105]
\begin{align} [106]
\label{eq:purity_and_stability} [106]
p^k = \frac{N_{\rec\&\gen}^k}{N_{\rec}^k}\\ [106]
s^k = \frac{N_{\rec\&\gen}^k}{N_{\gen}^k}. [106]
\end{align} [106]
$N_{\rec\&\gen}^k$ is the number of events generated and reconstructed in bin $k$, [118]
$N_{\rec}^k$ is the number of events reconstructed in bin $k$ and $N_{\gen}^k$ is the number of events [135]
generated in bin $k$. The stability of a bin is sensitive to the migration of events out of a bin, while [156]
the purity is sensitive to the migration of events into a bin (see Figure~\ref{fig:purity_and_stability}). [170]
[170]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [170]
\centering [170]
   \includegraphics[width=0.8\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/purity_and_stability.pdf} [170]
    \caption[Graphical representation of bin purity and stability.]{Stability quantifies the migration of [175]
    events out of a bin while purity quantifies the migration of events into a bin. Both quantities compare [193]
    the bin in which an event is generated to the range in which they are reconstructed.} [209]
   \label{fig:purity_and_stability} [209]
\end{figure} [209]
[209]
In this analysis, the bins for each primary variable distribution were chosen such that all bins have purity [227]
and stability values of 0.5 or greater, meaning that at least half of the events generated in a bin remain in [248]
that bin after reconstruction, and that at least half of the events reconstructed in a bin were generated in [267]
that bin. In order to avoid very small bins with a large relative statistical error, a requirement that all [286]
bins have at least 100 events is also enforced. [295]
[295]
The determination of the bin boundaries following these criteria is carried out simultaneously in (and [310]
therefore the binning is identical in) both centre of mass energies and both the electron+jets and [327]
muon+jets channel. [330]
[330]
Plots of generated versus reconstructed events in simulation for all primary variables are shown in the [346]
electron+jets channel in Figure~\ref{fig:binning_7TeV_electron} for $\roots=7\TeV$ and in [355]
Figure~\ref{fig:binning_8TeV_electron} for $\roots=8\TeV$. The corresponding plots in the muon+jets channel [366]
are shown in Figures~\ref{fig:binning_7TeV_muon} and \ref{fig:binning_8TeV_muon} in [372]
Appendix~\ref{as:binning_muon}. %The purity and stability values of the chosen bins are shown in [373]
%Appendix~\ref{as:binning_tables_electron}. [373]
[373]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [373]
\centering [373]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/binning/electron_MET_7TeV.pdf}\hfill [373]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/binning/electron_HT_7TeV.pdf}\\ [373]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/binning/electron_ST_7TeV.pdf}\hfill [373]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/binning/electron_MT_7TeV.pdf}\\ [373]
\includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/binning/electron_WPT_7TeV.pdf}\hfill [373]
\caption[Generated versus reconstructed distributions of the primary variable at $\roots=7\TeV$.]{Generated [373]
  versus reconstructed distributions of the primary variables \met (upper left), \HT (upper right), \st (middle [373]
  left), \mt (middle right) and \wpt (lower) with horizontal and vertical lines representing the boundaries of [373]
  the selected bins at $\roots=7\TeV$ in the electron+ jets channel. These distributions are obtained using [373]
  \ttbar simulation.} [373]
    \label{fig:binning_7TeV_electron} [373]
\end{figure} [373]
[373]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [373]
    \centering [373]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/binning/electron_MET_8TeV.pdf}\hfill [373]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/binning/electron_HT_8TeV.pdf}\\ [373]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/binning/electron_ST_8TeV.pdf}\hfill [373]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/binning/electron_MT_8TeV.pdf}\\ [373]
\includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/binning/electron_WPT_8TeV.pdf}\hfill [373]
\caption[Generated versus reconstructed distributions of the primary variables at $\roots=8\TeV$.]{Generated [373]
  versus reconstructed distributions of the primary variables \met (upper left), \HT (upper right), \st [373]
(middle left), \mt (middle right) and \wpt (lower) with horizontal and vertical lines representing the [373]
  boundaries of the selected bins at $\roots=8\TeV$ in the electron+ jets channel. These distributions are [373]
  obtained using \ttbar simulation.} [373]
    \label{fig:binning_8TeV_electron} [373]
\end{figure} [373]
\FloatBarrier [373]
[373]
\section{Maximum Likelihood Fit} [3]
\label{s:maximum_likelihood_fit} [3]
A maximum log likelihood fit of four templates to data in each bin of the primary variables is used to obtain [24]
the number of events from each process in each bin. Three fitting variables are used because no individual [42]
variable is able to distinguish between all four templates used in the fit: [55]
\onehalfspacing [56]
\begin{itemize} [56]
  \item {\ttbar} [56]
  \item{single-top} [57]
  \item{V+jets (W+jets + Z+jets)} [63]
  \item{QCD multi-jet} [65]
\end{itemize} [65]
\doublespacing [65]
The template distributions are obtained from the following three variables: the absolute pseudorapidity of the [80]
lepton (\abseta), the three-dimensional angle between the lepton and the nearest \bjet ($\alpha$), and the [93]
invariant mass of the three jets with the highest \pt sum ($M3$). [104]
[104]
The fit is carried out by maximising the log of the likelihood function (LL): [118]
[118]
\begin{equation} [119]
\label{log_likelihood} [119]
LL\left(x_i, d_i\right) = -2 \log{\prod\limits_{i}\frac{x_i^{d_i}\cdot [119]
e^{-x_i}}{d_i!}}=-2\sum\limits_{i}\log{\left(\frac{x_i^{d_i}\cdot e^{-x_i}}{d_i!}\right)}. [119]
\end{equation} [119]
[119]
where $i$ is the bin index in the template, $x_i$ is the total of all the templates in bin $i$, and $d_i$ is [142]
the observed number of data events in  bin $i$. $x_i$ is defined to be [156]
[156]
\begin{equation} [157]
\label{eq:sum_mc} [157]
x_i = \sum\limits_{j}N_{j}x_{i\,j},\;\text{with}\;\sum\limits_{i}x_{i\,j}=1\ \text{for each process}. [157]
\end{equation} [157]
[157]
where $x_{i\,j}$ represents the templates and $N_{j}$ represents the normalisations of the templates \ie the [171]
fit parameters. Fitting using more than one variable (the three aforementioned fitting variables), the [185]
log likelihoods are summed: [189]
\begin{equation} [190]
\label{eq:log_L_final} [190]
LL\left(x, d\right) = -\frac{2}{n} \sum\limits_{k=1,n} \log{L_k} [190]
\end{equation} [190]
[190]
where $L_k$ is the likelihood function of each of the different fit variables. Here the division by $n$ [208]
accounts for the fact that the same information is used in all three fit variables, and so full correlation is [228]
assumed between the three fitting variables, which provides a conservative estimate of the uncertainties in [243]
the resulting fitted parameters. The fit operates by adjusting the normalisation of each template with the aim [260]
of equating $x_{i}$ and $d_{i}$ in each bin of each template. The starting normalisations in the templates are [278]
obtained from simulation after the full selection has been applied (this includes the QCD template, although [294]
the shape for this is obtained from data). [302]
[302]
\subsection{Choice of templates} [3]
\label{choice_of_templates} [3]
[3]
\ttbar, single-top and V+jets templates are taken from simulation, while the QCD template is extracted from [19]
data as described in Section~\ref{ss:background_selection}. The W+jets and Z+jets templates are combined [33]
firstly due to the similar shapes of the distributions in these two background processes, and secondly due to [51]
limited statistics available in simulation. The four template shapes in each of the three fitting variables at [68]
$\roots=7\TeV$ in both channels are shown in Figure~\ref{fig:fit_variable_distributions_7TeV}. The [77]
corresponding plots for $\roots=8\TeV$ are shown in Appendix~\ref{as:fitting_variables_distributions}. [85]
[85]
This combination of fitting variables was selected because they are only weakly correlated to the primary [101]
variables under investigation, and they show good discrimination between the four templates. [113]
Single top events have similar signatures to \ttbar events, with a central lepton from the decay of the single [131]
top, leading to a single top template that is similar to the \ttbar template in the electron \abseta and muon [149]
\abseta distributions. In the $\alpha$ distribution, the similarity is attributable to the fact that the [163]
closest \bjet from the lepton is generally a \bjet from the decay of a \tquark. However, the average boost for [180]
single top events is lower than in \ttbar events, leading to a wider single top template. [195]
The M3 variable will be a combination of the jets from the hadronically decaying \tquark (a \bjet and two [212]
other jets from the \W-boson, which may include a second \bjet) in \ttbar events, whereas in the other [228]
templates, M3 will simply correspond to some random combination of jets in the event. Hence, M3 shows the best discrimination between the single top [252]
and \ttbar templates. [254]
[254]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [254]
    \centering [254]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/7TeV/fit_variables/electron/MET/electron_absolute_eta/MET_inclusive_electron_absolute_eta_2orMoreBtags_templates.pdf}\hfill [254]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/7TeV/fit_variables/muon/MET/muon_absolute_eta/MET_inclusive_muon_absolute_eta_2orMoreBtags_templates.pdf}\\ [254]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/7TeV/fit_variables/electron/MET/angle_bl/MET_inclusive_angle_bl_2orMoreBtags_templates.pdf}\hfill [254]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/7TeV/fit_variables/muon/MET/angle_bl/MET_inclusive_angle_bl_2orMoreBtags_templates.pdf}\\ [254]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/7TeV/fit_variables/electron/MET/M3/MET_inclusive_M3_2orMoreBtags_templates.pdf}\hfill [254]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/7TeV/fit_variables/muon/MET/M3/MET_inclusive_M3_2orMoreBtags_templates.pdf}\\ [254]
\caption[Normalised distributions of the templates for the three fit variables, inclusive across all primary [254]
  variable bins at $\roots=7\TeV$.]{Normalised distributions of the templates for the three fit variables [254]
  lepton \abseta (upper), $\alpha$ (middle) and M3 (lower) inclusive across all primary variable bins at [254]
  $\roots=7\TeV$ in the electron+jets channel (left) and in the muon+jets channel (right).} [254]
    \label{fig:fit_variable_distributions_7TeV} [254]
\end{figure} [254]
[254]
\FloatBarrier [254]
[254]
The QCD templates, in particular those in higher bins of the primary variables, contain lower statistics than [271]
those in lower bins. Therefore, the inclusive QCD template shape, \ie the QCD distribution over all bins, is [288]
used for the fitting process in every bin. Figure~\ref{fig:fit_variable_qcd_comparisons_8TeV} shows a [299]
comparison between QCD templates at $\roots=8\TeV$ in the lowest three bins of the \met variable and also the [316]
inclusive \met QCD template. It can be seen that the third \met bin already shows large statistical errors due [333]
to low numbers of events, and that the inclusive template is largely shaped by events in the first two bins. [353]
Therefore, the inclusive QCD template is used rather than those in individual bins. %Similar plots showing the [366]
%same behaviour for the other primary variables at $\roots=8\TeV$ are shown in [366]
%Appendix~\ref{as:fitting_variable_QCD_template_comparisons}. [366]
[366]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [366]
    \centering [366]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/8TeV/fit_variables/electron/MET/electron_absolute_eta/qcd/MET_electron_absolute_eta_0orMoreBtag_QCD_template_comparison.pdf}\hfill [366]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/8TeV/fit_variables/muon/MET/muon_absolute_eta/qcd/MET_muon_absolute_eta_0orMoreBtag_QCD_template_comparison.pdf}\\ [366]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/8TeV/fit_variables/electron/MET/angle_bl/qcd/MET_angle_bl_1orMoreBtag_QCD_template_comparison.pdf}\hfill [366]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/8TeV/fit_variables/muon/MET/angle_bl/qcd/MET_angle_bl_1orMoreBtag_QCD_template_comparison.pdf}\\ [366]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/8TeV/fit_variables/electron/MET/M3/qcd/MET_M3_0orMoreBtag_QCD_template_comparison.pdf}\hfill [366]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/8TeV/fit_variables/muon/MET/M3/qcd/MET_M3_0orMoreBtag_QCD_template_comparison.pdf}\\ [366]
\caption[Normalised distributions of the QCD templates for the three fit variables in \met bins [366]
  at $\roots=8\TeV$.]{Normalised distributions of the QCD templates for the three fit variables lepton \abseta [366]
(upper), $\alpha$ (middle) and M3 (lower) inclusive across all \met bins and for the lowest three \met bins [366]
  at $\roots=8\TeV$ in the electron+jets channel (left) and in the muon+jets channel (right).} [366]
    \label{fig:fit_variable_qcd_comparisons_8TeV} [366]
\end{figure} [366]
[366]
An inclusive template is also used in the V+jets (W+jets + Z+jets) template for the same reason. [385]
Figure~\ref{fig:MET_fit_variable_vjets_comparisons_8TeV} shows a comparison between the V+jets templates at [395]
$\roots=8\TeV$ in each \met bin and also the inclusive \met V+jets template. [406]
As is the case for the QCD background template, it can be seen in the V+jets templates that there are [427]
diminished statistics available in higher bins, and the inclusive template shape is largely governed by the [443]
lower bins. %Similar plots demonstrating the same behaviour for the other primary variables at $\roots=8\TeV$ [445]
%are shown in Appendix~\ref{as:fitting_variable_vjets_template_comparisons}. [445]
[445]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [445]
    \centering [445]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/8TeV/fit_variables/electron/MET/electron_absolute_eta/vjets/MET_electron_absolute_eta_2orMoreBtags_VJets_template_comparison.pdf}\hfill [445]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/8TeV/fit_variables/muon/MET/muon_absolute_eta/vjets/MET_muon_absolute_eta_2orMoreBtags_VJets_template_comparison.pdf}\\ [445]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/8TeV/fit_variables/electron/MET/angle_bl/vjets/MET_angle_bl_2orMoreBtags_VJets_template_comparison.pdf}\hfill [445]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/8TeV/fit_variables/muon/MET/angle_bl/vjets/MET_angle_bl_2orMoreBtags_VJets_template_comparison.pdf}\\ [445]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/8TeV/fit_variables/electron/MET/M3/vjets/MET_M3_2orMoreBtags_VJets_template_comparison.pdf}\hfill [445]
   \includegraphics[width=0.45\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/8TeV/fit_variables/muon/MET/M3/vjets/MET_M3_2orMoreBtags_VJets_template_comparison.pdf}\\ [445]
\caption[Normalised distributions of the V+jets templates for the three fit variables in \met [445]
bins.]{Normalised distributions of the V+jets templates for the three fit variables lepton \abseta (upper), [445]
  $\alpha$ (middle) and M3 (lower) inclusive across all \met bins and for the lowest three \met bins at [445]
  $\roots=8\TeV$ in the electron+jets channel (left) and in the muon+jets channel (right).} [445]
    \label{fig:MET_fit_variable_vjets_comparisons_8TeV} [445]
\end{figure} [445]
[445]
\FloatBarrier [445]
%TODO: Fit Template Plots? [445]
[445]
\subsection{Fit Results} [2]
\label{ss:fit_results} [2]
The results from the fit are shown in Figures~\ref{fig:data_mc_comparison_after_fit_7TeV_electron} and [12]
\ref{fig:data_mc_comparison_after_fit_7TeV_muon} for the electron and muon channels respectively at [20]
$\roots=7\TeV$, and in Figures~\ref{fig:data_mc_comparison_after_fit_8TeV_electron} and [25]
\ref{fig:data_mc_comparison_after_fit_8TeV_muon} for the electron and muon channels at $\roots=8\TeV$. The [34]
corresponding numerical values from the fit can be found in Appendix~\ref{as:fit_results_tables}. Overall, [46]
there is broad agreement between the data and the simulation within fit uncertainties. [59]
[59]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [59]
    \centering [59]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/control_plots/after_fit/7TeV/EPlusJets_patType1CorrectedPFMet_2orMoreBtags_with_ratio.pdf}\hfill [59]

[59]
\section{Fit cross-checks} [2]
\label{s:fit_cross_section} [2]
The correlations between the fitted processes, $N_{\ttbar}$, $N_{\mathrm{singletop}}$, $N_{\VpJets}$ and [12]
$N_{\mathrm{QCD}}$, for the \met variable in the electron+jets channel at $\roots=8\TeV$ are shown in [26]
Figure~\ref{fig:correlation_plots_8TeV_electron}. The equivalent plots for $\roots=7\TeV$ are shown in [35]
Figure~\ref{fig:correlation_plots_7TeV_electron} in Appendix~\ref{as:fit_correlations}. It can be seen that [43]
the correlation between signal and QCD remains very low for all \met bins. The \VpJets template is negatively [59]
correlated with the QCD template in low bins, whereas this is not seen in higher bins due to these bins [79]
containing very few QCD events. [84]
[84]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [84]
    \centering [84]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/fitchecks/8TeV/Correlations_electron_MET_0-27.pdf}\hfill [84]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/fitchecks/8TeV/Correlations_electron_MET_27-52.pdf}\\ [84]
\includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/fitchecks/8TeV/Correlations_electron_MET_52-87.pdf}\hfill [84]
\includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/fitchecks/8TeV/Correlations_electron_MET_87-130.pdf}\\ [84]
\includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/fitchecks/8TeV/Correlations_electron_MET_130-172.pdf}\hfill [84]
\includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/fitchecks/8TeV/Correlations_electron_MET_172-inf.pdf}\\ [84]
\caption[Correlation between fit processes for the \met variable in the electron+jets channel at [84]
  $\roots=8\TeV$.]{Correlation between fit processes for the \met variable in the electron+jets channel at [84]
  $\roots=8\TeV$ in bins 0-27\GeV (upper left), 27-52\GeV (upper right), 52-87\GeV (middle left), 87-130\GeV [84]
(middle right), 130-172\GeV (lower left) and $\geq$172\GeV (lower right).} [84]
    \label{fig:correlation_plots_8TeV_electron} [84]
\end{figure} [84]
[84]
[84]
\section{Background Subtraction} [2]
\label{s:background_subtraction} [2]
As a cross-check for the fitting process, an alternative method of extracting the number of \ttbar events [18]
using the background subtraction method was performed. The MC predictions of single top, \VpJets and QCD [33]
events is subtracted from the data in each bin to provide the \ttbar yield. The normalisations of these background [51]
processes is the same as previously used in the fitting method, \ie to their respective cross sections and [68]
luminosities. The resulting number of \ttbar events is then taken forward to the unfolding process. [82]
[82]
\section{Unfolding} [1]
\label{ss:unfolding} [1]
[1]
The measurement of the differential cross section will be limited by the finite resolution of the detector, [18]
detector acceptance and selection efficiency, and also by the presence of a small number of [33]
dilepton and fully hadronic \ttbar events, and semi-leptonic events in the tau channel. In order to allow [49]
later comparison of results with theory predictions and with measurements from other experiments, [62]
deconvolution (unfolding) is employed to provide an estimate of the true distributions of the measured [77]
variables. [78]
[78]
Generally speaking, any variable can be generated and reconstructed in simulation. Denoting the generated [92]
(``true'') distribution by a vector $x_{0}$, and the corresponding reconstructed distribution by $b_{0}$, [105]
these can be related by [110]
\begin{equation} [111]
\label{eq:unfolding_MC} [111]
\hat{A} x_0 = b_0. [111]
\end{equation} [111]
where $\hat{A}$ is the response matrix, containing information about how the true distribution is [125]
reconstructed and measured as the distribution obtained in the real world. The variable in question is then [142]
measured in reality to have some distribution, $b$, which is then related to the true distribution by [159]
\begin{equation} [160]
\label{eq:unfolding_data} [160]
\hat{A} x = b, [160]
\end{equation} [160]
and therefore [162]
\begin{equation} [163]
\label{eq:unfolding_data_rearranged} [163]
b = \hat{A}^{-1} x, [163]
\end{equation} [163]
Therefore, in this analysis, the system is solved to identify the true underlying distribution, $x$, using [179]
Singular Value Decomposition (SVD) \cite{Hocker:1995kb} of the response matrix, with the RooUnfold package [191]
\cite{Adye:2011gm}, and using regularisation overcome the problem of oscillating solutions. In SVD unfolding, [203]
the response matrix is factorised as follows: [210]
\begin{equation} [211]
\hat{A} = USV^{T}. [211]
\label{eq:response} [211]
\end{equation} [211]
$S$ is a diagonal matrix with non-negative diagonal elements of dimensions $m \times n$, and $U$ and $V$ are [228]
orthogonal matrices of dimensions $m \times m$ and $n \times n$ respectively. The diagonal elements of $S$ are [242]
called \textit{singular values} of the matrix $A$ and the columns of $U$ and $V$ are called the left and right [262]
\textit{singular vectors}. The inverse of the response matrix can then be stated as [275]
\begin{equation} [276]
\hat{A}^{-1} = VS^{-1}U^{T}. [276]
\label{eq:inverse_response} [276]
\end{equation} [276]
In systems in which the response matrix, $\hat{A}$, is of full rank (all columns and rows are linearly [294]
independent of each other) and statistical errors in the bins of the distribution are small, the problem can [312]
be solved simply using the inverted response matrix $\hat{A}^{-1}$. However, in most real life cases, this is [329]
not the case, leading to unphysical fluctuations~\cite{Hocker:1995kb}. Regularisation is used in SVD unfolding [342]
to help overcome this problem using a regularisation parameter, $k$, which specifies the number of [357]
statistically significant terms in the system. [363]
[363]
The value of $k$ can be obtained by considering a measured variable that follows a smooth [379]
distribution, an \textit{a priori} knowledge of the measured distribution, in which only the first few terms [395]
of the matrix decomposition are expected to be significant, with the contribution of higher, rapidly [410]
oscillating, terms expected to be compatible with zero~\cite{Hocker:1995kb}. The $i$th component of the vector [425]
$d$, $d_{i}$, is the coefficient of the measured distribution $b$. Using $d$, a vector obtained by rotating [442]
the measured distribution $b$, [446]
\begin{equation} [447]
d = U^{T}\times{b}. [447]
\label{eq:d} [447]
\end{equation} [447]
A plot of log\abs{d_{i}} versus $i$ can be plotted, where the bin number is represented by $i$. This will show [469]
$d_{i}$ as being statistically significant, \ie $d_{i}$ >> 1, for small $i$, and falling exponentially to a [484]
random Gaussian distribution about 0 for larger $i$. A falling exponential function plus a flat line can be [502]
fitted to this distribution, and the value of $i$ at which the $d_{i}$ changes from exponentially falling to [520]
within 10~\% of the flat component is taken as the value of the regularisation parameter, $k$, which [537]
represents the number of significant bins in the distribution \cite{Hocker:1995kb}. [546]
[546]
The value of $k$ should be between 2 and the number of bins in the distribution, and aims to prevent [566]
statistical fluctuations in the distribution being interpreted as real variations in the true data. A low [582]
value of $k$ favours the Monte Carlo truth input, while a high value of $k$ favours the measured data which is [603]
to be unfolded. The log\abs{d_{i}} plots for \met variable at $\roots=7\TeV$ is shown in [618]
Figure~\ref{fig:d_plots_7TeV}. The resulting $k$ values for both channels and both centre of mass energies are [633]
shown in Table~\ref{tab:best_k_values}. [636]
[636]
\begin{figure}[!] %hbtp] [636]
    \centering [636]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/unfolding_tests/8TeV/k_values/k_from_d_i_electron_channel_MET_data.pdf}\hfill [636]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/unfolding_tests/8TeV/k_values/k_from_d_i_electron_channel_MET_data.pdf}\\ [636]
\caption[log\abs{d_{i}} plots at $\roots=8\TeV$]{log\abs{d_{i}} plots at $\roots=8\TeV$ for the [636]
  electron+jets channel (left) and the muon+jets channel (right).} [636]
    \label{fig:d_plots_7TeV} [636]
\end{figure} [636]
[636]
\input{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/tables/unfolding/best_k_values} [636]
[636]
The required inputs to SVD unfolding with the RooUnfold package are: [647]
\begin{itemize} [647]
\item the simulated true distribution before selection [653]
\item the simulated reconstructed distribution after selection [659]
\item the two-dimensional reconstruction matrix of the true distributions after selection versus the [671]
measured distributions after selection. [675]
\end{itemize} [675]
[675]
All of the above are obtained from Monte Carlo simulations of \ttbar events. Unfolding is carried out to the [693]
semi-leptonic phase space, where the lepton is either an electron or a muon. In the cases of \met, \wpt and [711]
\mt, unfolding is carried out to the full phase-space where the \met is defined as the \pt of the neutrino [728]
from the semi-leptonic decay; and in the cases of \HT and \st, unfolding is carried out to particle level [745]
where the jets in the true distribution have $\pt\geq20\GeV$. [754]
[754]
Closure tests were carried out to verify the unfolding method using reconstructed simulated events as [769]
pseudo-data. A successful closure test results in the unfolded values matching the simulated truth of the same [786]
simulation sample, as can be seen in Figure~\ref{fig:unfolding_closure_tests} for the \met variable at [798]
$\roots=8\TeV$. [799]
[799]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [799]
    \centering [799]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/unfolding_tests/8TeV/closure/electron_MET_RooUnfoldSvd_closure.pdf}\hfill [799]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/unfolding_tests/8TeV/closure/muon_MET_RooUnfoldSvd_closure.pdf}\\ [799]
\caption[Unfolding closure tests for the \met variable at $\roots=8\TeV$.]{Unfolding closure tests performed [799]
  by unfolding the reconstructed \MADGRAPH distribution (``measured'') to generated values for the \met variable in the electron+jets channel [799]
  (left) and the muon+jets channel (right) at $\roots=8\TeV$.} [799]
    \label{fig:unfolding_closure_tests} [799]
\end{figure} [799]
[799]
The unfolding method described here was tested using toy Monte Carlo sets and producing pull distributions to [816]
investigate any potential bias in the method and to verify the unfolding error is estimated correctly. The [833]
central \ttbar \MADGRAPH sample is used to vary the contents in each bin of each primary variable distribution [849]
based on assumed Poissonian behaviour around the observed values. 300 sets of variations (henceforth referred [864]
to as models) are created, with the truth and reconstructed distributions varied independently, while another [879]
independent variation of the reconstructed distribution is used as the pseudo-data to be unfolded. This [894]
therefore creates $300\times300$ combinations of model and pseudo-data. The pull distributions are created as [908]
follows [909]
\begin{equation} [910]
\frac{N^{unfolded}-N^{true}}{\sigma} [910]
\label{eq:pulls} [910]
\end{equation} [910]
where $N^{unfolded}$ is the number of events in the unfolded result, $N^{true}$ is the number of events in the [929]
expected distribution after unfolding (Monte Carlo truth), and $\sigma$ is the unfolding uncertainty. Provided [943]
the unfolding uncertainty is estimated correctly and that there is no bias in the method, the pull [960]
distribution is expected to have a Gaussian distribution around a mean of 0 and a $\sigma$ of 1. Any bias [980]
would manifest as a pull distribution centred at a non-zero value, and any miscalculation of the [996]
unfolding uncertainty will result in a width of $<1$ or $>1$ for an overestimation or an underestimation [1013]
respectively. [1014]
[1014]
\begin{figure}[hbtp] [1014]
    \centering [1014]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/unfolding_pulls/8TeV/MET/electron/kv3/pull_from_files_all_bins_stats_65520.pdf}\hfill [1014]
   \includegraphics[width=0.48\textwidth]{Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/images/unfolding_pulls/8TeV/MET/muon/kv3/pull_from_files_all_bins_stats_65520.pdf}\\ [1014]
\caption[Pull distribution using toy Monte Carlo datasets for the \met variable using a $k$ value of 3 for [1014]
  the \met variable at $\roots=8\TeV$]{Pull distributions using toy Monte Carlo datasets for the \met variable [1014]
  using a $k$ value of 3 in the electron+jets channel (left) and in the muon+jets channel (right) at $\roots=8\TeV$.} [1014]
    \label{fig:unfolding_pull_tests} [1014]
\end{figure} [1014]
[1014]
\subsection{Measurement} [1]
\label{ss:measurement} [1]
[1]
The unfolded number of \ttbar events can now be used to calculate the normalised differential cross section in [18]
each bin of the primary variables by first calculating the average cross section in each bin using [35]
\begin{equation} [36]
\label{eq:finll_1} [36]
\Delta\sigttbar^i = \frac{\Nttbar^i}{\mathrm{BR} \times \mathcal{L}}. [36]
\end{equation} [36]
Here, the theoretical \ttbar semi-leptonic branching ratio is denoted by BR, $\epsilon$ is the total [50]
efficiency of the \ttbar simulation sample, and $\mathcal{L}$ is the luminosity of the recorded dataset. [64]
Subsequently, the differential cross section in each primary variable bin is calculated by dividing by the bin [81]
width $\Delta \mathrm{X}$ as follows: [85]
\begin{equation} [86]
\frac{\mathrm{d}\sigttbar^i}{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{X}} = [86]
\frac{\Delta\sigttbar^i}{\Delta \mathrm{X} } = \frac{\Nttbar^i}{\mathrm{BR} \times {\cal L} \times \Delta \mathrm{X}} . [86]
\end{equation} [86]
Finally, the normalised differential cross section in each bin is obtained by normalising to the total [102]
measured cross section [105]
\begin{equation} [106]
\label{eq:normalisedxs} [106]
\frac{1}{\sigttbar^\mathrm{tot}} \frac{\mathrm{d}\sigttbar^i}{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{X}} = [106]
\frac{1}{\sum\limits_{j}{\mathrm{d}\sigttbar^j}} \frac{\mathrm{d}\sigttbar^j}{\mathrm{d} \mathrm{X}} = [106]
\frac{\mathrm{BR} \times {\cal L}}{\sum\limits_{j}{\Nttbar^j}}\frac{\Nttbar^i}{\mathrm{BR} \times {\cal L} \times \Delta \mathrm{X}} = \frac{1}{\sum\limits_{j}{\Nttbar^j}}\frac{\Nttbar^i}{\Delta\mathrm{X}} [106]
\end{equation} [106]
 

  • Included file: Chapters/04_Analysis/04b_XSections/04b_DifferentialTTbarCrossSections_2.tex
